In this paper, we present a transformer network aimed primarily at detecting the precise timing of heart beats from predicted electrocardiogram (ECG) signals that are derived from input Ballistocardiogram (BCG) signals. We compared the performance of segment-based and subject-based models across three datasets: a dataset with 46 young, healthy subjects, a dataset with 28 older adults, and a combined dataset. The segment-based model demonstrated superior performance, with correlation coefficients of 0.97 for both, HR and mean heart beat interval (MHBI) when compared to ground truth ECG. This non-invasive method offers significant potential for long-term, in home HR and HRV monitoring, aiding in the early indication and prevention of cardiovascular issues.

title: Multi-Port Extended-Duty-Ratio Boost Converter for Hybrid Power Sources
authors: Hyeongmeen Baik, Isha Prabhu, Jinia Roy
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: Multi-port converters (MPCs) are increasingly employed to integrate renewable energy sources, energy storage systems, loads, and the utility grid, offering a reduced component count and improved overall efficiency by minimizing power conversion stages. In this work, the extended-duty-ratio (EDR) converter is explored for MPC operation. While the boost-derived EDR topology has been previously introduced as a non-isolated DC-DC converter with high voltage gain capability, conventional implementations have been limited to single-input configurations, restricting its applicability in MPCs that require multiple input sources. The proposed topology enables multiple input sources while allowing independent control of each phase, which is essential to achieve distinct control objectives of hybrid input power sources. A modified phase-shifted control strategy is proposed to reduce voltage stress on switching devices and is validated through theoretical analysis and simulations of a 4-phase EDR converter operating under different conditions. Additionally, its bidirectional operation is analyzed and verified through simulation for the 2-phase case.

title: Securing Cryptography in the Quantum Era: A Systematic Review of Post-Quantum Cryptography Solutions
authors: Adil Khan, Khawla Khamis, Maitha Al Mesafri, Fatma Mubarak, Rayan Mustafa, Usman Butt
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Business Analytics for Technology and Security (ICBATS)
abstract: With the constantly changing world of computers nowadays, the introduction of quantum computing has posed immense threats to the security of old and previous encryption algorithms. Post-Quantum Cryptography or PQC refers to a new generation of algorithms specifically created to resist the intense quantum computer attacks and offer secure and long-lasting protection to digital communications. As the potential of quantum technology becomes increasingly evident, the pursuit of secure, future-proof cryptographic solutions has never been more critical. This systematic review explores different PQC solutions for their strengths, weaknesses, and challenges of implementation. provides a comprehensive analysis of key studies on quantum-resistant algorithms, migration strategies and examines cryptographic security measures to present a complete picture of the latest advancements in quantum-safe cryptography. In this systematic paper, different PQC algorithms such as lattice, hash, code, multivariate and isogeny are reviewed along with their advantages and disadvantages. It also discusses how such findings will affect the security of real world communication, digital signatures, as well as blockchain security. This ensures how important it is to establish standardized PQC protocols for overall data security. This paper concludes with what future research directions and practical considerations relate to the adoption of PQC in critical infrastructures.

title: Multi-View 3D Reconstruction with Attention Mechanism and Dynamic Multi-Kernel Convolution
authors: JianAn Xie, Tao Liu
publish: 2025 18th International Congress on Image and Signal Processing, BioMedical Engineering and Informatics (CISP-BMEI)
abstract: To address the poor reconstruction quality in multi-view 3D reconstruction for scenes with weak texture, repetitive texture, and non-Lambertian surfaces, an improved network model based on Global Attention Mechanism (GAM) and Dynamic Multi-Kernel Convolution (DMC) is proposed. Using CasMVSNet as the baseline, GAM is incorporated to enhance feature extraction, while DMC is applied to improve cost volume regularization, thereby optimizing depth prediction accuracy and robustness. On the DTU dataset, the completeness and overall quality are improved by 21.5% and 7.3%, respectively. On the Tanks and Temples dataset, the F-score reaches 59.17, demonstrating the method's good generalization capability.

title: Non-Invasive Detection of Coronary Artery Disease and Valvular Disorders Using a Multichannel PCG Vest
authors: Matthew Fynn, Milan Marocchi, Arnab Maity, Kayapanda Mandana, Javed Rashid, Yue Rong, Goutam Saha
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Coronary artery disease (CAD) and valvular heart disorder (VHD) are major categories of cardiovascular disease (CVD), the leading cause of mortality and morbidity worldwide. CAD occurs due to plaque accumulation on the inner walls of the coronary arteries, restricting blood flow to the myocardium and potentially leading to heart attack or stroke. VHD refers to dysfunction in one or more heart valves, impairing blood flow between the heart’s chambers or to other systemic organs. Due to the prevalence of CVD, there is a global need for an effective screening tool capable of detecting various CVDs on a mass scale. Both CAD and VHD alter the acoustic signature of phonocardiogram (PCG) signals, offering a non-invasive detection method. This study implements a multiclass classification model to differentiate between CAD, VHD, and normal heartbeats, collected from subjects using an innovative wearable multichannel PCG vest. Linear frequency cepstral coefficients (LFCCs), coupled with a support vector machine (SVM) using a radial basis function (RBF) kernel, achieved the highest multiclass subject-level accuracy of 81.53%, with a sensitivity of 85.20% for VHD and 81.47% for CAD. Additionally, a binary classification task between normal and abnormal (CAD and VHD together) heartbeats reported an accuracy of 82.01%. This is the first study to apply multiclass classification across different CVD categories using PCG signals collected with the same hardware.

title: Efficient Simultaneous Wireless Power Transfer and High-Data-Rate Full-Duplex Communication Circuit for Implantable Medical Devices
authors: Qihang Zhang, Xiangsheng Xu, Congyi Qian, Songping Mai
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: This paper proposes a high-energy-efficiency wireless energy and data transmission circuit design that supports full-duplex communication. The circuit is designed for multi-channel neural implantable medical devices, enabling bidirectional high data rate communication with low power consumption while providing stable energy delivery. In the data link, the master device utilizes a switch module combined with a power amplifier (PA) to achieve amplitude shift keying downlink data transmission, supporting a maximum data rate of 1 Mbps under varying modulation depths. The slave device integrates a low-power transmitter based on an injection-locked ring oscillator and employs binary phase shift keying modulation, achieving a maximum data rate of 20 Mbps with an energy efficiency of 20.9 pJ/bit. In the energy link, the system adopts a zero-voltage switching feedback loop combined with a traditional Class-D PA circuit, ensuring soft switching under various load conditions. At an output power of 415 mW, the peak efficiency reaches 91.8%. The proposed transmission circuit is implemented in 180 nm BCD process.

title: A Deep Convolutional Network Based on Transformer for Disease Recognition Using Brain Connectivity
authors: Xinuo Huang, Yue Yuan, Binghao Shi, Xue Chen, Yanjiang Wang
publish: 2025 18th International Congress on Image and Signal Processing, BioMedical Engineering and Informatics (CISP-BMEI)
abstract: With the rising prevalence of mental disorders globally, there is an urgent need for more and more patients to receive early diagnosis and treatment. However, the current diagnostic approach for brain disorders is primarily based on subjective symptom criteria derived from clinical observation, which is both time-consuming and costly. In this study, we developed a deep learning framework that combines Channel-Space Self-Attention-Mechanism and convolutional networks (CSAM-CNN) to discriminate diseased participants from healthy controls using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) and diffusion tensor imaging (DTI), which helps clinicians in the early detection and categorization of brain illnesses. Specifically, firstly multimodal neuroimaging data and clinical priors are fused to create a disease-specific brain network. Then, a self-attention mechanism is proposed for obtaining spatial and temporal representations in brain networks. In addition, non-imaging information (age, gender, etc.) is introduced to address the issue of brain biology being ignored in disease classification tasks. Extensive experiments on disease prediction tasks demonstrate that the proposed CSAM-CNN achieves 92 % and 93.94 % classification accuracy on ABIDE (Autism Brain Imaging Data Exchange) and COBRE (Centre for Biomedical Research Excellence) datasets, respectively. Furthermore, our model can identify brain regions associated with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and schizophrenia (SZ). The approach accounts for individual differences and has the potential for application and clinical use in various brain diseases.

title: An Improved Switching Signal Split PWM for Switching Loss Reduction in Single Current Sensor Based Inverters
authors: Joon-Seok Kim, Byeong-il Kim, June-Hee Lee, June-Seok Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: This paper proposes an improved switching signal split PWM (SSSPWM) method to reduce switching loss in single current sensor (SCS) based current reconstruction. In conventional SSSPWM -based single current sensing methods, the phase voltage with the minimum or intermediate magnitude is split to ensure accurate current sensing. However, this approach introduces an additional switching event within two switching cycles, leading to increased switching loss. To address this issue, this paper proposes an improved SSSPWM technique that determines the phase for additional switching based on the stator current magnitude, selecting the phase with the smallest current. The proposed method minimizes switching loss while maintaining accurate current reconstruction. Furthermore, current reconstruction dead zone (CRDZ) variation with respect to power factors is analyzed, and potential issues arising from the proposed method are addressed with effective solutions. The feasibility of the proposed method is verified through simulation results.

title: Predicting Sustainability According to Banks' Financial Performance by Regression Model and Bee Algorithm
authors: Esraa Mohammed Abdulameer, Mohammed Ali Mosa Al-Mamoory, Nadia Talib Salman
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Business Analytics for Technology and Security (ICBATS)
abstract: This research aims to study and predict bank sustainability by analyzing financial performance using regression models and neural networks. The focus is on the main dimensions of financial performance, such as profitability, liquidity, efficiency, and financial stability, to determine their impact on the sustainability of banks. The research is based on a statistical questionnaire distributed to a number of bank employees. The regression model was used to analyze linear relationships between variables, while neural networks were employed to identify non-linear relationships and complex patterns in the data. The results showed expectations of the sustainability of banks by analyzing their financial performance based on statistical models and artificial intelligence analysis. Comparing the regression models and the bee algorithm showed that the sustainability prediction is better based on the bee algorithm at a rate that is the lowest in comparison and equals (0.121). Forecasts of financial performance can be enhanced by employing the dimensions of human resources variables and information technology.

title: Classification of ECG Arrhythmia Types Using 2D Recurrence Polar Maps and Deep Learning Techniques
authors: Amira Omar, Alaa Tarek, Tamer Basha
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Cardiac arrhythmias constitute a significant subset of cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) and can lead to severe complications such as stroke, heart failure, and sudden cardiac arrest. Accurate and timely diagnosis of arrhythmias is crucial for effective intervention, yet traditional electrocardiogram (ECG) interpretation relies heavily on expert analysis, which can be prone to variability. Recent advancements in machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) have shown promise in automating ECG analysis. However, existing one-dimensional (1D) approaches often fail to fully capture the spatial and temporal complexities of ECG signals. To address these limitations, we propose two novel two-dimensional representations for 12-lead ECG signals—Recurrence Polar Plots (RPP) and Cross Recurrence Polar Plots (CRPP)—which effectively reflect signal features while capturing the cyclic and directional patterns inherent to different leads. A multichannel neural network model is trained on these 2D maps to classify four major arrhythmia types. Our model achieves high classification accuracies: 84.0% for Atrial Fibrillation (AF), 94.5% for Sinus Tachycardia (ST), 91.5% for Sinus Bradycardia (SB), and 93.5% for Ventricular Tachycardia (VT), demonstrating the efficacy of leveraging complementary information from RPP and CRPP maps in a unified model for robust arrhythmia detection.

title: Reinforcement Learning with Dynamic Experience Integration for Edge-Aware Microservice Deployment
authors: Zhen Tang, Haifeng Sun
publish: 2025 18th International Congress on Image and Signal Processing, BioMedical Engineering and Informatics (CISP-BMEI)
abstract: The rapid expansion of Internet of Things (IoT) applications has significantly increased computational demands and latency requirements, creating challenges for deploying interdependent microservices on resource-limited edge nodes. This paper proposes a novel reinforcement learning (RL) framework for dynamic microservice deployment in edge computing environment, employing a Dynamic Experience-Integrated Proximal Policy Optimization (DEPPO) algorithm to jointly optimize service latency reduction and resource utilization efficiency. The framework dynamically adjusts deployment strategies by combining real-time data with a sliding window of dynamic experiences, enabling it to adapt to both immediate and long-term patterns. Experimental evaluations show that our approach outperforms traditional methods, achieving lower request latency and better resource utilization under varying workloads. Importantly, the framework demonstrates strong adaptability and stability to dynamic edge environments, offering a practical and scalable solution for real-world microservice deployment.

title: Precision Needle Localization Using Electromagnetic Tracking and AR Visualization in Ventricular Interventions
authors: S. Choi, K. Koo, T. H. Rho, C. U. Park
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: This study introduces an augmented reality (AR) system using electromagnetic (EM) stylet tracking to enhance surgical precision and patient safety for external ventricular drainage (EVD). By integrating a tablet PC, 3D camera, and EM tracking system, this study developed a real-time navigation method for catheter insertion. The system employs deep learning facial landmark detection and coordinate registration techniques to align CT, 3D camera, and EM tracking systems. A phantom model experiment was conducted with 20 trials: 20 drainage procedures and 20 accuracy measurements. All 20 drainage attempts were successful. And the Euclidean distance error for the 20 trials of measurement was 1.68 ± 0.66 mm. The research suggests significant potential for further development of AR technologies in neurosurgical interventions, highlighting the importance of continuous technological innovation in medical precision procedures.

title: A Novel EKF Optimization Algorithm Based on Nonlinear Compensation and Forgetting Factor
authors: Zedong Liang, Lu Liu, Shuo Zhang, Xiaomeng Zhang, Yilu Wang, Meng Yang
publish: 2025 18th International Congress on Image and Signal Processing, BioMedical Engineering and Informatics (CISP-BMEI)
abstract: To address the issue of increased linearization error and filter divergence in the Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) during abrupt target maneuvering, this paper proposes an EKF algorithm incorporating nonlinear compensation and a forgetting factor. Specifically, the measurement matrix of the EKF is redesigned as a time-varying nonlinear matrix to enhance target observability during maneuver transients. Historical innovations are stored via a sliding window to compute the covariance matrix, while a forgetting factor dynamically updates both the process noise covariance matrix and the measurement noise covariance matrix. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm significantly improves estimation accuracy during turning maneuvers and achieves superior overall localization performance compared to traditional EKF and adaptive EKF algorithms.

title: Non-Invasive In-Vivo Detection of Random Blood Glucose using Photoacoustic Spectroscopy
authors: P N S B S V Prasad V, Syed Ali Hussain, Nagamalleswari Katragadda, Biswabandhu Jana, Ch. Lakshmi Rajyam, Pranab Mandal, Pradyut Kumar Sanki
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: The random blood glucose monitoring is a quick testing at any time to detect hyperglycemia and decrease the risk of common health complications. This paper focuses on a non-invasive in vivo random blood glucose estimation using the Photoacoustic Spectroscopy (PAS) technique. A portable system has been designed to obtain the pre-processed Photoacoustic (PA) signal from a finger using a Laser source of wavelength 905 nm. The Partial Least Square Regression algorithm is implemented where the PA signal feature values are utilized for calibrating coefficients, while the Body Mass Index parameter is included for better accuracy. The study has been conducted on 32 subjects, and the performance is observed with the Clarke Error Grid and Bland-Altman Plots. The Mean Absolute Relative Difference, Mean Absolute Difference, and Root Mean Square values are estimated as 8.9%, 13.75 mg/dl, and 16.13 mg/dl, respectively. Overall, the proposed non-invasive random blood glucose monitoring technique can facilitate the growth of point-of-care applications for frequent monitoring, particularly in resource-limited settings, which facilitates proper diabetic management.

title: High-Fidelity Simulation Modeling of Dual Three-Phase PMSM Drive Based on Partially Linearized Flux Model
authors: Sangjun Na, Sungwon Hur, Jiwon Yoo, Jonghun Choi, Yunkyung Hwang
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: This paper presents a high-fidelity flux modeling method for dual three-phase permanent magnet synchronous motors (DTP-PMSMs). Conventional modeling approaches require solving nonlinear four-dimensional inverse functions, which significantly increase the computational burden and are impractical for real-time applications. To address this issue, a partially linearized flux modeling method is introduced based on decomposing the total flux linkage into average and differential components, derived from the rotating dq-axes stator current. In the proposed approach, the flux linkage associated with the average current is modeled using a nonlinear two-dimensional look-up table (LUT) derived from finite element analysis (FEA), while the differential current is approximated through the linearized model. The proposed approach reduces the dimensionality of the flux model and avoids the use of high-order inverse functions. The method captures key physical phenomena such as magnetic saturation and spatial harmonics. The proposed model is validated through simulation and experiments, demonstrating reliable accuracy with reduced computational complexity.

title: A Novel Strain-based Dynamic Left Ventricle Model for Surgical Planning and Training
authors: Angela Peloso, Martina Santoro, Emiliano Votta, Elena De Momi
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Digital twin technology is revolutionizing cardiovascular research by enabling patient-specific cardiac simulations. However, existing models often rely on computationally expensive mechanistic models, limiting their real-time clinical applicability. This study proposes a strain-based left ventricle (LV) digital twin that integrates myocardial deformation data from speckle-tracking echocardiography to achieve computational efficiency while maintaining high-fidelity LV wall motion. The LV wall was regionally divided according to standard echocardiographic views and modeled for longitudinal, circumferential, and radial strain components. Geometric deformations were simulated and animated using patient-derived strain data derived from the literature. Model validation against literature-derived peak systolic strain values demonstrated strong agreement, with minor discrepancies in the basal anteroseptal and apical regions due to anatomical constraints and modeling assumptions. The proposed framework offers a viable alternative for real-time cardiac motion simulation, bridging the gap between physiological fidelity and clinical usability. Future developments will focus on left atrial modeling, paving the way for digital twins that adapt dynamically to patient-specific data for enhanced intraoperative interventional planning and surgical training.Clinical relevance— This study proposes a strain-based left ventricle digital twin that can enhance patient-specific cardiac assessment, providing a non-invasive tool for functional evaluation, surgucal planning and intraoperative guidance.

title: Study of Wye-Delta Winding Topology for Permanent Magnet Synchronous Machines
authors: Md Sariful Islam, Mohammad Islam
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: This study investigates the application of a wye-delta <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(Y-\Delta)$</tex> winding configuration in a 3-phase permanent magnet-assisted synchronous reluctance machine (PMa-SynREL). The impact of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{Y}-\Delta$</tex> winding on key performance metrics-including average torque, torque ripple, machine parameters, and noise, vibration, and harshness (NVH)-is analyzed and compared with a conventional 3-phase wye (Y) connected configuration. The <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{Y}-\Delta$</tex> winding demonstrates improved performance, achieving a 4.8% increase in average torque and effectively canceling the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6^{th}$</tex> th-order (electrical) torque harmonic. However, torque ripple under the same load condition can vary with operating speed due to the circulating current. Additionally, the performance is compared with an equivalent dual 3-phase machine which has a 30-degree phase shift between the inverters. Experimental results using a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$Y$</tex> connected machine are also presented to validate the simulation results and the analysis approaches.

title: Neural network-based pose estimation and real-time tracking of ultrasound probes
authors: Cosimo Aliani, Alberto Morelli, Leonardo Bocchi
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Object tracking is a crucial component in the medical field, with great potential to enhance clinical workflows, particularly when integrated with augmented reality technologies. Accurate and reliable tracking systems can improve precision, usability, and operator feedback, facilitating innovative applications such as telemedicine, medical training, and robot-assisted procedures. This study evaluates the performance of FoundationPose, a neural network designed for six-degree-of-freedom pose estimation and real-time object tracking, in the context of ultrasound probe tracking. The RGB and depth images necessary for the network’s operation were acquired using an Intel RealSense D435 3D camera. The feasibility and accuracy of FoundationPose were evaluated by analysing its ability to estimate both the translational and rotational components of the probe’s pose. Experimental results demonstrated the network’s ability to achieve mean errors of less than 6mm in distance estimation and under 1° in rotation tracking, with low sensitivity to the initialisation point. These findings confirm the potential of FoundationPose for real-time ultrasound probe tracking in controlled conditions. Future developments could focus on integrating this system with augmented reality platforms to provide real-time visual guidance and enhance clinical applications.Clinical relevance—This system enables precise real-time ultrasound probe tracking, enhancing procedural accuracy and supporting advanced clinical applications like augmented reality guidance and robotic-assisted interventions.

title: Smartphone Dual-Camera based Blood Pressure Screening Using Pulse Transit Time Between Ear and Finger
authors: Qiang Wei, Jingyu Fu, Yingen Zhu, Yongshen Zeng, Lin Liu, Wenjin Wang
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: The advancement of smartphones, particularly the optical cameras and embedded sensors, has enabled the acquisition of physiological signals from the human body for health screening. This study proposes a framework using a smartphone’s dual-camera system to synchronously collect photoplethysmographic (PPG) signals from finger and ear for estimating blood pressure (BP). By calculating the Pulse Transit Time (PTT) between PPG signals from the ear and finger, and extracting heart rate and heart rate variability parameters, we estimate systolic and diastolic BP based on two personalized regression models. These estimates are then compared with the cuff-based reference. Experiments involving 15 participants demonstrated that the best performance was achieved using the physiological information extracted from PPG, such as PTT and heart rate, in combination with a random forest regression model. The mean absolute error for systolic/diastolic BP is 3.74 mmHg and 2.73 mmHg, with Pearson correlation coefficient of 0.877 and 0.868, validating the feasibility of BP screening using a smartphone dual-camera system.

title: Low-Complexity Triple-Vector Predictive Control for Five-Level Power Converters
authors: Yongdu Wang, Zhenbin Zhang, Yuanxiang Sun, Zhen Li, Ibrahim Harbi, Shuo Wang, Marcelo Heldwein
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: Five-level power converters present challenges for control design, since the number of internal states is relatively high and the degrees of freedom are many. This typically results in complex controller implementation. In this work, a low-complexity triple-vector finite-control-set model predictive control (FCS-MPC) with zero common-mode voltage (CMV) is proposed for five-level active neutral-point-clamped (5L-ANPC) power converters. Compared to conventional FCS-MPC for 5L-ANPC converters, the proposed approach directly identifies the optimal three vectors from a pre-selected vector space with zero CMV, eliminating the need for complex cost function evaluations as well. Furthermore, the duty ratios computation for triple vectors is optimized to improve steady-state control performance. The simulation and experimental results validate the proposed method, showing good current tracking and adequate voltage balance while reducing computational complexity.

title: Topology and Control of a Hexagonal Hybrid Frequency Solid-State Transformer
authors: Yichao Sun, Yinyu Yan, Carlos Teixeira, Xiong Yang, Hao Jiang, Yilin Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: As a critical component in future AC/DC hybrid distribution networks, existing hybrid-frequency solid-state transformers (HF-SSTs) with medium-voltage DC (MVDC) ports present challenges in frequency decoupling and power density optimization. This paper proposes a novel hexagonal HF-SST (HHF-SST) topology and its control strategy, eliminating the need for extra filters required by conventional designs. The proposed configuration integrates three decoupled ports, namely MVDC, fundamental-frequency medium-voltage AC (MVAC), and low-voltage DC (LVDC), through its unique hexagonal structure, achieving inherent port voltage/current frequency decoupling while enhancing power density and cost-effectiveness. A control strategy is proposed as well to ensure stable power transmission across multiple ports. Experimental validation via hardware-in-loop testing confirms the operational effectiveness and control performance of the proposed HHF-SST.

title: A Lightweight CNN-LSTM Approach for Accurate EEG Normal-Abnormal Classification
authors: Lan Wei, Catherine Mooney
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Electroencephalogram (EEG) is an important tool in diagnosing neurological conditions, with normal abnormal classification often serving as the first step in identifying abnormalities associated with various diseases. However, many previous methods for EEG classification have relied on nonpublic datasets, limiting accessibility and reproducibility. In this study, we propose a lightweight CNN-LSTM-based model for classifying normal and abnormal EEGs using the publicly available TUH abnormal EEG dataset. Unlike previous methods that require multiple EEG channels, our approach uses only the T5-O1 channel, reducing complexity and computational costs. Additionally, our model utilizes convolutional layers for automatic feature selection, allowing it to identify important features without manual intervention, improving efficiency. We also apply Gradient-weighted Class Activation Mapping to visualize the model’s output, enhancing interpretability.

title: Development of a simple softness measurement method using a wearable force sensor and depth camera for remote edema palpation
authors: Koki Ebina, Mitsuhiro Goto, Hitoshi Seshimo
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Telemedicine is becoming increasingly vital in improving access to healthcare in rural areas, increasing diagnostic efficiency, and reducing medical costs. Palpation is an essential diagnostic method that is widely used to assess a patient’s physical condition, and there are significant benefits to performing it remotely. However, there has been relatively little research on remote palpation, and the few studies that do exist have tended to use robotic manipulators, which come with several challenges such as initial cost, safety, and operability. Therefore, we proposed a form of palpation where nurses or the patient’s family perform the palpation on behalf of the doctor and transmit the sensing results. This study presents the development of a palpation system that can acquire the mechanical properties of the target tissue in real time by touching it with the hands without interfering with the user’s sense of touch. Our system features a simple yet effective configuration, comprising only a force sensor attached to the user’s nail and a depth camera. The results of calibration experiments using urethane gel confirmed that the proposed system can measure Young’s modulus with a mean absolute error of 26.15% when pressed in to produce a displacement of 4 mm. In addition, to apply this system to remote edema assessment, a classification model was created to discriminate edema grade into five levels using sensor data in a dry lab. The results of repeated and nested 10-fold cross-validation confirmed that edema could be discriminated with a median accuracy of 60.57%. This system is expected to provide accurate diagnostic information to doctors in remote areas and to improve the local medical system.

title: How do Body Mass Index (BMI) and Gender Affect Time-Up-and-Go Measurements
authors: Diego Rendon, Mario Ibarra, Irene Cheng
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Time-Up-and-Go (TUG) is a commonly used clinical test to evaluate an individual’s gait and frailty state. By combining TUG data with other knowledge, e.g., nutrition and daily habits, informed decisions can be made to delay the progression of or alleviate chronic diseases, such as Parkinson’s. Scheduling TUG tests in clinics requires assisted transportation and appointment. With the increasingly overloaded healthcare system, recent advances in e-Health provide an alternative solution. Research studies suggest that it is feasible to perform tests at home and automate gait analysis using intelligent software to classify frailty levels in a remote setting. This allows more frequent monitoring, and clinical appointments are made only to patients at higher risk or those in need. However, conducting the TUG test at home comes with challenges. In this paper, we discuss these challenges, e.g., cluttered environment, and propose solutions. In addition, we investigate whether Body Mass Index (BMI) and gender can affect gait measurement. Our experimental results demonstrate that some machine learning models perform better and the choice of input parameters plays an important role in the classification accuracy. Our experimental results demonstrate that high BMI can be reflected in an individual’s TUG, if a robust machine learning model is deployed, while men and women in general show distinct gait measurements. Based on this finding, different thresholds should be defined when making the frail, pre-frail and healthy assessment.

title: Microwave Imaging for Bone Regeneration Monitoring Using Magnetic Scaffolds: Preliminary Results
authors: Ehsan Akbari Sekehravani, Gennaro Bellizzi, Roberta Palmeri, Matteo B. Lodi, Lorenzo Crocco, Alessandro Fanti, Rosa Scapaticci
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Biomedical applications, both in therapy and diagnosis, are increasingly using magneto-dielectric composite materials. One notable example is magnetic scaffolds (MagS), which consist of a biomaterial matrix embedded with magnetic nanoparticles. These devices respond to external magnetic fields, triggering specific biological effects. This contribution explores the potential of using microwave imaging as a tool for monitoring bone healing and regeneration. In this context, implanted MagS, which are widely used to promote bone healing, are investigated. By leveraging their unique ability to respond to external magnetic fields, we demonstrate that MagS degradation, directly linked to bone healing, can be tracked through their microwave response. Preliminary results are reported in this paper.

title: Enhancing Segmentation Accuracy of the Common Iliac Vein in OLIF51 Surgery in Intraoperative Endoscopic Video through Gamma Correction: A Deep Learning Approach
authors: Kaori Yamamoto, Reoto Ueda, Kazuhide Inage, Yasuhiro Shiga, Yawara Eguchi, Masahiro Inoue, Satoshi Maki, Takeo Furuya, Seiji Ohtori, Sumihisa Orita
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: While minimally invasive surgery reduces the physical burden on the patient, the lack of depth perception and the difficulty in grasping the position and morphology of organs make it a burdensome procedure for the surgeon. In particular, when an endoscope is used to secure the field of view, two-dimensional images are used, making it difficult to fully grasp the complex three-dimensional structures and identify the organs. This problem is no exception in the treatment of spinal disorders. In lumbosacral anterolateral intervertebral fusion, which can treat a variety of spinal disorders, the common iliac vein (CIV), a type of vena cava, runs in the vicinity of the operative field. This vein has a fragile, thin wall and carries large volumes of blood at low pressure, which can cause fatal hemorrhage if injured intraoperatively. However, they are often located behind the peritoneum or arteries and are difficult to identify because of their similar redness to the surrounding tissues. This increases the risk of damage caused by surgical instruments during field development and intraoperative manipulation. In this technique, an assistive endoscope is used to secure the field of view. The surgeon compares the 3D construction images (MRI, CT, etc.) taken preoperatively with the actual space to ensure an appropriate surgical route. However, the identification of veins depends on the surgeon's experience, and only a limited number of physicians are able to perform this procedure safely and reliably. Therefore, an intraoperative support system is required to standardize the identification, but such a system has not been established. Therefore, we developed a method for automatic extraction of vein regions in endoscopic images to facilitate identification and reduce the risk of intraoperative injury by visually presenting the common iliac vein to the surgeon.

title: Preliminary Validation of a Cursive Handwriting Reconstruction Algorithm from a Sensorized Ink Pen
authors: Simone Toffoli, Chiara Gentile, Linda Greta Dui, Stefania Fontolan, Cristiano Termine, Simona Ferrante
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Lack of handwriting automatization in childhood can cause difficulties within and outside the school context. Therefore, the objective quantification of the handwriting performance is key. A Smart Ink Pen (SIP) used on paper demonstrated its validity in characterizing primary school children’s handwriting process, although missing information on the handwriting product. To overcome this limitation, a trace reconstruction algorithm was developed, based on the force and IMU signals measured by the SIP. A total of 353 words "uno", written in cursive from the BVSCO-3 battery by 50 Italian students of the 5<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sup> grade of primary school, was reconstructed. The quality of the reconstructions was validated through an Optical Character Recognition (OCR) algorithm (Google Vision), using the scans of the actual traces as a reference. The character recognition rates were 81.02% and 59.49%, the character error rates 21.48% and 47.65%, for scans and reconstructions, respectively. A deeper analysis revealed that 15% of the reconstructions were read in the opposite direction by the OCR algorithm, likely due to a non sufficient sampling rate for the last portion of the words. A characterization of the differences between the good, bad and opposite reconstructions allowed to identify some directions of improvement. An increase of the SIP sampling rate, a better modeling of the thickness of the trace, a finer estimation of the relative distance between the IMU sensor and the tip and the reconstruction of the tip trajectory during in-air movements could improve the trace reconstruction algorithm. In addition, the possibility to leverage transfer learning approaches on the OCR algorithm using the reconstructed traces for additional training could further improve the performances in terms of character recognition rate. However, the preliminary results obtained are promising and highlight the possibility of reconstructing handwriting traces while maintaining the naturalness of the gesture.Clinical relevance— This contribution establishes the possibility of reconstructing handwritten traces from the kinematic and force signals recorded by an ecological sensorized ink pen.

title: Interpretable Multi-Attention Fusion Mechanisms for Early Detection of Transitional Phases in Alzheimer’s Disease
authors: Meng-Chien Lin, Po-Chih Kuo, Yi-Tien Li, Cheng-Yu Chen
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Alzheimer’s disease (AD), a chronic neurodegenerative disorder, is characterized by progressive cognitive and memory decline, ultimately leading to physical deterioration and death. Early detection is essential for slowing the progression of symptoms and improving patient outcomes. Recent advancements in technology have led to the increased application of machine learning for AD detection. In this study, we aim to identify individuals at risk for future AD onset. To this end, we propose a Multi-Attention Gated Multimodal Unit model that integrates Electronic Health Records (EHRs) and Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) data. We also present an evaluation framework designed to measure the model’s effectiveness in early-stage AD detection. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach outperforms baseline models in recognizing early signs of AD. Furthermore, to enhance interpretability, we employ Gradient-Weighted Class Activation Mapping (Grad-Cam) heatmaps and attention maps, offering insights into the model’s decision-making process and its ability to detect crucial AD-related features at an early stage.

title: Individual Difference Frequency Adaptive Adjustment Method for Magnetic Resonant Human Body Communication
authors: Lina Chen, Shuang Yang, Han Wang, Jiejie Yang, Mang I Vai, Sio Hang Pun, Yueming Gao
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Magnetic resonant human body communication (MR-HBC) features ultra-low power consumption under resonance conditions, with flexible electrode configurations that enable contactless communication, making it suitable for various body area network applications. However, the resonance state is susceptible to the influence of different human body, leading to detuning and frequency shifts, which can cause communication interruptions. This paper proposes an adaptive adjustment method to address resonance frequency variations caused by individual differences, locking the resonance frequency by minimizing the reflection coefficient, ensuring that the MR-HBC system maintains high-quality communication resonance across different scenarios. Finite element analysis and in vivo experiments were conducted to investigate the effects of varying body fat content and different skin conditions, validating the accuracy and effectiveness of the adaptive adjustment system. The results show that resonance frequency fluctuations caused by individual differences are within 1.02 MHz, with a variation of up to 9.3%.Frequency variations result in a maximum increase of 14.53 dB in path loss, with inter-individual path loss differences reaching up to 28.9%. The integration of the adaptive adjustment system resulted in notable improvements, limiting the maximum locking error to 0.031 MHz, achieving an average enhancement of 12.96 dBm, and reducing MR-HBC transmission path loss by an average of 32.57%.

title: Spectral Differentiation of β-Carotene Accumulation Patterns in Skin Tissues with Distinct Levels of Constitutive Pigmentation
authors: Gladimir V. G. Baranoski
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: The accumulation of β-carotene in human skin has been connected to various forms of protection offered by this ubiquitous carotenoid, from the absorption of ultraviolet radiation to the neutralization of reactive oxygen species. These protective mechanisms, in turn, are likely to be associated with the accumulation pathways of this pigment, via the top (epidermal) and/or the bottom (dermal) cutaneous tissues. The differentiation of the distinct accumulation patterns of β-carotene through noninvasive methodologies is still an open problem, however, notably for skin specimens with relatively high levels of constitutive pigmentation. In this paper, we address this open problem by proposing and evaluating three spectral tests based on carotenemia-elicited variations in skin reflectance within the red end of the visible spectrum. Their efficacy is examined using a first-principles in silico experimental framework grounded on measured data for different skin specimens. The outcomes of our investigation indicate that the use of such a spectral testing approach can lead to reliable and cost-effective differentiation assessments of distinct β-carotene accumulation patterns in skin tissues.

title: A Multistate Network Approach for Resilience Analysis of Logistic System Based on Disjoint Minimal Path Vectors
authors: Yanxuan Hong, Tao Liu, Shuai Zhang, Guanghan Bai, Junyong Tao
publish: 2024 15th International Conference on Reliability, Maintenance and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: As the modern warfare switch towards to integrated joint operations, the complexity and multidimensionality of operational requirements places elevated demands on logistic system. Addressing the exigencies of resource provisioning under highly adversarial and uncertain battlefield, we introduced a logistic system model that incorporates the multistate characteristics of the logistic network. Firstly, a multistate network model is formulated to accommodate the dynamic and stochastic nature of logistic system. Subsequently, to address the need for flexibility and diversity in logistic systems, the performance metric of multistate network predicated on disjoint minimal path vectors is proposed. This foundation is then leveraged to assess network resilience across two critical dimensions: temporal resilience and operational resilience. Empirical investigation through case study demonstrated the model’s accuracy in navigating the inherent uncertainties and complexities inherent in dynamic combat theaters, thereby providing a robust data-driven framework for the design and refinement of logistic system.

title: Initial Position and Speed Estimation for Flying Start of a Synchronous Reluctance Motor Using Stationary-Frame Current Control
authors: Daiki Kato, Keiichiro Kondo, Takumi Ito
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: This paper proposes a method for estimating the initial rotor position and speed to enable continuous-operation flying start of a synchronous reluctance motor (SynRM). First, the method estimates the rotor angle and speed from the inverter's voltage vector while maintaining a constant αβ current in the stationary reference frame. Experimental validation using a 1.5 kW SynRM demonstrates that the proposed method enables accurate initial estimates. Furthermore, the influence of deviations in key motor parameters on estimation errors is thoroughly analyzed.

title: Patient-Specific Depth Error Correction in Dual-Sensor System for Image-Guided Minimally Invasive Facial Osteotomy
authors: Khaing Thandar Hnin, Yong Gi Jung, Sunghwan Lim
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: This study introduces a patient-specific method for real-time depth error correction, improving the accuracy of the dual-sensor system previously developed by our team for image-guided facial osteotomy. The system integrates two RGB-D sensors with time-of-flight (ToF) technology and an optical localizer, enabling simultaneous real-time tracking of both the patient and surgical tools. Due to anatomical variations in facial skin, ToF sensors are susceptible to depth inaccuracies, requiring a tailored correction strategy. The proposed method uses the probe’s tip position, tracked by the optical localizer, to estimate parameters for an error model and correct depth inaccuracies. This real-time, patient-specific depth error correction significantly improves both registration and shape sensing accuracy. Validations using three patient mockups demonstrated a 87% reduction in depth errors, with an average fiducial registration accuracy of 2.33±0.23mm and an average shape sensing accuracy of 2.25±0.38mm. These results highlight the potential of patient-specific depth error correction to improve registration accuracy, thereby ensuring reliable and precise guidance, which may improve clinical outcomes in minimally invasive facial osteotomies.Clinical relevance—This method has the potential to enhance the accuracy of real-time guidance in image-guided facial osteotomies by correcting depth errors and improving image-to-patient registration accuracy, thereby contributing to better clinical outcomes and increased patient safety.

title: Comparative study of HD-EMG electrode setups for Smart Mechatronic Ankle-Foot Orthoses development
authors: Marta Mirkov, Matija Štrbac, Ivan Vujaklija
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Smart mechanized ankle-foot orthoses aim to enhance rehabilitation and mobility assistance by integrating advanced human-machine interfaces. This study evaluates different high-density electromyography (HD-EMG) electrode configurations to investigate signal quality for future designs, addressing challenges in sensor variability and noise. By analyzing dorsiflexion and plantarflexion movements with HD-EMG arrays placed over the tibialis anterior and gastrocnemius medial muscles of 4 healthy participants, the research identifies configurations that improve signal quality and enable better integration into future ankle-foot orthoses. The results demonstrate that the electrodes with smaller surface area of sensors provide higher signal-to-noise ratio and more stable signals compared to the larger electrodes with a higher interelectrode distance. Additionally, while printed electrodes tend to offer greater comfort, due to their flexible design, they performed worse in comparison to their conventional counterparts. The study highlights the need for further investigation of alternative printed interfaces and materials, which will allow for smaller and more densely placed electrode pads while retaining the overall malleability.Clinical relevance— The results of this study provide guidance for future HD-EMG system designs for integration into advanced ankle-foot orthoses, which are used in the rehabilitation of mobility problems.

title: Simulation, Design and Prototyping of a Diaphragm for the Acquisition of Lung Sounds
authors: Marco Modena, Alessandro Bertacchini, Fabrizio Pancaldi
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: This paper investigates the effect of diaphragm on the sensitivity and bandwidth of electronic stethoscopes. The analyzed system includes the lung, human body, diaphragm, and microphone. A simulation framework was developed using parameters devised from respiratory mechanics, commercial components and practical characterizations. Numerical simulations were compared to experimental data collected with the electronic stethoscope prototype we developed. The predicted pressure at the microphone closely matched the experimental measurements carried out during outpatient visits at the University Hospital of Modena (Italy). All the human subjects involved in these measurements were volunteers and gave their informed consent. Based on the simulation results, we designed a diaphragm optimizing bandwidth and gain. Interestingly, the optimal configuration weakly depends on the damping factor. In fact, bandwidth and gain of the frequency response function of the system are affected by less than 1% if the damping factor is changed over ±3 orders of magnitude around the optimal value. A prototype has been produced in ONYX® material under the optimal configuration. The prototype is 3D-printed in a single block composed of a central disc capturing and transferring vibration waves, a suspension that links the central disc to the outer ring and a joint to fix the diaphragm to the stethoscope body. The predicted mechanical characteristics are Young modulus of 2.4 GPa and density of 1200 Kg/m3.Clinical Relevance— The shortage of general doctors and physicians is a major issue for modern healthcare systems, as well as high facility and maintenance costs, prevent the wide diffusion of advanced medical test laboratories. The development of new and cheap diagnostic tools is crucial to address these challenges. By developing this application and refining the vibrating membranes, which act as the 'ear' of the stethoscope, it will be possible to reliably and early detect pulmonary diseases directly through auscultation. This would eliminate the need for specialized visits, which require professionals not always available in the field, as well as highly expensive equipment that is not universally accessible, particularly in less affluent regions. Recent studies showed that electronic stethoscopes can improve the capability of detecting pulmonary diseases, such as interstitial lung diseases. Indeed, the diaphragm (or membrane) is a fundamental component of stethoscopes and plays a significant role in its performance, although its exact influence on acoustic coupling remains mostly unclear.

title: Intelligent Switching Optimization Using Quantum Differential Evolution in 13- Level Switched-Capacitor Inverter
authors: Arya Singh, Ranjit Mahanty, Vivek Nandan Lal, Rajeev Kumar Singh
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: Multilevel inverters (MLIs) are essential in modern power electronics; however, conventional designs often require numerous components, which makes them complex and bulky. This paper presents a 13-level switched-capacitor multilevel inverter (SC-MLI) that utilizes minimal hardware, featuring a single DC supply, 11 switches, 2 diodes, and 3 capacitors, with achieving a high voltage gain of six. A distinctive switching ensures capacitor charging in a 1:1:3 ratio with inherent self-balancing. A key problem in MLIs is elimination of dominant lower-order harmonics. This paper employs the Quantum Differential Evolution (QDE) algorithm to compute the optimized switching angles for selective harmonic elimination pulse width modulation (SHE-PWM). QDE solves the nonlinear SHE-PWM equation in less than 20 iterations, showing better tracking efficiency. A 500 W prototype validates the proposed SC-MLI performance under varying loads and modulation indices. The proposed SC-MLI with no additional input inductance and auxiliary circuits minimizes inrush current, reduces component count, weight, and reliance on bulky filters.

title: Safe Stabilization for Control-Affine Systems Using Non-Smooth Control Lyapunov Barrier Function
authors: Jianglin Lan, Congcong Sun
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Control and Fault-Tolerant Systems (SysTol)
abstract: Stabilizing dynamic systems to the desired equilibrium whilst avoiding unsafe state regions is crucial for safety critical systems. This paper presents a new control design to ensure safe stabilization for control-affine systems that are fully-actuated or over-actuated. We introduce the concept of non-smooth control Lyapunov barrier function (NCLBF) and design a NCLBF-based piecewise continuous feedback control to achieve safe stabilization. Rigorous theoretical analysis and extensive simulations demonstrate the effectiveness of our method in achieving safe stabilization for systems with single or multiple bounded unsafe state sets, as well its superiority over the existing smooth control Lyapunov barrier function method.

title: Enhancing Automated Patient Detection and Tracking in Epilepsy Monitoring Unit Videos
authors: Daniel A. Galindo Lazo, Isabel Sarzo Wabi, Amirhossein Jahani, Oumayma Gharbi, Tan T. Nguyen, Nicolas Nguyen, Manon Robert, Juan P. Millan Sandoval, Gianluca D’Onofrio, Ke Peng, Dang K. Nguyen, Elie Bou Assi
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Continuous patient monitoring using automated algorithms has the potential to reduce risks associated with seizures by accelerating interventions. Video monitoring offers a practical alternative; however, seizure detection algorithms could learn to associate incidental events with seizure activity, introducing biases during both the training and the testing phases. By incorporating patient tracking into seizure detection algorithms, patients can be isolated within video frames, reducing biases and improving specificity. As no existing object detection models are pre-trained to identify patients as unique class of individuals, a YOLOv8 model was fine-tuned using 1,590 manually labeled frames from 131 patients admitted to our epilepsy monitoring unit, capturing daily activities, seizures, and body occlusions in both daytime and nighttime. Hyperparameter optimization was performed using a grid-search with a five-fold cross-validation on the training and validation set (85% of the data), while 15% was reserved as a held-out test set. Data were split on a patient-wise basis to prevent data leakage across patients. Additionally, a novel post-processing pipeline for videos was developed to further improve performances. The fine-tuned model achieved 97.6% recall and 96.8% precision, detecting patients under diverse conditions. The post-processing pipeline was evaluated on four new seizure videos, correcting 577 out of 580 misclassified or missed detections in these videos. Combined with the novel post-processing step, the proposed pipeline offers a promising tool for enhancing video-based seizure detection.Clinical relevance— This approach reduces misattributions in video-based seizure detection, leading to more reliable, biasfree monitoring. Thus, it enables faster and more accurate interventions, improving patient safety.

title: Bioimpedance monitoring of arrested myocardium during open-chest surgery: from coronary artery occlusion to cardiac resuscitation
authors: M. Min, P. Annus, M. Rist, R. Land, A. Krivošei, A. Ruusalepp, K. A. Ruusalepp, O. Märtens
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: In this paper, we discuss an original approach to assessment of the myocardial condition during open-chest cardiac surgery by the aid of online sensing of the electrical bio-impedance. We introduce suitable electrode arrangements and modern micro/nano size electronic components to formulate and design the system of active electrodes that can be glued onto the epicardium of heart muscle, which is silenced chemically using cardioplegia. The designed system demonstrates reasonable resolution in detecting impedance changes under controlled conditions.Clinical Relevance—Although the possibility of using the electrical bioimpedance measurement to assess the physiological state of the myocardium has been known for almost four decades, this method has not yet reached practical surgery. This paper aims to address the obstacles that have hindered the bio-impedance-based approach.

title: Proposal of High-Power Bearingless Machines for Flying Cars and eVTOLs
authors: Hisato Nakamura, Hiroya Sugimoto
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: This paper proposes novel topologies for high-power bearingless machines for flying cars and electric vertical take-off and landing aircraft (eVTOLs). The five degrees of freedom (5DOF) are actively positioned to achieve full magnetic suspensions. The proposed machine has a turbine blade inside the rotor without a rotor shaft and mechanical bearings so that it contributes to enhance efficiency and reliability. In this paper, three bearingless topologies are compared with respect to the magnetic circuits, suspension forces, the number of inverters, the number of switches and DC link voltages. In particular, an axial suspension force is a key performance index to overcome a maximum take-off weight. In three-dimensional finite-element-method (3D-FEM) analysis, it is verified that the calculated axial suspension force is sufficient in the proposed 5DOF bearingless motor.

title: An Implementation Of The Particle Swarm Optimization Algorithm To Maximize The Profits Of The Petrochemical Industries Company In Iraq
authors: Hala Sabah. Radhi, Mousa Kadhim Wali, Teeb Hussein Hadi
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Business Analytics for Technology and Security (ICBATS)
abstract: Algorithms for optimization are required to tackle numerous issues related to a company's earnings. One of these optimization algorithms is Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO). The PSO algorithm aims to find the best solution within the search space. This study emphasizes the basic background of understanding and applying the PSO algorithm. The first topics addressed in this work are the PSO method, the search space, and how to move particles to obtain the optimal or nearly optimal solution. The research was based on data from the Iraqi National Company for Chemical and Plastic Industries, a mixed joint stock company and part of the Iraq Stock Exchange. The data was recorded for two years (2016–2017) based on the company's monthly profits from marketing its products in Iraqi dinars. The PSO algorithm was applied to show how to move particles to search for the optimization problem of finding the required profits with the least frequency. The algorithm's effectiveness was analyzed with the help of the five particles mentioned in the data. (Matlab R2011a) the program was used to implement the proposed algorithm based on the validity criteria, which included accuracy and mean square error, which gave 97.118% and 0.02882, respectively.

title: Robotic Arm Surgery vs. Human Hand Surgery: A Comparative Analysis for Minimally Invasive Procedures
authors: Jessie R. Balbin, Benjie T. Guiwo, Noel A. Salalila, Esperanza E. Chua, Kallista Coleen T. Antenor, Allana Kyle H. Deang, Sumin Yoo, Marlon Jim P. Garino
publish: 2024 IEEE 16th International Conference on Humanoid, Nanotechnology, Information Technology, Communication and Control, Environment, and Management (HNICEM)
abstract: This study explores the comparative efficacy and precision of robotic arm surgery versus human hand surgery. By examining clinical outcomes, procedural accuracy, and patient recovery metrics, it aims to provide a detailed understanding of the advantages and limitations of each approach, thereby aiding in optimizing surgical practices and patient care.

title: A Proposed IoT-Cloud Framework for Archaeological Preservation: Preliminary Design and Case Study
authors: Rana Fadhil Rasheed, Dhuha Basheer Abdullah, Auday h. Al-Wattar
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Business Analytics for Technology and Security (ICBATS)
abstract: This paper explores the use of cloud-based realtime Internet of Things (IoT) technologies to improve the preservation and visitor engagement at Nineveh's archaeological sites. The research aims to develop a comprehensive IoT solution that enhances the preservation of Nineveh's archaeological sites while improving visitor experiences through real-time monitoring and interactive technologies. It accentuates the threats posed by environmental degradation and vandalism to the site's heritage by reviewing the current preservation status and determining suitable IoTs for monitoring. The study implements IoT sensors for critical environmental monitoring, creates a cloud-computing platform for real-time data inspection and Employing special platforms to train artificial intelligence models for preventive maintenance, predicting risk situations, and issuing alerts when such situations occur. Furthermore, it incorporates augmented and virtual reality (AR, VR) to foster visitors' engagement and knowledge of Nineveh's cultural heritage, to develop a framework to protect archaeological assets while enriching visitor interactions.

title: Navigating Severe Class Imbalance in Population Cohort Data
authors: Joshua Fieggen, Bradley Segal, Emma C. Walker, Anshul Thakur, Christopher C. Butler, David A. Clifton, Lei Clifton
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Class imbalance is a major challenge in predictive modelling for rare disease outcomes, particularly in large-scale population cohorts. Traditional machine learning models often struggle with imbalanced datasets, leading to biased performance metrics and poor generalisability. This study systematically evaluates multiple approaches to mitigate class imbalance in predicting Multiple myeloma using proteomic and clinical data from UK Biobank. We compare standard classification models (XGBoost and logistic regression) with synthetic resampling (SMOTE), anomaly detection techniques (isolation forests, local outlier factors, one-class SVM, and autoencoders), and a transformer-based foundation model (TabPFN), using standard classification performance metrics. Our results indicate that anomaly detection models generalise better than conventional classifiers (XGBoost and logistic regression), while SMOTE fails to improve, and may actively worsen, predictive performance. To address the precision-sensitivity trade-off, we introduce a sequential XGBoost ensemble classifier (SeqXGB) that prioritises high precision over sensitivity to minimise false positive predictions. Compared with a single XGBoost model, the SeqXGB approach successfully reduces false positives (420 vs 9), but significantly limits sensitivity (0.70 vs 0.15) in held-out test data. Our findings highlight that no single method is universally optimal for addressing class imbalance; rather, model selection should be guided by clinical application, balancing the risks of false positives and false negatives.Clinical relevance— This study highlights the challenges with using machine learning to predict diseases in highly imbalanced large population cohorts and underscores the need to consider clinical purpose (e.g. screening vs diagnosis) when evaluating models.

title: Thermal Safety Management and Thermal Runaway Diffusion Test Cases Analysis of Lithium-Ion Power Battery Systems
authors: Jun Tian, Chunchang Xu, Hongbo Gao, Haiju Wang, Baosen Cao, Yanwei Wei, Huipeng Tang, Haochen Wang, Qi Wan, Xiaoqiang Liang
publish: 2024 15th International Conference on Reliability, Maintenance and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: Based on typical thermal management and thermal runaway test cases of power battery systems, this study summarizes the test methods and procedures for thermal management, analyzes the test assessment indicators for thermal management and the specific test process of temperature changes in the battery system. It also summarizes the standards, methods, and procedures for thermal runaway propagation, and analyzes the temperature and voltage changes during the thermal runaway propagation process. This research shows that the establishment of cooling strategy and temperature monitoring is the key point of heat management test, while the thermal runaway trigger strategy and temperature monitoring is the key factor of thermal runaway test. This research plays a significant reference role in systematically improvement in thermal management design, safety design, battery management system protection and early warning of vehicle power battery system.

title: A New Method for Spacecraft Attitude Estimation Based on Prior Models and ISAR Images
authors: Yuqiang Liang, Jue Wu, Zhihui Li
publish: 2025 18th International Congress on Image and Signal Processing, BioMedical Engineering and Informatics (CISP-BMEI)
abstract: Spacecraft attitude estimation can be applied to various space missions, including state assessment, on-orbit maintenance, and debris removal. Currently, Inverse Synthetic Aperture Radar (ISAR) has become a mainstream sensor for observing spacecraft, providing crucial information for attitude estimation. This paper proposes a novel method based on ISAR images and prior three-dimensional models. This method calculates loss values by matching key points between ISAR images and model key points, establishing an optimization function to solve for the spacecraft's attitude angles. When the candidate attitude of the geometric model aligns with the true attitude, the loss value from key point matching reaches its minimum. To improve the search efficiency for spacecraft attitude angles, the Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) algorithm is employed. Compared to methods based on target contours, this method leverages key point matching, demonstrating stronger robustness to noise and yielding smaller estimation errors. Experimental results validate the accuracy and effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Factors Influencing the Proficiency of Second Year Bachelor of Secondary Education Students: a Case Study in Aldersgate College Inc., Philippines
authors: James Patrick Vincent C. Abalos, Jonard D. Balinbin, Virginia G. Molina, Rocele D. Nanale, Rechelle Anne V. Ramos, Skarlet Faith S. Nanale, Aprilene F. Villa, Jovelyn A. Detablan
publish: 2024 IEEE 16th International Conference on Humanoid, Nanotechnology, Information Technology, Communication and Control, Environment, and Management (HNICEM)
abstract: This study intends to determine the level of English language proficiency among second-year Bachelor of Secondary Education students in the School Year 2023-2024. Additionally, it sought to identify the strengths of these students in English, given their future roles as English teachers. Utilizing a descriptive- correlational research design, the study seeks to assess the relationships between the demographic profile of the respondents, their English language proficiency levels, and the factors influencing their proficiency. Survey questionnaires were employed to gather the necessary data. The findings revealed key characteristics of the demographic profile of the second-year Bachelor of Secondary Education students at Aldersgate College. Most students were female, aged between 19 to 21 years old, and of Ilocano ethnicity, often speaking Iloco. They predominantly came from public high schools and almost half achieved the passing scores on the English proficiency test. Additionally, many students' parents worked as farmers or housewives. The study identified family as a significant influencer of English language proficiency among these students. Despite these, students demonstrated a high level of proficiency across listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills. When grouped by sociodemographic profiles, no notable differences emerged in the factors affecting English proficiency levels. Similarly, no significant relationship was observed between English proficiency levels and the influencing factors, regardless of how students were grouped based on their profile variables.

title: Technological and Biomechanical Advances in Handcycling: A Multidisciplinary Perspective on Inclusive Sport Engineering
authors: Laura Gastaldi, Alessandro Di Gesù, Chiara Gastaldi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Workshop on Sport, Technology and Research (STAR)
abstract: This article provides a multidisciplinary perspective on the evolution of the handbike, detailing its historical, biomechanical, and technological dimensions. Beginning with its origins in the 17th century as a mobility aid, the paper traces the rise of competitive handcycling and athlete profiles, highlighting the physical, technical, and psychological requirements of the discipline. It describes the main handbike types (upright, recumbent, off-road) and key biomechanical parameters (crank axis position, crank length, grip angle, propulsion strategies) that influence performance. A dedicated focus is given to "Cerberus," the Politecnico di Torino’s record-breaking handbike prototype: a fully faired recumbent handcycle developed through athlete 3D scanning, CFD simulations, and on-road testing, achieving an exceptionally low drag coefficient of 0.0325. Cerberus reached 83.28 km/h at the 2024 World Human Powered Speed Challenge, surpassing the previous world record. The article demonstrates how the integration of engineering, biomechanical research, and parasport can drive performance, safety, and inclusivity—reshaping the boundaries of human mobility

title: Tissue Individual Signatures through Machine Learning Analysis of Ultrasound Images
authors: Katarzyna Heryan, Joanna Sorysz, Michael Friebe
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Advancements in sensors, computing, and surgical data science have significantly enhanced minimally invasive procedure, offering benefits such as reduced trauma, faster recovery, and lower infection risk. Despite these improvements, challenges persist regarding intraoperative accuracy, safety, and localization of surgical tools. Ultrasound imaging, while widely used for real-time visualization, faces limitations such as artifacts and poor alignment with instruments during procedures. This study presents a preliminary framework for ultrasound-based classification of materials with tissue-like properties using machine learning algorithms. Artificial phantoms constructed from accessible materials and biological tissues were imaged with ultrasound. Extracted image features were preprocessed using Gabor, Tamura, and Hessian filters, followed by statistical parameterization. Classification models including Random Forest, Support Vector Machines, and Discriminant Analysis were evaluated using the F1 score, achieving up to 0.8 in classification performance. The results indicate that ultrasound imaging, combined with statistical learning, has the potential to differentiate materials with tissue-relevant properties. This approach may contribute to enhanced intraoperative navigation and real-time tissue characterization. Future work will include dataset expansion, statistical validation, and integration with clinical systems.

title: Investigation of Multi-Tooth Dual-PM Machines Accounting for Different Cooling Strategies
authors: Ankan Dey, Z. Q. Zhu, Dawei Liang, Xu Hai, Liang Chen, Lei Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: This paper investigates the operational torque and torque density of multi-tooth dual-permanent magnet (PM) machines (MT-DPMMs), considering the effect of various cooling strategies including natural cooling (NC), forced air cooling (FAC), and water jacket cooling (WJC). A 6-stator slots with 10 rotor pole pairs MT-DPMM is analyzed, considering thermal constraints of the windings and PMs. Through finite element analysis and computational fluid dynamics, it is shown that PM thermal constraints limit the torque density of MT-DPMMs, especially under NC and FAC, while WJC enables the designed electromagnetic torque density. Additionally, the torque density exhibits a greater dependence on stator-PM grade compared to rotor-PM grade, especially at high torque levels, notably with FAC. A prototype machine is fabricated for experimental validation.

title: Univariate Electricity Demand Transfer Forecasting Framework Under Data Scarce Scenario in Selected Visayas Subgrids
authors: Jayson C. Jueco, Norman Digma Romulo, Chrisley Jake Anahaw, Allen Vincent Navesis, Antonio Jose Tuazon, Ferdinand F. Batayola, Marvin A. Radaza, Xavier Julian P. Fernandez, Wilen Melsedec O. Narvios, Maria Gemel B. Palconit
publish: 2024 IEEE 16th International Conference on Humanoid, Nanotechnology, Information Technology, Communication and Control, Environment, and Management (HNICEM)
abstract: Traditional forecasting methods often produce unreliable results in data-scarce and complex environments like the Visayas region. This paper introduces a new univariate electric demand forecasting method that utilizes Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) combined with Transfer Learning techniques to address these challenges. By leveraging transfer learning, the model improves generalization across various sub-grids and mitigates the limitations of traditional methods. The paper effectively tackles data scarcity and demonstrates the ability to achieve precise load demand forecasts. The datasets from both domains show perfect cosine similarity with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\cos\theta=1$</tex> and a weak positive monotonic relationship, as indicated by Spearman's rank correlation coefficient <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\rho=0.2877$</tex>. Despite <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\rho < \cos \theta$</tex>, the datasets have substantial similarities. The model significantly reduces data requirements and achieves average errors of 5.63 %, 5.15 %, 4.50 %, and 5.35 %, highlighting its efficiency in improving forecast accuracy. Experimental results emphasize the potential of LSTM and transfer learning in addressing data limitations and optimizing resource management in the Visayas sub-grid and similar contexts.

title: Leveraging Transfer Learning and Monte Carlo Dropout for Uncertainty Informed NIRS-based Detection of Systemic Sclerosis Hand Perfusion Patterns
authors: F. Bargagna, S. Berhami, G. D’Angelo, L. Gargani, N. Vanello, M. F. Santarelli, V. Positano, V. Hartwig
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Early diagnosis of systemic sclerosis (SSc) is critical for early intervention and improved patient outcomes. This study explores the integration of near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) with deep learning for classification of SSc patients based on hand perfusion patterns.
