The proposed framework establishes a scalable and secure architecture for intelligent condition monitoring of wind turbine blades, integrating edge computing, wireless sensor networks, and predictive modeling techniques.

title: Machine Learning for IoT Device Security in Smart Homes
authors: Mohammad Abu Kausar, Yousif Khalid Yousif, M. Al Batahari, Mohammad Nasar, Nidal A. Al-Dmour, Ali Q Saeed
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Business Analytics for Technology and Security (ICBATS)
abstract: The massive rise of smart home Internet of Things (IoT) devices has provided immense comfort and automation, but it has also led to greater security vulnerabilities. Because of these limitations, the multidimensional protocols as well as decentralized nature of these devices, ensuring the security of such devices becomes an unavoidable issue. In this article, we are discussing how the application of machine learning (ML) techniques can help in improving IoT device security in smart homes. The study employs algorithms of ML in real time to detect and mitigate possible faults such as unauthorized access, dysfunctional behavior, or data leaks. A comprehensive pattern of IoT ecosystems combining supervised, unsupervised, and reinforcement learning methods is proposed to be the practical solution. Finally, we have conducted experiments using both synthetic and real-world IoT datasets which have shown that such ML models can be successfully utilized for various applications including but not limited to intrusion detection, malware classification, and anomaly detection with high accuracy rates. The obtained findings verify that and show us how to utilize the intelligence of ML to interactively protect IoT devices at the same time ensuring their productivity, security, and privacy. Machine learning plays the crucial part of the project called “Next Generation Smart Homes: Resilience and Security”.

title: Utilizing Machine Learning Techniques for Water Quality Evaluation: A Comparative Analysis of Classifiers Efficiency
authors: Arwa Saad, Abdelmoty M. Ahmed, Ahmed A. Elngar, Amer Ibrahim
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Business Analytics for Technology and Security (ICBATS)
abstract: Communities' safety and well-being greatly depend on their water supply quality. Ensuring safe and clean water is vital for public health, environmental preservation, and effective water resource management. Regular monitoring of water quality helps detect contaminants, prevent waterborne diseases, and maintain ecological balance. Artificial Intelligence (AI) presents valuable opportunities to enhance classification processes. This paper evaluates the performance of multiple machine learning classifiers for water quality. The evaluated techniques comprise Random Forest, Support Vector Machines (SVM), Gradient Boosting, and Logistic Regression. Their performance is evaluated using metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score, with confusion matrices employed to illustrate the distribution of predictions across different classes. Our results reveal that random forest achieves the highest predictive accuracy, 93%.

title: GEN AI in Identity and Access Management: Transforming Security Solutions
authors: Anant Wairagade, Raj Sonani, Vijay Govindarajan
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Business Analytics for Technology and Security (ICBATS)
abstract: The integration of Generative Artificial Intelligence (Gen AI) is revolutionizing the way access control, adaptive authentication, and anomaly detection work. GenAI leverages deep learning architecture in IAM to analyze user behavior patterns, distinguish anomalies, and implement context-aware access policies in real time. This article thoroughly analyzes GenAI-powered IAM, examining its impact on adaptive authentication, anomaly detection, user behavior analysis, and compliance automation. The article also explores applications of different GenAI models, including Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs), Variational Autoencoders (VAEs), and Large Language Models (LLMs, within IAM. The exploration of existing use cases showcases the real-life impact of these solutions in IAM. The primary object of this article is to give a thorough overview of GenAI-based IAM, showcasing their impact, the challenges they encounter, and the possible roadmap to encounter these challenges. To our knowledge, this is the first article that offers in-depth knowledge regarding GenAI-based IAM, combining technical analysis, challenges, real-world use cases, and future research areas in a single structure.

title: Consistency Model-Assisted Optimal Configuration of Integrated Energy Systems
authors: Hualong Liu, Wei Sun, Wenyuan Tang
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: Although integrated energy systems (IESs) provide an innovative energy solution for improving energy efficiency, reducing emissions, and integrating high shares of renewable energy, determining their optimal configuration under high renewable penetration remains a significant challenge due to the inherent uncertainties in renewable generation and load demand. To address this issue, this study proposes a novel consistency model-assisted approach for the optimal configuration of IESs, which comprehensively incorporates uncertainty modeling. First, a scenario generation and reduction method that uses consistency models in combination with the k-means++ clustering algorithm is developed. Second, a framework for IESs that captures the interactions among multiple energy carriers and components is constructed. Third, a two-stage stochastic programming approach for determining the optimal configuration of energy technologies and capacities in IESs is proposed. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed approach is validated through comprehensive case studies. The results demonstrate that explicitly considering uncertainties leads to increased installed capacities and more reliable system configurations, highlighting the importance of uncertainty-aware planning in IESs.

title: Using the SSEMGP – SEMI - STATE Equation Matrix Generation Program for Transfer Function Generation in Analog Circuits with Single Input – Single Output and Multiple Inputs - Multiple Outputs
authors: Mihai Iordache, Marilena Stanculescu, Lavinia Bobaru, Dragoş Niculae, Sorin Deleanu, Adrian Georgescu, Mihai Rotaru, Anton Anastasie Moscu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromechanical and Energy Systems (SIELMEN)
abstract: The main objective of symbolic analysis is to derive the symbolic expressions of circuit functions and to compute their sensitivities, thereby enabling the evaluation of circuit characteristics and their variation with respect to parameter values. This paper presents an approach for generating transfer functions in both SISO (single-input-singleoutput) and MIMO (multiple-input-multiple-output) systems. The method is based on the circuit's semi-state equations. Using this semi-state equation technique, a computational program called SSEMGP (Semi-State Equation Matrix Generation Program) was developed. This program symbolically and numerically produces the matrices associated with the semistate equations (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$W, G, B$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$L^{\boldsymbol{t}}$</tex>) and supports a complete circuit analysis. It automatically formulates symbolic equations, generates various types of circuit functions in symbolic or partially symbolic form, and produces matrix representations for systems with multiple inputs and outputs.

title: Hybrid CNN-Transformer Model for Accurate Classification of Human Attention Levels Using Workplace EEG Data
authors: Anice Jahanjoo, Yiting Wei, Mostafa Haghi, Philip Schörpf, Nima TaheriNejad
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Accurately detecting human attention levels is a key challenge in cognitive neuroscience, with broad application value in improving productivity. Although Electroencephalography (EEG) signals are often used to study cognitive states, most studies still rely on data collected in controlled laboratory environments. This paper collects EEG data from employees during their daily work using a commercial single-channel EEG headband, making attention detection closer to real-world applications and increasing its feasibility and promotion value. We propose a new classification method based on a multi-head attention transformer to identify six different attention levels. We first perform a Short-Time Fourier Transform (STFT) on the EEG signal. Subsequently, we constructed a transformer architecture to effectively model long-range dependencies and subtle pattern changes in EEG data using self-attention and stacked encoder layers. Experimental results show that our proposed model achieves 87.37% classification accuracy in the six-level attention classification task, outperforming traditional high-performance methods and demonstrating superior performance compared to existing similar approaches. This achievement not only verifies the potential of the transformer architecture in EEG attention level classification but also provides new possibilities for developing advanced tools in fields such as brain-computer interface (BCI) and cognitive monitoring.

title: Fairness-Aware Joint Optimization of Dynamic Service Caching and Base Station Clustering in User-Centric MEC Networks
authors: Chen Lin, Haifeng Sun
publish: 2025 18th International Congress on Image and Signal Processing, BioMedical Engineering and Informatics (CISP-BMEI)
abstract: With the advancement of Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS), edge caching has emerged as a pivotal technology within new computing paradigms for reducing transmission latency and optimizing network load. In traditional Mobile Edge Computing (MEC) systems, severe signal fading and intercell interference often lead to degraded throughput and even transmission failures, significantly hampering the availability of MEC services for cell-edge users. User-Centric MEC (UC-MEC) is regarded as a promising solution to this issue. However, due to the limited storage capacity of edge servers, devising dynamic service caching strategies that accommodate real-time fluctuating user demands during task offloading remains a critical challenge. It is noteworthy that existing edge caching approaches in UCMEC networks largely overlook fairness among users. This paper presents the first attempt to address the edge caching problem in UC-MEC networks while incorporating fairness in service provision. Specifically, we formulate a dynamic edge caching framework and jointly optimize base station clustering and service caching decisions to maximize user fairness while minimizing service caching costs. To handle the hybrid action space inherent in this problem, we employ the Twin Delayed Deep Deterministic (TD3) Policy Gradient algorithm. Extensive simulation results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm achieves rapid convergence and exhibits superior performance in terms of both service latency and fairness.

title:
Enhanced SpO
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    and Heart Rate Estimation from Smartphone Facial Videos with Dynamic Selection of Optimal Region of Interest
authors: Maggie Ezzat Gaber Gendy, Vishal Singh Roha, Mehmet Rasit Yuce
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Continuous monitoring of blood oxygen saturation (SpO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>) and heart rate (HR) provides critical insights into respiratory and cardiovascular health. Remote photoplethysmography (rPPG), a non-contact technology, has gained significant attention for vital signs monitoring. However, its accuracy is highly dependent on the selection of optimal regions of interest (ROIs), which remains a critical challenge. To address this, we present a new non-invasive framework for predicting SpO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> and HR from smartphone facial videos, using advanced neural models to dynamically identify and select the most suitable ROI for each participant, ensuring robust and precise measurements. Leveraging a combination of ResNet and convolutional neural networks (CNN), our proposed framework excludes obstructed facial regions, selects the optimal ROI, and extracts rPPG signals from the selected area. These signals are subsequently utilized for accurate SpO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> and HR prediction. To validate the effectiveness of our system, we constructed a comprehensive dataset comprising synchronized facial and fingertip videos, benchmarked against ground truth SpO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> and HR values measured with clinically validated commercial devices, including the Finapres NOVA and OMRON. Our experimental results demonstrate the reliability of the proposed framework, achieving a mean absolute error, root mean square error, signal quality index, standard deviation, coefficient of determination, and pearson correlation coefficient of (0.697 bpm, 1.476 bpm, 97.11%, 3.011, 0.966, 0.986) for HR and (0.73%, 1.573%, 99.74%, 1.778, 0.982, 0.998) for SpO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>. These results meet the performance standards set by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO), Food and Drug Administration (FDA), and Association for the Advancement of Medical Instrumentation (AAMI), demonstrating the potential of our system for reliable, non-invasive vital signs monitoring.

title: Improving Worker Fall Detection with Two Cameras: A Hybrid Model Integrating Pose Estimation and Fall Classification
authors: Kevin Fong-Rey Liu, Tung-Ju Wu, Yu-Cheng Chan, Ssu-Han Chen
publish: 2024 IEEE 16th International Conference on Humanoid, Nanotechnology, Information Technology, Communication and Control, Environment, and Management (HNICEM)
abstract: This study addresses safety challenges in unmanned and single-worker environments in the Industry 4.0 era, specifically focusing on issues related to fall detection. Traditional wearable devices and environmental sensors often face limitations in real-world applications due to environmental noise and high maintenance costs. To overcome these challenges, this research proposes an innovative solution that integrates computer vision and deep learning technologies to achieve realtime fall detection. Specifically, this study utilizes two cameras to monitor fall events from different angles. To accurately identify human postures, the YOLO-POSE model was applied for human skeleton pose estimation. The ST-GCN (Spatial-Temporal Graph Convolutional Network) model was then used to precisely classify fall events, effectively handling time-series data to capture the spatiotemporal characteristics of human movement. During model testing, the detection model exhibited excellent performance. The training accuracy curve achieved an accuracy rate of 0.9974, the validation accuracy curve was 0.9986, and the evaluation accuracy curve reached 0.9983. These results demonstrate the model's effectiveness, reliability, and potential for practical applications.

title: Calibration of Friction and Roughness in an Urban Water Distribution Network Using an LSTM Neural Network-Based Framework
authors: Leonardo Gómez-Coronel, Lizeth Torres, Ildeberto Santos-Ruiz, Joaquim Blesa, Roberto G. Ramírez-Chavarría
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Control and Fault-Tolerant Systems (SysTol)
abstract: This paper proposes a method to estimate both the friction factor and the roughness coefficient of the pipes in a water distribution network (WDN). Pressure head data is used for the training of a Long-Short Term Memory (LSTM) neural network to predict the pressure head at all of the other nodes in the network, as well as the flow rate through the pipes. When all the data is predicted, the estimated pressure head drops, and the flow rate for the entire water distribution network is used to compute both the friction factor and the flow rate. The proposed method is tested using the well-known Hanoi DMA (District Metered Area) as a case study. Satisfactory results are obtained when comparing the predicted friction factor and roughness coefficient against the expected values.

title: Ultra-Low Power EEG Headband Based on Gold Nanowire Foam Electrode
authors: Shilei Wang, Lim Wei Yap, Zhiya Wang, Wenlong Cheng, Wei Chen
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Wearable electroencephalogram (EEG) systems are significant for brain activity monitoring across clinical and everyday applications. In this study, we present a lightweight, low-power EEG headband based on innovative gold nanowire foam (G-foam) electrodes, designed to ensure stable scalp contact and reliable signal acquisition. The system operates at the average current draw of 2.56 mA with a 3.7 V supply, which supports use in real-world environments. Lab evaluations, including impedance measurements, Steady-State Visually Evoked Potential (SSVEP) experiments, and alpha wave detection during eyes-closed states highlight its ability to capture both task-specific and resting-state EEG signals accurately. Comparative analysis shows a high correlation (r = 0.995) between the headband and polysomnography systems, underscoring their reliability. Its low-power design further supports applications in continuous monitoring scenarios, including sleep analysis, emotion recognition, and neurofeedback. This work demonstrates a meaningful step toward practical, accessible EEG solutions for diverse real-world applications.

title: Modeling of Kilohertz Wireless Power Transfer Systems with Transmitter-Side Low-Frequency Metamaterials
authors: Kaiyuan Wang, Junxiang Yang, Zhen Sun, Ching-Ming Lai, Yun Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: Equivalent circuit modeling has proven to be more accurate than permittivity-and permeability-based approaches for describing the electrical characteristics of low-frequency metamaterials in wireless power transfer (WPT) applications. Although circuit-based models are sometimes criticized for their similarity in practical implementation to relay coils in multi-coil WPT systems, such as domino WPT systems, they are based on different theoretical interpretations and employ distinct compensation strategies. This paper aims to present a more comprehensive modeling framework for transmitter-side low-frequency metamaterials in WPT systems operating in the kilohertz frequency range. Based on this framework, the characteristics of the equivalent circuit parameters are analyzed in relation to both the number of stacked passive coil array (SPCA) units and their resonant frequencies. Furthermore, comparisons are conducted between two transmitter-side compensation schemes, namely the series and LCC configurations, focusing on maximum efficiency, output power, and harmonic distortion. Both simulation and experimental results demonstrate that implementing LCC compensation on the transmitter side significantly enhances efficiency and output power while effectively reducing harmonic distortion.

title:
In vitro rifampicin release and antimicrobial activity of biodegradable polymer coatings
                    <sup>*</sup>
authors: Justine Fraser, Sarah Eccles, Hathairat Muangsaen, Aishwarya Kadam, Michelle Maclean, Christopher McCormick
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Implanted medical device infections represent a significant clinical challenge. Infections, often caused by staphylococcal species, are extremely difficult to treat due to challenges in targeting the infection site whilst avoiding systemic toxicity. This study reports on the development of a novel implant coating to provide controlled, local drug-release, for the inhibition of infection. The release of the broad-spectrum antibiotic rifampicin from a range of biodegradable poly (lacticacid) (PLA) and poly (lactic-co-glycolic acid) (PLGA) polymer formulations was analysed. Increasing the fraction of polymer in a formulation provided control over release; e.g. increasing the PLGA:rifampicin ratio from 25:75 to 75:25 significantly (p ≤ 0.001) slowed release of rifampicin from >99%, to <2% after 7 days. The antimicrobial activity of PLGA:rifampicin based formulations (25:75, 50:50, 75:25) against Staphylococcus aureus revealed that all formulations retained antimicrobial activity over 7 days in disk diffusion tests. The 50:50 formulation produced significantly (p ≤ 0.05) larger zones of growth inhibition than the 25:75 or 75:25 formulations. This investigation confirms rifampicin can be released from biocompatible, polymer-based coatings, and reveals potential for engineering both the release rate and level of antimicrobial efficacyClinical Relevance— This research demonstrates the potential of synthetic polymer coatings for the prevention of medical implant infections.

title: Reconfigurable Heterogeneous Multi-agent Network Modeling and Resilience analysis
authors: Yuheng Dang, Zimeng Yin, Xing Pan
publish: 2024 15th International Conference on Reliability, Maintenance and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: With the advancement of computer science, information wheel and control theory, multi-agent system, as a representative complex system, plays a crucial role in analyzing cluster behavior in various fields such as biology, social science, and military. The multi-agent system possesses the capability to adapt to environmental changes and dynamically adjust its structure for reconfiguration purposes in order to reduce vulnerability and enhance resilience. However, current research is limited to proposing reconfiguration strategies that improve the adaptability and resilience of the system without providing an interpretation of the reconfiguration mechanism and capacity constraints. This paper analyzes the operational mechanism and network structure of a multi-agent system based on the concept of typical operation loop while integrating reconfigurable features to propose a model called reconfigurable heterogeneous multi-agent network (RHMN). Additionally, this study examines network capability constraints under reconfiguration factors by introducing network evaluation indices and resilience measurements based on capability-load. Finally, using missile equipment systems as a case study example, we analyze the resilience of the proposed reconfigurable heterogeneous multi-agent network model using these models and indices to verify their validity and effectiveness.

title: Detection of Bond Wire Lift-Off Using a Parallel Resonant Tank Circuit During Gate Turn-Off
authors: Keqi Song, Henry Shu-Hung Chung
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: This article presents a real-time method for detecting bond wire lift-off in SiC MOSFETs by incorporating a switched-capacitor-based level shifter and a parallel-connected resonant tank into the gate drive circuit. This approach eliminates the need for external signal injections or additional equipment while enabling negative voltage turn-off. The idea is based on monitoring the energy distribution within a specific frequency band of the resonator upon turn-off of the SiC MOSFETs and a switched-capacitor-based circuit to generate a negative gate-source voltage to counteract the impact of spurious gate-source voltage. The effectiveness of this method has been validated in a 100W, 64V/32V, 100kHz buck converter.

title: Burnout Risk Prediction through Wearable Devices: An Initial Assessment
authors: Davide Marzorati, Alvise Dei Rossi, Radoslava Švihrová, Max Grossenbacher, Francesca Dalia Faraci
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Early detection of burnout is of utmost importance to avoid severe health consequences. Burnout is typically assessed through standardized questionnaires with self-reported information, a technique that could potentially delay its diagnosis. Wearable devices continuously and unobtrusively collect health-related data, making them valuable tools for the early detection of several mental health issues, including burnout syndrome. In this paper we report initial insights on the machine learning prediction of baseline burnout risk across cognitive, emotional, and physical dimensions. Our data consists of the first 30 days of a 9-months longitudinal study with 239 participants, including monthly burnout assessments and health data from smartwatches. Aggregated mean and standard deviation of physiological features over time windows of varying duration were employed as predictors of baseline burnout risk. Models employing sleep, cardiac, and stress features achieved a balanced accuracy of 0.66 and 0.68 in the detection of cognitive weariness and physical fatigue risk, respectively. The prediction of emotional exhaustion risk reached lower performance with a balanced accuracy of 0.55, suggesting the need of integrating additional data sources to reach better-than-chance performance. We expect to improve burnout risk prediction by crafting additional features and exploiting the collected data over their full longitudinal scale.

title: Quasi-Halbach Array Axial Flux Rotor for High Torque Applications
authors: Benjamin McIntosh, David Klink, Kelvin Wong, Dean Patterson, Greg Heins, Behrooz Bahrani
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: Surface-mounted permanent-magnet axial flux topologies are known to have comparatively high specific torque and power. Although surface permanent magnet (SPM) rotors are typical, Halbach arrays offer higher specific torque at the cost of manufacturing complexity. This work proposes a quasi-Halbach (QHB) solution which achieves comparable air gap flux density with a feasible mechanical construction and reduced magnet content. 2D finite-element-analaysis (FEA) design of experiments investigations compare the properties and relative performance of SPM, QHB array and full-pitch Halbach array rotor topologies for a fixed stator configuration. This application is demonstrated to achieve up to 11.2% higher specific torque with a Halbach array rotor than an SPM rotor under a high electrical loading, with the new solution achieving a 9.5% gain over SPM. Additionally, this was achieved with 18% less magnet material than HBA. Experimental tests benchmark a quasi-Halbach design against an existing SPM rotor to verify flux linkage and field shaping behaviours, demonstrating a 27.1% increase in back-EMF with only 2.7% greater magnetic material mass.

title: ZVS Region Expansion for Three-Phase Dual Active Bridge Based on Design of Wye-Asymmetric Extended Delta Transformer
authors: Mohamed Mansour, Joseph Olorunfemo Ojo
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: The three-phase dual active bridge (3p-DAB) converter is a key player in high-power applications thanks to its high-power density over single-phase designs. However, its efficiency can drop at light loads due to loss of soft switching. This paper uses a generalized model for the three-limb transformer and explores how unevenly splitting the secondary windings affects the phase shift angle. By adjusting the winding distribution, the soft- switching region of the 3p-DAB can be expanded. Using a complex variable stationary reference frame, the model captures winding currents precisely, offering deeper insight into system behavior. The study also focuses on how this partitioning improves soft switching, especially in extended delta transformer setups. Finally, a study of controllability is employed in order to design a voltage controller. The findings aim to support engineers and researchers in boosting the performance and efficiency of 3p-DAB converters.

title: TRAI: An AI-Driven Mobile Application to Reduce the Gap Between Triage and Care
authors: Ruturaj Ghatage, Joseph C. Ahn, Hayden Pour, Aaron Boussina, Vishal Nagarajan, Raghav Kachroo, Alexander H. Yang, Mattheus Ramsis, Rohit Loomba, Shamim Nemati
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: The integration of artificial intelligence (AI) into healthcare workflows offers transformative potential to streamline processes and enhance patient experience and outcomes. This paper presents a novel AI-powered chatbot that leverages a large language model (LLM) to conduct context-aware and adaptive conversations for patient triage and information gathering. The system integrates physician-guided prompts, triage notes, and patient history, including electronic health record (EHR) data, to dynamically refine clinical insights through iterative questioning. The chatbot ensures compliance with healthcare data standards while generating structured clinical summaries for physicians. Evaluations across ten gastroenterology/hepatology scenarios, reviewed by independent hepatologists, demonstrated high performance (scores 4.0–5.0/5.0) in documentation quality, assessment accuracy, patient education, and management planning. User ratings closely aligned with physician assessments, underscoring clinical relevance and user satisfaction. Through patient-facing Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources (FHIR) integration with EHR data, the system reduces redundant history-taking and bridges critical gaps between triage and care. Such systems can streamline previsit workflows, enhance patient-provider communication, and improve clinical efficiency. This work highlights the viability of LLM-driven patient-facing chatbots to improve clinic efficiency, patient engagement, and diagnostic accuracy in healthcare workflows.

title: A Single-Channel EEG Approach for Sleep Stage-Independent Automatic Detection of REM Sleep Behavior Disorder
authors: Gabriele Salvatore Giarrusso, Irene Rechichi, Alessandro Cicolin, Gabriella Olmo
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Rapid Eye Movement (REM) Sleep Behavior Disorder (RBD) is a parasomnia characterized by the loss of physiological muscle atonia during REM sleep, often manifesting through dream-enacting behavior. Idiopathic RBD is largely considered a prodromal stage of neurodegenerative diseases, with a conversion rate to overt α-synucleinopathies of up to 96% after 14 years. Currently, the diagnostic procedure relies on time-consuming and labor-intensive inspection of polysomnography (PSG). This study proposes a Machine Learning (ML), stage-agnostic framework for the automatic detection of RBD subjects through unstaged, single-channel EEG sleep data from 58 subjects (32 RBD). The best model achieved 86.21% accuracy, 90.6% sensitivity, and 87.9% F-1 score, demonstrating strong predictive power. This study is the first to explore whole-night EEG data for RBD detection, paving the way for scalable, lightweight clinical decision support systems for early neurodegenerative screening and risk assessment.Clinical relevance— This study presents a lightweight, clinical decision support tool to enhance RBD detection and support early interventions in neurodegenerative diseases.

title: Design and Implementation of a KNX Energy Management System for Optimizing Self-Consumption in Off-Grid Photovoltaic Systems
authors: Petru Valentin Roşu, Chirilă Constantin Alexandru, Sebastian Hudişteanu, Cristian Cherecheş, Emilian Turcanu, Radu Olaru
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromechanical and Energy Systems (SIELMEN)
abstract: This paper presents a novel solution for integrating off-grid photovoltaic inverters, which lack standard communication interfaces, into an advanced energy management system (BMS) based on the KNX standard. The innovative architecture, centred on a Wiser for KNX controller, overcomes the fundamental problem of the lack of communication with three single-phase Growatt inverters. This is achieved by collecting critical data through a network of external Modbus RS-485 sensors. The main contribution of this research is the development and validation of a dual-condition control logic, which intelligently manages high-power loads by simultaneously monitoring the generated photovoltaic power and the battery voltage. This strategy not only maximizes self-consumption by aligning the consumption curve with the production curve but also protects the storage system, preventing premature wear. The results, validated by the data recorded by the system, demonstrate the functionality and efficiency of the solution, achieving the objective of utilizing 100% of the produced solar energy.

authors: Rongrong Zhang, Shuai Ding, Hui Zhao, Shuo Wang, Teng Long, Chaoqiang Jiang, Jian Qiu, Kefu Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: Nanocrystalline materials are known for their high magnetic permeability and saturation magnetization, making them highly desirable for magnetic components. However, their low first resonant frequency (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$f_{R}$</tex>), typically below 1 MHz, limits their use in high-frequency applications. This paper proposes a novel structure combining stacked infinite split magnetic cores, and sub-micrometer coating to enhance the resonant frequency without compromising magnetic performance. By reducing parasitic capacitance and improving the distribution of electric and magnetic fields, the proposed design significantly boosts the high-frequency impedance of nanocrystalline inductors.

title: Using Reinforcement Learning to Investigate Neural Dynamics During Motor Learning
authors: Derek Xiao, Ken-Fu Liang, Keyu Ji, Jonathan C. Kao
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Recent work characterized shifts in preparatory activity of the motor cortex during motor learning. The specific shift geometry during learning, washout, and relearning blocks was hypothesized to implement the acquisition, retention, and retrieval of motor memories. We sought to train recurrent neural network (RNN) models that could be used to study these motor learning phenomena. We built an environment for a curl field (CF) motor learning task and trained RNNs with reinforcement learning (RL) with novel regularization terms to perform behaviorally realistic reaching trajectories over the course of learning. Our choice of RL over supervised learning was motivated by the idea that motor adaptation, in the absence of demonstrations, is a process of reoptimization. We find these models, despite lack of supervision, reproduce many behavioral findings from monkey CF adaptation experiments. These models also captured key neurophysiological findings. We found that the model’s preparatory activity existed in a force-predictive subspace that remained stable across learning, washout, and relearning. Additionally, preparatory activity shifted uniformly, independently of the distance to the CF trained target. Finally, we found that the washout shift became more orthogonal to the learning shift, and hence more brain-like, when the RNNs were pretrained to have prior experience with CF dynamics. We argue the increased fit to neurophysiological recordings is driven by more generalizable and structured dynamical motifs in the model with more prior experience. This suggests that prior experience could organize preparatory neural activity underlying motor memory to have more orthogonal characteristics, by forming structured dynamical motifs in the motor cortex circuitry.

title: eVTOL Propulsion Comparison Between Axial Flux and Radial Flux Motors
authors: Francesco Tripaldi, Daniele De Gregorio, Nicola Bianchi
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: This paper deals with the electromagnetic comparison between a Radial Flux and an Axial Flux Motor that are designed to drive the propeller of an electric Vertical Take-Off and Landing aircraft. The analysis highlights the main constraints imposed by the aircraft structure and compares the performance of the two proposed motors carrying out two different analysis: the first is done imposing the permanent magnet mass, the latter imposes the maximum available volume. The eletromagnetic performance are evaluated through 2D simulations. For the Axial Flux Motor the analysis is validated through 3D simulations, ensuring the accuracy of the proposed model. Once the performance are evaluated, several considerations are given on the appropriate cooling system for each motor.

title: Unsupervised Online Detection of Pipe Blockages and Leakages in Water Distribution Networks
authors: Jin Li, Kleanthis Malialis, Stelios G. Vrachimis, Marios M. Polycarpou
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Control and Fault-Tolerant Systems (SysTol)
abstract: Water Distribution Networks (WDNs), critical to public well-being and economic stability, face challenges such as pipe blockages and background leakages, exacerbated by operational constraints such as data non-stationarity and limited labeled data. This paper proposes an unsupervised, online learning framework that aims to detect two types of faults in WDNs: pipe blockages, modeled as collective anomalies, and background leakages, modeled as concept drift. Our approach combines a Long Short-Term Memory Variational Autoencoder (LSTM-VAE) with a dual drift detection mechanism, enabling robust detection and adaptation under non-stationary conditions. Its lightweight, memory-efficient design enables real-time, edge-level monitoring. Experiments on two realistic WDNs show that the proposed approach consistently outperforms strong baselines in detecting anomalies and adapting to recurrent drift, demonstrating its effectiveness in unsupervised event detection for dynamic WDN environments.

title: DCA-Former: Dual Channel Attention-Driven Multiscale Convolutional Transformer for P300 Speller
authors: Binghao Shi, Mengxue Liu, Rui Ma, Zhi Wang, Yanjiang Wang
publish: 2025 18th International Congress on Image and Signal Processing, BioMedical Engineering and Informatics (CISP-BMEI)
abstract: The P300 Speller is a brain-computer interface system that employs electroencephalography(EEG) signals for character input, which may offer a novel avenue for individuals with disabilities to communicate with the external world. However, the redundancy ofchannel information and the complexity of spatiotemporal features within EEG data present significant challenges to the spelling task. Moreover, the prevalent convolutional neural networks are only capable of extracting local temporal features, which limits their ability to capture longterm dependencies for EEG decoding. In response to these challenges, this paper attempts to apply Transformer to P300 speller and proposes a multiscale convolutional Transformer network incorporating the dual channel attention, named DCAFormer. DCA-Former combines the advantages of CNN for local feature extraction and Transformer for global dependency learning, while incorporating EEG channel attention and efficient channel attention mechanisms to address channel redundancy and enhance feature extraction. Extensive experiments conducted on two public datasets demonstrate that the DCA-Former effectively harnesses information accumulated from repetitive stimuli, significantly improving spelling accuracy. This research result provides innovative ideas and methods to enhance the performance of the P300 speller, thereby facilitating more efficient communication for individuals with disabilities.

title: Optimizing Machine Learning Performance with Word Frequency-Based Document Representation: A Comparative Analysis of Clustering Algorithms
authors: Boumedyen Shannaq, Oualid Ali
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Business Analytics for Technology and Security (ICBATS)
abstract: The proposed research examines how top frequent words serve as document representations in place of the complete text content for clustering textual documents. The data collection from Kaggle includes 4450 English text documents, which belong to nine separate categories: Technology (802) and Sport (1,022) and Business (1,020) with Politics (834) and Entertainment (772). We tested four standard clustering algorithms including K-Means and Agglomerative Clustering and DBSCAN and Gaussian Mixture Model through analysis of the initial dataset together with ten additional datasets built utilizing document representation using the first ten to the first one most frequent words. The use of K-Means clustering achieves maximum efficiency when documents are displayed through their top 10 frequent words thus leading to improved accuracy in document classification. The main goal was to prove the feasibility of the methodology rather than reaching maximum clustering accuracy yet our analysis proves that document complexity reduction boosts cluster quality especially when processing large-scale data. The research presents new clustering strategies for big data settings, which answer a substantial gap in text clustering efficiency research.

title: A Unified Approach to Dual-Mode Synchronous Overmodulation Regulation of PWM Inverters with Constant and Variable Fundamental Frequencies
authors: Valentin Oleschuk, Irina Vasiliev
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromechanical and Energy Systems (SIELMEN)
abstract: This paper presents a brief overview of methods and algorithms for synchronous overmodulation regulation of power electronic systems (variable-speed electric drives and photovoltaic (PV) installations) based on modulated voltage source inverters (VSINs). These inverters are controlled using synchronous space-vector pulse-width modulation (SSV PWM), which ensures synchronization and symmetry of the output voltage of power electronic systems with both constant (PV stations) and variable (AC electric drives) fundamental frequencies. In this case, dual-mode overmodulation control of PWM inverters is based on modified control correlations. Specifically, these correlations include two special overmodulation coefficients, defined as functions of two modulation threshold indices for PV inverters and two threshold frequencies for drive inverters. Simulations demonstrate the behavior of these inverter-based power conversion systems operating at increased modulation indices of PWM inverters.

title: Evaluation of gait training based on the combination of TWIN exoskeleton and Functional Electrical Stimulation of tibialis anterior
authors: Viola Camerini, Indya Ceroni, Pietro Di Bello, Stefano Maludrottu, Matteo Laffranchi, Marianna Semprini
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Lower limb exoskeletons are increasingly used in neurorehabilitation to assist walking in individuals with neurological impairments. The TWIN lower limb exoskeleton developed at the Rehab Technologies Lab of Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia (IIT) is an innovative prototype that has been previously tested on people with spinal cord injury (SCI) and post-stroke conditions. However, the absence of active ankle control limits its effectiveness, especially in addressing foot drop and foot slap. Functional electrical stimulation (FES) of the tibialis anterior (TA) has been shown to mitigate these deficits by promoting dorsiflexion during gait. This study evaluates the integration of TWIN with a FES system to improve ankle mobility. Ten healthy subjects walked on a treadmill with the TWIN+FES system for 30 minutes. Kinematic data showed that FES improved dorsiflexion during the swing phase, leading to more physiological ankle trajectories. Although some subjects exhibited signs of muscle fatigue, there were no significant changes in ankle performance over time. These findings support the feasibility of integrating FES with TWIN and lay the groundwork for future investigations into its impact on gait patterns and potential rehabilitation benefits. Future studies should investigate the effects of this approach in individuals with neurological impairments, and assess its impact on reducing exoskeleton motor demands.Clinical relevance—The combination of lower limb exoskeletons with functional electrical stimulation has the potential to enhance gait rehabilitation in individuals with SCI or post-stroke conditions. By improving ankle dorsiflexion in healthy subjects, this approach shows promise for reducing foot drop and foot slap in future clinical applications; further studies are needed to evaluate its actual effectiveness in individuals with neurological impairments.

title: Training-Free Optical Identifier Recognition for Injection-Molded Components
authors: Juan Cervera, Dimitrios Arapis, Lazaros Nalpantidis
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Imaging Systems and Techniques (IST)
abstract: Automating component identification and sorting using injection-molded component identifiers poses a significant challenge in quality control and inspection processes, particularly within precision industries like pharmaceutical manufacturing. Standard optical character recognition (OCR) tools fail to accurately interpret these molded component identifiers, due to the low visibility, molding-induced artifacts, and minimal contrast between the component’s text and its surfaces, limiting the automation potential and sustaining dependency on labor-intensive and error-prone manual processes. This paper introduces an innovative, zero-shot solution, SMaRT-STR, ensembling state-of-the-art scene text recognition (STR) and lexicon-based sequence matching techniques to overcome the challenging visual conditions. Scene text recognition models, originally developed for interpreting complex environmental text for autonomous vehicles, are uniquely suited for accurately deciphering non-uniform, low-contrast, and distorted text. An additional prediction refinement layer is integrated, implementing algorithms traditionally utilized in bioinformatics for DNA sequence alignment. This leverages the known sample batch information and uses it to reframe the recognition task to a classification problem. Experimental evaluation demonstrates the efficacy of this hybrid approach, achieving above 99% decoding accuracy across diverse imaging conditions, including scenarios hardly distinguishable by human operators. These results highlight the capability of cross-domain methodology fusion, showcasing substantial potential to streamline quality control processes, significantly reduce manual effort, and increase operational reliability in manufacturing environments. Our source code is publicly available at https: //github.com/jcer10/SMaRT-STR.

title: In silico Deployment Modeling of an Everolimus Coated Balloon
authors: Grigorios G. Kotoulas, Vasileios S. Loukas, Antonis I. Sakellarios, Georgia Karanasiou, Sotirios Nikopoulos, Christos C. Katsouras, Lambros K. Michalis, Arsen Semertzioglou, Anargyros Moulas, Dimitrios I. Fotiadis
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Atherosclerosis, a chronic inflammatory condition, is linked to heart attacks and strokes. It leads to the formation of atherosclerotic plaques within arterial vessels, consequently diminishing blood flow to various organs. Drug-Eluting Balloons represent a non-stent approach, facilitating the uniform and regulated release of anti-proliferative drugs into the vessel wall via an inflated balloon. In silico modeling serves as an effective approach to precisely predict and evaluate the efficacy of the balloon deployment process. Our in silico study investigates the performance of a novel Everolimus Eluting Balloon in patient-specific swine coronary artery models and assesses the performance of the balloon at the Angioplasty procedure, considering that the same procedural approach is followed by the interventional cardiologist. The results studied refer to overall exhibited stresses and strains in the balloon and the arterial tissue and demonstrate that the balloon closely follows the compliance charts of the producer with respect to overinflation, while effectively tackling stenosis without inducing critical amounts of stresses and strains on the arterial wall. The approach described in this article is a step farther toward precision investigation of Drug Coated Balloon (DCB) mechanical performance. Validating and correlating our study’s outcomes with patient specific case studies can contribute to inform the Percutaneous Transluminal Coronary Angioplasty (PTCA) procedure from the clinical perspective.Clinical Relevance - The approach described in this article contributes towards precision investigation of DCB mechanical performance and respective arterial response. Validating the results of our study with patient-specific case studies will eventually lead to a digital twin of the balloon angioplasty medical device, informing the clinicians to optimal pre-operative planning regarding the PTCA procedure.

title: A Deep Learning approach for Depressive Symptoms assessment in Parkinson’s disease patients using facial videos
authors: Ioannis Kyprakis, Vasileios Skaramagkas, Iro Boura, Georgios Karamanis, Dimitrios I. Fotiadis, Zinovia Kefalopoulou, Cleanthe Spanaki, Manolis Tsiknakis
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Parkinson’s disease (PD) is a neurodegenerative disorder, manifesting with motor and non-motor symptoms. Depressive symptoms are prevalent in PD, affecting up to 45% of patients. They are often underdiagnosed due to overlapping motor features, such as hypomimia. This study explores deep learning (DL) models—ViViT, Video Swin Tiny, and 3D CNN-LSTM with attention layers—to assess the presence and severity of depressive symptoms, as measured by the Geriatric Depression Scale (GDS), in PD patients through facial video analysis. A secondary analysis was conducted to evaluate the same parameters considering patients’ medication states: one hour after dopaminergic medication intake (ON-medication) and 12 hours without medication (OFF-medication). Using a dataset of 1,875 videos from 178 patients, the Video Swin Tiny model achieved the highest performance, with up to 94% accuracy and 93.7% F1-score in binary classification (presence or absence of depressive symptoms) and 87.1% accuracy with an 85.4% F1-score in multiclass tasks (absence, mild, or severe depressive symptoms).Clinical relevance— This study underscores the potential of DL-based spatiotemporal analysis for scalable, noninvasive diagnosis and monitoring of depressive symptoms in PD patients. These findings highlight the potential of AI-driven facial analysis as a screening tool or a supplementary aid in depressive symptom assessment, supporting clinical diagnosis and treatment decisions. Integrating such methods into routine clinical practice could improve early detection and personalized treatment strategies, ultimately enhancing patients’ care and quality of life.

title: FairCauseSyn: Towards Causally Fair LLM-augmented Synthetic Data Generation
authors: Nitish Nagesh, Ziyu Wang, Amir M. Rahmani
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Synthetic data generation creates data based on real-world data using generative models. In health applications, generating high-quality data while maintaining fairness for sensitive attributes is essential for equitable outcomes. Existing GAN-based and LLM-based methods focus on counterfactual fairness and are primarily applied in finance and legal domains. Causal fairness provides a more comprehensive evaluation framework by preserving causal structure, but current synthetic data generation methods do not address it in health settings. To fill this gap, we develop the first LLM-augmented synthetic data generation method to enhance causal fairness using real-world tabular health data. Our generated data deviates by less than 10% from real data on causal fairness metrics. When trained on causally fair predictors, synthetic data reduces bias on the sensitive attribute by 70% compared to real data. This work improves access to fair synthetic data, supporting equitable health research and healthcare delivery.

title: Thermal Aware Design Methodologies for System On Chip Application Processor
authors: Youngsang Cho, Jun So Pak, Seungwook Yoon, Ilryong Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACM International Symposium on Low Power Electronics and Design (ISLPED)
abstract: In the semiconductor industry, there has been a continuous process technology scaling. This enables more logic into the limited space and more chips from a same sized wafer. All electrical power consumed by the chip is converted into heat, and the on-chip temperature depends on the thermal design of the chip itself. Heat causes more leakage currents inside the components of semiconductors. Although the required operational power remains constant, the resulting heat leads to additional consumption of temperature-dependent leakage power. An increase in leakage power generates further heat, leading to negative feedback whereby increased temperatures cause additional leakage power, potentially causing runaway heating without proper thermal control. Therefore, managing temperature is critical in semiconductor chips, especially in mobile semiconductors which have restricted cooling environments. While package structures aim to remove internal hot spots within the chip, optimal design optimization concerning thermal coupling-induced hotspots is essential from the chip-design perspective. This paper discusses studies conducted from a thermal engineering standpoint aimed at achieving optimized cooling designs for environments containing multiple functional blocks integrated onto one chip, similar to mobile System-On-Chip Application Processors (SOC AP).

title: Herbal Finder: A Deep Learning-Based Mobile Application for Providing Identification and Usage of Herbal Leaves
authors: John Paul T. Cruz, Dionis A. Padilla, Alaric S. Espiña, Khyle Matthew P. Gopole, Roger Angelo D. Salinas
publish: 2024 IEEE 16th International Conference on Humanoid, Nanotechnology, Information Technology, Communication and Control, Environment, and Management (HNICEM)
abstract: Using plants in traditional medicine has been a practice for centuries and has contributed significantly to human well-being. Despite modern medicine's advancements, herbal medicine still holds promise and relevance. This study introduces an innovative mobile application called Herbal Finder, powered by Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools, leveraging technology accessibility. The application uses deep learning-based models to classify herbal plants, providing users with essential information on their benefits and usage. Additionally, it integrates Natural Language Processing (NLP) for symptom-based search queries and incorporates a speech-to-text search option using the Whisper Model API by OpenAI. Previous studies have explored various algorithms for herbal plant recognition, suggesting that such systems should be implemented on smartphones for public access. This study proposes an ensemble model of Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) classifiers to enhance the accuracy and reliability of herbal plant classification. The most effective CNN classifiers were identified and integrated into the application through diligent testing. The results of the study showed that after testing seven different models; VGG, ResNet, SqueezeNet, and Inception models were used in the ensemble model with the highest accuracy being 99.99% and the fine-tuned ClinicalBERT model obtained an accuracy 98.53%. The Herbal Finder mobile application was able to provide the users with the necessary information for their query, either through means of Images, Voice or Text.

title: Enhancing Cryptocurrency Market Forecasting Through Advanced AI-Driven Predictive Analytics
authors: Mohammed Kadhim Rahma, Majid M. Manhosh, Yasameen AL-Quraishi, Muhannad Khalifa Obed, Muhannad Khamis Abed, Ahmed Nawar Naseef, Mashael Taha Hamad, Ali J. Al-Shimary, Sameer Algburi
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Business Analytics for Technology and Security (ICBATS)
abstract: Cryptocurrency market forecasting remains a challenging task due to high volatility (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3-7 \%$</tex> daily price fluctuations), sentiment-driven market behavior, and decentralized trading environments. This research presents an AI-driven predictive analytics framework utilizing Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks, sentiment analysis (BERTbased classifiers), and blockchain analytics to improve forecasting accuracy. The proposed LSTM model achieves a precision of 0.96, recall of 0.97, and F1-score of 0.96, significantly outperforming conventional models such as CNN (F1-score: 0.82), ARIMA (F1-score: 0.79), and Transformerbased models (F1-score: 0.90). The Mean Squared Error (MSE 0.001), Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE0.03), and Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE 2%) validate the model's superior predictive capabilities. The Sharpe Ratio (1.5) further confirms its effectiveness in risk-adjusted market forecasting. A wide dataset of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$500,000+$</tex> daily tweets related to cryptocurrency, Binance historical price, and on-chain transaction data were used to optimize model performance. The findings reveal that short-term (24 -hour) forecasting leads AI-based cryptocurrency predictions (68.6 %), whereas longterm forecasting (120 -day) is underutilized (1.4 %). The hybrid AI architecture combines deep learning, financial sentiment analysis, and blockchain analytics and results in 18 % increased forecasting accuracy compared to current methodologies. This research sets the stage for LSTM-based neural networks as a more effective forecasting instrument, opening doors to future development in real-time AI-based financial prediction.

title: Towards Optimal Oyster Mushroom Growth under Multiparametric Internet-of-Things Automation
authors: Marvin A. Radaza, Xavier Julian P. Fernandez, Jojemar Eserell M. Bacalan, Yves Vhenston T. Formentera, Raymund Jan S. Relatorres, Wilen Melsedec O. Narvios, Ferdinand F. Batayola, Joecyn N. Archival, Jayson C. Jueco
publish: 2024 IEEE 16th International Conference on Humanoid, Nanotechnology, Information Technology, Communication and Control, Environment, and Management (HNICEM)
abstract: One of the problems mushroom cultivators face is maintaining the optimal environment for oyster mushrooms due to the country's harsh climate. This study aims to develop an IoT-based system to control temperature, humidity, CO2 levels, and light intensity, monitored remotely via ThingSpeak. It compares the growth of oyster mushrooms (Pleurotus ostreatus) in controlled and traditional environments to assess their impact on radial size and growth rates. In controlled environments, mushrooms reached an average radial size of 6.66 cm with a growth rate of 0.0307 cm/day, while those in traditional settings averaged 3.83 cm and 0.0228 cm/day. Statistical analysis, including hypothesis testing and T-tests, obtained a p-value of 0.04527, indicating significant differences with controlled environments producing more giant and faster-growing mushrooms. These findings highlight the benefits of controlled environments in promoting optimal mushroom growth.

title: Analyzing Trends in Civil Rights Cases Using NLP Techniques
authors: Ali Mahmoud Masadeh, Amjad Ali Mohammad Alnagrash, Husein Bani Issa
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Business Analytics for Technology and Security (ICBATS)
abstract: Civil rights cases are essential in making laws and society more equal, thereby reflecting the new challenges of equality and justice. The study examines the possible use of Natural Language Processing (NLP) for the analysis of civil rights litigation trends. Moreover, by taking advantage of a comprehensive dataset of legal documents such as case summaries, verdicts, and judicial opinions, this topic modeling, sentiment analysis, and named entity recognition (NER), applied in the study, with a very fresh process, would enable the detection of patterns and insights that can be obtained. The results give a more profound understanding of the different legal themes, geographical distributions, and the time periods in which civil rights cases take place. What is more, the study provides the identification of significant factors that affect the outcomes of the cases, such as the legal precedents and the demographics of the people. The results illustrate how NLP can be effectively harnessed to speed up legal research and help policymakers to correct systematic inequalities in society. This paper is an important contribution to the new and increasingly important combining of artificial intelligence and legal studies, and it also aimed at receiving feedback on such frameworks for further research in automated legal analysis.

title: Functional and Structural Neural Plasticity Following sEMG Control of a Virtual Prosthetic Hand in an Individual with Bilateral Upper-Limb Congenital Amputation
authors: Daniel A. Feldman, Davi F. Cavinatto, Connor D. Olsen, W. Caden Hamrick, Michael D. Paskett, Tyler S. Davis, Chris Baschuk, Chris C. Duncan, Jace B. King, Gregory A. Clark, Jacob A. George, Mark R. Brinton
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Here we document cortical neural connectivity changes associated with several weeks of prosthetic use in an individual with bilateral upper-limb congenital amputation. Secondly, we explore how those changes relate to prosthetic performance over time. Previous research in unilateral aplasia has shown that functional brain connectivity and activations can be disrupted in the missing hand area, and that prosthetic use can normalize those abnormalities. Functional connectivity and prosthetic use related brain changes in individuals with bilateral congenital upper limb amputations have not been defined. Here, we describe functional and structural connectivity changes measured with MRI after 10-weeks’ unilateral use of an sEMG-controlled virtual prosthetic in an individual with aplasia born without either arm. We find that both functional connectivity and structural connectivity change with sEMG prosthetic use. Specifically, functional connectivity of motor regions tends to lateralize and become more hemisphere specific. Additionally, structural connectivity of motor cortico-spinal white matter projections and interhemispheric commissural projections increase after sEMG prosthetic use. These functional connectivity changes are different from those previously reported for one-handed congenital amputees, where prosthetic use normalized, not lateralized, imbalanced interhemispheric motor connectivity. Alongside these neural changes, sEMG virtual prosthetic performance both increased and decreased over time, depending on the action performed. Our results suggest that neural representations of bilateral congenital amputation and subsequent neural adaptions with unilateral prosthetic use may be distinct from those of unilateral congenital and traumatic upper-limb amputees. Consideration of condition-specific neurobiology may be critical in developing effective neuro-prostheses.Clinical Relevance— This describes the neural changes induced by sEMG prosthetic control in a congenital bilateral amputee.

title: Battery-Friendly Model Predictive Control for Direct-Drive Wave Energy Converters with Hybrid Energy Storage System
authors: Xuanyi Zhu, Zechuan Lin, Xuanrui Huang, Xi Xiao
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: Utilizing battery-supercapacitor hybrid energy storage systems (HESSs) to smooth the fluctuating power from direct-drive wave energy converters (DDWECs) is a common practice in the DDWEC community. However, existing model predictive control (MPC)-based energy-capture-optimizing strategies for DDWECs are ineffective at accounting for the degradation of HESS, primarily the battery. To address this limitation, this article proposes a battery-friendly MPC strategy. Specifically, the battery ampere-hour (Ah) throughput, obtained using a low-pass filtering rule, is incorporated into the MPC objective function to enable awareness of battery degradation. The MPC simultaneously pursues two control objectives: increasing net electricity generation and reducing battery Ah throughput. The priorities of these two objectives are dynamically adjusted according to the grid-connected power demand. Finally, simulations and experiments conducted under various operating conditions verify the proposed strategy's ability to enhance net electricity generation and extend battery lifespan.

title: Comparison of Optimal Control Mitigation Techniques for $E_{3}$ HEMP Insults Utilizing the Transformer Neutral Path
authors: Connor A. Lehman, Rush D. Robinett, David G. Wilson, Wayne W. Weaver
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: The purpose of this paper is to investigate high-altitude electromagnetic pulse (HEMP) insult mitigation strategies. State-of-the-art solutions currently endorse capacitor blocks on the neutral path. These devices cause system ringing which introduces unnecessary stress on the electrical grid and adjacent components. The scope of this paper is to explore and contrast five different control laws. Performance metrics for this trade study of control laws look at minimizing: i) magnetic core flux saturation, ii) voltage and control effort ringing/oscillations, iii) required energy storage, and iv) transient decay. Additionally, minimizing control effort does not necessarily imply minimized energy storage. Highlights for the results of two of the potential control designs contrast a modern linear quadratic regulator (LQR) feedback controller with a novel Hamiltonian feedback control. The novel controller produced minimal amount of energy storage required to mitigate the HEMP insult.

title: Designing a Self-Powered Hydrogel-Based Wearable EMG Device
authors: Nazmi Alsaafeen, Adil Rehman, Mohammed Alzaabi, Ahsan Khandoker, Kinda Khalaf, Hani Saleh, Mahmoud Al-Qutayri, Charalampos Pitsalidis, Anna Maria Pappa
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Neuromuscular conditions arising from accidents, injuries, or genetic neurodegenerative conditions can significantly affect the patient’s physical and mental well-being, and tracking their progression and treatment often requires continuous monitoring. Herein, we propose a self-powered IoT-enabled wearable electromyography (EMG) solution that integrates flexible solar panels embedded in everyday clothes. This study presents a self-powered wearable EMG system that integrates flexible solar cells, hydrogel-based electrodes, and a microcontroller-driven circuit. The solar cells deliver 1.763 W, 1.7 W, and 0.95 W in cloudy, sunny, and indoor conditions, respectively, ensuring sufficient power for charging a rechargeable battery and supporting extended operation. The innovative hydrogel-based electrodes outperform traditional silver-silver chloride (Ag/AgCl) electrodes, offering enhanced signal quality, skin-friendliness, sustainability, and conformability for comfortable long-term use. The system employs a multitasking algorithm to process muscle activity in real-time and uses WiFi to transmit the data to the Arduino cloud for remote monitoring. This user-friendly, sustainable solution overcomes the limitations of conventional EMG systems by enabling uninterrupted monitoring in remote areas and diverse environments. Its versatile design benefits healthcare, rehabilitation, and sports applications.Clinical relevance-The extracted EMG feature profile and pattern enable a deeper quantitative assessment of the overall muscle state. For instance, each parameter could be used to track an aspect of the muscle activity. Healthcare providers are empowered to diagnose diseases more accurately by matching each disorder with a certain profile, monitor rehabilitation progress by observing changing trends in a certain parameter, or, similarly, assess sports performance.

title: Identification of Spatio-Temporal Features in Volumetric Task-Based fMRI Data Using 3D Variational Autoencoder
authors: Kexin Wang, Zhengyang Liu, Song Yin, Qixin Liu, Xiaowei He, Yudan Ren
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Characterizing functional brain networks (FBNs) has always been an important issue in the field of neuroimaging and brain mapping. Traditional methods often suffer from limitations such as low signal-to-noise ratio and restricted spatial resolution when processing fMRI data. In contrast, deep learning has been demonstrated to exhibit superior performance over traditional methods and can be effectively applied to fMRI data. However, due to the high dimensionality of fMRI volumetric data and the lack of labeled data, deep learning is prone to overfitting in supervised training processes. Most deep learning-based models for functional brain networks identification neglect the critical spatial information of fMRI volumes. In order to tackle these problems, our study proposed and utilized a 3D variational autoencoder (3DVAE) to identify the spatio-temporal features from task-based fMRI (tfMRI) data. As a generative model, 3DVAE can learn fMRI volumetric data in an unsupervised manner without the requirement of any labels, hence resolving the issue of data scarcity. Using the Human Connectome Project (HCP) Q1 data as test-bed, 3DVAE can effectively learn more meaningful and interpretable FBNs than state-of-art method. Furthermore, as a complete data-driven model, 3DVAE can capture meaningful temporal features embedded in tfMRI signals at both subject-level and group-level. We also evaluated the performance of 3DVAE on small datasets and found that it can still derive meaningful spatio-temporal features of tfMRI data even with limited samples.

title: FLASH-D: FlashAttention with Hidden Softmax Division
authors: Kosmas Alexandridis, Vasileios Titopoulos, Giorgos Dimitrakopoulos
publish: 2025 IEEE/ACM International Symposium on Low Power Electronics and Design (ISLPED)
abstract: The transformer’s attention mechanism has revolutionized AI and machine learning, with its efficient computation being crucial to its performance. However, calculating attention involves matrix operations interspersed with softmax rescaling, which inherently slows down computation and requires processing the entire input sequence. Building on online softmax computation, FlashAttention integrates softmax calculation with matrix arithmetic, enabling tiled computation independent of sequence length. While optimized for GPUs, FlashAttention’s simplicity makes it amenable to direct hardware acceleration. This work re-evaluates the core FlashAttention kernel, presenting FLASH-D a mathematically equivalent, yet simplified, formulation that achieves: (a) hiding softmax division within other nonlinear function evaluations; (b) inherently numerically stable computation of exponentials, eliminating the need for maximum value subtraction; and (c) a reduction in computational cost without introducing numerical approximations to the FlashAttention kernel. Importantly, the essential FlashAttention properties that facilitate efficient tiled implementation are fully preserved. Hardware implementation results at 28nm demonstrate that this proposed formulation achieves a 22.8% reduction in area and a 20.3% reduction in power, on average, compared to state-of-the-art parallel hardware architectures without any performance penalty.

title: Thermal System Identification of Electric Machine Stators using ARX Methods
authors: Nicholas Krause, Dominick Sossong, Ian P. Brown
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: The temperature rise of stator windings has a significant influence on the torque density, lifetime, and efficiency of electric machinery. The prediction of the thermal performance of electric machines is critical to ensuring the desired lifetime of winding insulation, losses, and demagnetization risk. A popular thermal modeling technique for electric machines is lumped parameter thermal networks (LPTNs). One of the challenges of using LPTNs for estimating electric machine temperatures is that thermal conductivities and thermal capacitances are significantly influenced by manufacturing and material variations. This paper presents the use of AutoRegressive eXongenous (ARX) system identification techniques for the estimation of secondorder Ohmic power loss to winding temperature transfer function coefficients or time constants. Five motorettes are constructed to explore the influence of the input signal, sample rate, and data record length on ARX coefficient estimation. The winding temperatures predicted by the second-order transfer function with ARX estimated coefficients matches very closely with experimentally measured winding temperatures during validation. Differences in the thermal coefficents and time constants among the motorettes due to intentional construction variation were detected using the ARX technique.
