title: Hardware Design Optimization and Testing of an Interleaved DC-DC Converter with Asymmetric Phase-Leg Structure for Reversable Solid Oxide Fuel Cell Applications
authors: Ahmed Amr Saafan, Timothy Thacker, Dong Dong, Rolando Burgos
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: This paper presents the design optimization and experimental validation of a two-channel DC-DC converter utilizing an asymmetric phase-leg architecture for a 23 kW reversible solid oxide fuel cell (RSOFC) system. Building upon previous work, where a multi-objective optimization framework identified the two-channel interleaved buck converter as the most effective topology in terms of efficiency and weight, the proposed design integrates an asymmetric phase-leg configuration composed of three high-side and one low-side SiC MOSFETs to accommodate the RSOFC's bidirectional yet asymmetric current demands. The PCB layout is carefully engineered to minimize and balance parasitic elements, achieving a commutation loop inductance of only 4.3 nH. A static thermal model incorporating copper inlays is implemented to improve the thermal performance of the surface-mount SiC MOSFETs. Furthermore, the design of the gate drive circuitry and the digital control platform responsible for implementing average current mode control is detailed. Experimental validation confirms the high-performance operation of the DC-DC converter, achieving peak efficiencies in excess of 99.1% and a gravimetric power density of 11 kW/kg.

title: Analysis and Implementation of Transformer-Less High Voltage Gain Buck Converter
authors: Dinh Phuc Nguyen, Huang-Jen Chiu, Anh Dung Nguyen, Yu-Chen Liu, Trong Nha Quang, Thanh Nhat Trung Tran, Van-Quy Le
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: In this paper, a DC-DC converter with low voltage stress on the switching devices and a high voltage conversion ratio is proposed. The operation principle and characteristics are similar to the traditional buck converter. The proposed converter can operate in Continuous Conduction Mode (CCM) and Discontinuous Conduction Mode (DCM). Additionally, due to the similar nature of the two converters, the controller of the proposed converter is simple and easy to implement. Moreover, a high voltage conversion can be achieved with low voltage stress on the switching devices compared to the traditional design, resulting in significantly reduced losses. Finally, a 40W, 48V-to-1.5V prototype operating at 100kHz is built and tested to verify the feasibility of the proposed converter.

title: Robust $H_{\infty}$ AC-Grid-Forming Electrolytic Capacitor-Free Fully Soft-Switched AC/DC On-Board Charger for Vehicle-to-Home Application
authors: Siamak Derakhshan, John Lam
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: This paper presents a new robust <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$H_{\infty}$</tex> state-feedback control system for an AC-Grid-Forming (AC-GFM) control of an electrolytic capacitor-less bidirectional AC/DC On-Board Charger (OBC) enabling Vehicle-to-Home (V2H) operation with guaranteed robust stability and robust <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$H_{\infty}$</tex> performance. The proposed control strategy ensures global stability and robustness, providing robust voltage control during DC-to-AC operation of the OBC. By modeling parametric uncertainties as polytopic-type convex uncertainties, the controller employs a Linear Matrix Inequality (LMI)-based state-feedback approach driven by convex optimization to minimize performance degradation under voltage disturbances and component uncertainties. The utilized converter features a half-bridge/dual-stacked switch topology that achieves fully soft-switched operation and eliminates the need for traditional electrolytic capacitors via an active ripple reduction control strategy. Simulation results and experimental validation on a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{1}\mathbf{kW}, \boldsymbol{750}\mathbf{V}_{\mathbf{dc}}/\boldsymbol{120}\ \mathbf{V}_{\mathbf{rms}}$</tex> proof-of-concept prototype demonstrate the system's superior transient response, precise reference tracking, and reliability under system uncertainties and disturbances.

title: Design and Development of a Transillumination-based Intraoral Imaging Probe for Dental Implant Localization
authors: Prerna, Milind Lal, Obelish Sai, Karthika. J, Uttam M. Pal
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Multiple usage of ionizing radiation exposure from conventional imaging methods, such as CT scans and X-rays for dental implant procedures lead to significant risks to the patient. This study involves the design and development of a transillumination-based intraoral imaging probe as a radiation-free alternative for the visualization of dental implant after healing, when the gums fully cover the metal implant. For validation, the probe was tried and tested on tissue-mimicking Polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) phantoms with a buried M2 metallic screw imitating a dental implant. The accuracy of the probe in predicting implant diameter was validated by quantitative analysis of intensity profiles, achieving an error rate of 5.29%. The imaging probe showcased key implant features, potentially offering a safer approach to locating implant.

title: Model-Free Physiological Denoising Using State-Space Reconstruction and Time Reversal
authors: Andrea Scarciglia, Claudio Bonanno, Gaetano Valenza
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Physiological systems exhibit nonlinear deterministic behavior driven by physiological noise. Since the exact deterministic functions governing these systems are unknown, estimating physiological noise and, in particular, performing effective denoising is challenging. This study introduces a model-free denoising method for biomedical signals based on state-space reconstruction and time-reversed forecasting. The method’s effectiveness is demonstrated on discrete-time noisy synthetic data, where it outperforms existing techniques. Applying the method to real Heart Rate Variability (HRV) series (10 subjects from each cohort: healthy, heart failure, and atrial fibrillation) resulted in reduced physiological noise and decreased Sample Entropy (SampEn) across all groups. While a standard HRV analysis associated the highest SampEn with atrial fibrillation, denoising revealed that healthy individuals actually exhibit the highest cardiac complexity. Additionally, the method effectively enhances the distinction between healthy and heart failure conditions.Clinical relevance— The proposed physiological noise reduction technique offers new unbiased insights into the complexity and dynamical analysis of the cardiovascular system.

title: Robotic Gripper Sensing with Optimized Grouped Electrode Angles for ECT Imaging
authors: Yang Hu, Haozheng Bai, Ruixiang Deng, Wuqiang Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Imaging Systems and Techniques (IST)
abstract: Electrical capacitance tomography (ECT) can be integrated into robotic grippers to image the dielectric distribution of grasped objects. The aim of this study is to develop an ECT system that balances mechanical constraints and imaging performance for such integration. The system consists of three groups of electrodes with four electrodes in each group, which are mounted on a three-finger robotic grippers. Inspired by fan-beam scanning, the configuration includes one fixed electrode group and two variable electrode groups with inter-group angles of $0^{\circ}, 20^{\circ}, 40^{\circ}$, and 60° for performance evaluation. For each configuration, rotational scanning is performed over 360° at $\mathbf{1 0}^{\circ}$ intervals for capacitance measurement. For image reconstruction, Landweber iteration masked by linear back projection (LBP) and multi-angle data fusion are employed. The imaging quality is assessed by image correlation coefficient (CC) and structural similarity index (SSIM). Simulation results show that for a twoobject target, the optimized reconstruction at 0° achieves the highest imaging performance, with SSIM of 0.98 and CC of 0.97. For annular and stratified targets, the angle-fused reconstruction provides superior structural fidelity across all angles. Overall, smaller inter-group angles consistently yield high reconstruction quality, particularly for complex targets. These findings establish practical guidelines for grouped electrode design in robotic ECT systems, enabling high-fidelity permittivity imaging across diverse object types, handled by a gripper.

title: A Breakerless Solid-State Protection Scheme for VSC-based DC Microgrids
authors: Jinzhuo Bai, Li Qi, Ting Wang, Yeji Jiang, Xuemeng Zhang, Zhiguo Hao
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: As the adoption of DC microgrids expands, the need for robust, fast, and cost-effective protection against faults becomes significant. Traditional protection methods often rely on DC circuit breakers (DCCBs), which can be slow or prohibitively expensive. This paper proposes a novel breakerless solid-state protection scheme for Voltage Source Converter (VSC)-based DC microgrids. The scheme utilizes the distributed protection devices (DPDs) integrated with solid-state switching devices (SSSDs), galvanic isolation switching devices (GISDs), and a protection controller at the terminal of each converter. The SSSD provides ultra-fast isolation of the converter bridge from the filter capacitor, while the GISD ensures physical isolation for safety. A central controller coordinates the functions of faulty branch location, faulty branch isolation, and restoration of the healthy parts of the system. The proposed protection scheme is capable of ultra-fast converter isolation from faults without interrupting high fault currents, and thus eliminates the need for DCCBs. The proposed scheme reduces protection cost and enhances feasibility of DC in field applications. The effectiveness of the proposed scheme is validated through simulations in MATLAB/Simulink, which demonstrate its ability to detect and isolate a fault, protect converter components, and restore the healthy parts of a microgrid to stable operation with minimal disruption.

title: Preliminary Investigation of Clustering Analysis for Understanding Individual Sensory Contributions in Human Postural Control
authors: Masato Shindo, Ryosuke Aoki
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: In human postural control, visual, proprioceptive, and vestibular functions cooperatively work to maintain a stable posture, known as sensory reweighting. Considering that the training effect on sensory reweighting is suggested to vary depending on the original sensory weights, examining the variations in weights across individuals is crucial. This study investigated the individual characteristics of sensory contributions more comprehensively and quantitatively by clustering analysis. A total of 122 participants performed the modified Sensory Organization Test (mSOT), which consists of the four standing conditions, and the three relative sensory weights were calculated using the center of pressure (COP) sway in each condition. Each participant’s sensory weights were classified with similar sensory properties using the X-means clustering method, showing that sensory characteristics could be divided into six clusters, suggesting the existence of diverse variations. Almost all of the clusters included both age groups, those under 50 years old and those 50 years and older, indicating that the use of sensory modalities varies among individuals regardless of age.Clinical relevance— These findings could provide foundational knowledge for developing sensory reweighting training programs tailored to specific sensory profiles, as well as for delivering clear and personalized feedback in health assessments.

title: Systemic Analysis of Blood Pressure Waveform Features Using a Cardiovascular Simulator: Implications for Non-invasive Vascular Health Monitoring
authors: Bomi Lee, Junki Hong, Adelle Ria Persad, Hyunwoo Song, Jae-Hak Jeong, Yong-Hwa Park
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Blood pressure waveform analysis offers valuable insights into cardiovascular health, yet the complex interrelationships between waveform features and specific cardiovascular parameters remain incompletely understood. This study presents a systematic analysis of blood pressure waveform features using a validated cardiovascular simulator that accurately replicates pulse wave reflection phenomena and non-linear vascular mechanics. By precisely controlling key cardiovascular parameters—vascular elasticity, stroke volume, peripheral resistance, and heart rate—within physiologically realistic ranges, the independent effects of each parameter on waveform morphology were quantified. The simulator-based approach uniquely enabled exploration across the entire physiological spectrum, incorporating non-linear relationships that would be difficult to observe in traditional clinical studies. Sensitivity and stability analyses identified specific features highly responsive to vascular elasticity changes, with DownSlope and pulse pressure (PP) demonstrating both high sensitivity and stability. Clinical validation using waveform data from 78 human subjects confirmed that simulator-derived sensitivity patterns were observable in actual human waveforms, particularly the strong correlation between DownSlope and vascular elasticity as measured by pulse wave velocity. This physics-informed approach to feature selection provides valuable insights for non-invasive cardiovascular health monitoring applications and establishes a foundation for more interpretable and reliable machine learning models in cardiovascular assessment.Clinical Relevance— This enables clinicians to more accurately interpret pressure waveforms by providing clearer understanding of how elemental cardiovascular parameter changes are reflected on waveform features.

title: Fraud Detection by Machine Learning and Fuzzy Using Imbalance Credit Card Turkish Dataset
authors: Khattab M. Ali Alheeti, Anas D. Sallibi, Ahmed Qasim Abdulghani, Osman Nuri Ucan, Saleem Hamad Majeed, Muzhir Shaban Al-Ani, Hamsa M Ahmed
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Business Analytics for Technology and Security (ICBATS)
abstract: The increase in Credit Card Fraud (CCF) has put researchers continuously work to find advanced and flexible solutions to reduce financial losses. Difficulties researchers face include dataset problems such as imbalance cases and fraud methods and their development. This work presents an intelligent system that detects fraud through Machine Learning (ML) and fuzzy membership. We used four algorithms from ML: Logistic regression (LR), Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA), Naive Bayes (NB) and XGBoost. We used a Turkish dataset from the IEEE Data Port. We used the accuracy metric to check the system efficiency and other metrics. Then, we made a comparison with previous work.

title: Exploring the Effect of Gate Loop on Switching Behaviors of Paralleled Discrete SiC MOSFETs
authors: Yifu Zhang, Emanuel Eni, Shashank Karanth
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: To meet the growing need for higher current power switches, paralleling discrete SiC MOSFETs is becoming more and more prevalent, as it can offer more second sourcing flexibilities. The circuit and PCB of paralleled devices must be carefully designed to optimize the current and loss sharing while avoiding oscillations. Apart from the power loop and devices themselves, the gate loop also plays a significant role, particularly when the dv/dt during the switching transient becomes very high. In this work, a simple model is proposed to analyze the impact of gate loop on the oscillations. Corresponding experimental measurements were also performed to verify the analysis results. In the end, a recommended optimization strategy is proposed, accordingly.

title: Imaging-Process-Informed Generative Strategy for Microwave Medical Image Processing
authors: Qihua Liu, Zheng Gong, Yifan Chen
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Microwave medical imaging (MMI) has significant potential for stroke imaging due to its unique portability and timeliness, and is therefore highly valued by researchers. This paper proposes an imaging-process-informed generative strategy (IPIGS) that addresses the challenges posed by nonlinearity in the imaging process, thereby generating more intuitive and diagnosis-friendly microwave medical images. Aiming at the limitations of traditional imaging methods (e.g., distorted Born iterative method, DBIM), namely the blurry imaging background and the confusion of stroke areas, we first attribute this issue to the nonlinearity in the imaging process. That is, under certain circumstances, the dielectric constants of different brain tissues are misinterpreted by the DBIM imaging algorithm, resulting in incorrect imaging of stroke areas. Then, we establish a generalized model for this nonlinear problem, and introduce the corresponding a prior knowledge (APK), such as brain tissue information that is sensitive to changes in dielectric constants, into the generative adversarial network Pix2pix to restore the unclear imaging caused by this problem. The final results show that our method has a significant improvement over traditional methods in terms of the structural similarity and threshold segmentation effect, with an increase in structural similarity of 8% compared to traditional methods and an average increase in intersection-over-union of approximately 47%. This provides new possibilities for the restoration of microwave images.

title: Pulsating Power Processing and Voltage Balancing of Multi-Active Bridge (MAB) Converter for Single-Phase Grid-Connected EV Charging
authors: Md Didarul Alam, M A Awal, Nazmul Hassan, Srdjan Lukic, Iqbal Husain
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: This paper presents a control framework for single-phase grid-connected electric vehicle (EV) charging using a Multi-Active Bridge (MAB) DC-DC converter that enables direct pulsating power processing and voltage balancing. In conventional systems, large DC-link capacitors are required to suppress low-frequency ripple originating from single-phase AC-DC rec-tifiers, increasing cost and reducing reliability. The proposed approach mitigates this by enabling the load-side battery to absorb ripple current directly, thereby reducing DC-link capacitance requirements. A Proportional-Integral-Resonant (PIR) controller, integrated with a decoupling matrix, ensures 120 Hz ripple current tracking and mitigates power cross-coupling among ports. A four-winding MAB topology is employed, where two high- voltage-side windings interface with series-connected Active Front-End (AFE) rectifiers, improving transformer utilization and supporting scalable multi-port operation. The controller further incorporates intra-bus voltage balancing to minimize circulating currents and improve power sharing accuracy. The effectiveness of the proposed method is validated through both simulation and experimental studies on a DSP-controlled four-port MAB prototype. Results demonstrate up to 75% reduction in required DC-link capacitance, robust ripple power handling, and tight voltage regulation under both equal and unequal loading conditions.

title: A Dwell-Time Approach for Global Optimal Fault-Tolerant Control Performance: an Aeronautic Case
authors: M. Gouzien, S. Waitman, D. Henry
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Control and Fault-Tolerant Systems (SysTol)
abstract: This paper aims at demonstrating how the dwelltime fault-tolerant control (FTC) approach can be used to accommodate faults occurring in control surfaces of high speed aircraft. The application support is the F-8 aircraft that performs a coordinated turn. Global exponential stability of the FTC law is proven, considering the coupling between the fault diagnosis and control units. Beyond the application case, the paper demonstrates how the structured <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$H_{\infty}$</tex> approach can be embedded within the dwell-time FTC theory. A simulation campaign considering sensor noise, control surfaces saturation and uncertainties in mass, inertia and aerodynamic coefficients, demonstrates the potential of the proposed approach.

title: EDGeNet: Electroencephalography Denoising Efficient Network for Fast Artifact Removal
authors: Dipayan Dewan, Apoorva Srivastava, Debdoot Sheet
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Electroencephalography (EEG) is a non-invasive neuroimaging technique that records electrical activity in the brain using electrodes placed on the scalp. It provides high temporal resolution, making it valuable for studying brain dynamics, cognitive processes, and neurological disorders. EEG is widely used in clinical and research settings for diagnosing epilepsy, sleep disorders, and mental health conditions. However, EEG signals are often contaminated by artifacts from ocular, muscular, and environmental sources, complicating accurate analysis. Traditional artifact removal methods, such as Independent Component Analysis (ICA) and wavelet transform, require significant computational resources and manual tuning, limiting their effectiveness in real-time applications. To overcome these challenges, this paper presents a deep learning-based framework for automated EEG denoising and simultaneous artifact removal while ensuring efficiency in real-time deployability. Various performance metrics such as relative-root-mean-square (RRMSE), structural similarity index measure (SSIM), and correlation, (CC) are measured to evaluate the model performance. The model achieves an average temporal and spectral RRMSE of 0.214 and 0.217 respectively, average SSIM of 0.964 and CC 0.963 of across various datasets. The model outperforms as compared to the state-of-the-art method with 295 × lesser parameters as compared to prior models. The model is able to denoise the EEG signals from various artifacts simultaneously. The proposed model demonstrates the potential for real-time deployment. The source code is available at https://github.com/dipayandewan94/EDGeNet

title: Adaptive and Switching Internal Model Design: ROBUST ADAPTIVE FEEDFORWARD TECHNIQUES FOR STABLE SYSTEMS
authors: Yang Wang, Yizhou Gong, Chenyang Ji, Gilberto Pin, Andrea Serrani, Thomas Parisini
publish: IEEE Control Systems
abstract: This article addresses the output regulation problem for linear systems whose model is not known a priori but are internally stable or have achieved internal stability through feedback. The article provides a perspective that complements classical internal model-based methodologies. The paradigm we follow emphasizes adaptive feedforward control, signifying all those design methodologies that position a model of the signal to be tracked or rejected by a controlled system outside the primary feedback loop responsible for system stabilization.

title: Pitfalls in Using Pallor of the Eye to Detect Anaemia with Digital Cameras
authors: Thomas A. Wemyss, Ranjan Rajendram, Terence S. Leung
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Anaemia - a reduced concentration of functional haemoglobin in the blood - affects around 20% of the global population. As a result, there is focus on developing non-invasive methods to screen for anaemia. A promising group of techniques uses smartphone imaging of external tissues. Because haemoglobin preferentially reflects red light, by measuring the colour (‘redness’) of blood vessels (or tissues as a whole), it is suggested that blood haemoglobin may be estimated. However, a potential issue is that ‘redness’ might depend not just on the severity of anaemia, but also upon the ‘physiological structure’ - i.e. the vessel density, vessel depth, and vessel diameter. We performed Monte-Carlo tissue optics simulations to investigate the potential impact of these structural factors on measurement of colour in the scleral conjunctiva. We found that within reasonable ranges of physiological structure, it is possible to get similar redness between severely anaemic (2.35 g/dL) and non-anaemic (15 g/dL) blood haemoglobin concentrations. This suggests that simple measurement of the redness of external tissues may not be suitable for detecting anaemia.Clinical RelevancePallor of external tissue is commonly used as a hallmark of anaemia. These results suggest that pallor may arise not only from anaemia, but also from variation in the physiological structure of the eye.

title: Magnetic Concrete for Road-Embedded Wireless Power Transfer: A Review
authors: Xiuhu Sun, Shen-En Chen, Qiang Mu, Jiale Zhou, Tiefu Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: Magnetic concrete (MC) is a composite material that integrates high-permeability magnetic particles with binders, offering a promising alternative to conventional ferrite components in wireless power transfer (WPT) systems for electric vehicles (EVs) and battery-electric locomotives (BELs). Compared to ferrite cores, MC provides enhanced mechanical durability and flexibility, making it suitable for embedding in roadways and other structural applications. This review synthesizes recent advancements in MC, focusing on its composition, magnetic properties, and potential for large-scale applications. The main research findings indicate that commonly used binders for MC include cement, resin, and polyurethane, while the primary magnetic fillers are ferrite particles, iron powder, and nanocrystalline materials. Additionally, the effective magnetic permeability of MC is influenced by the intrinsic properties, volume fraction, and particle size of the magnetic materials, as well as the processing methods used. However, MC's permeability remains significantly lower than that of the base magnetic materials, typically ranging from 2.5 to 222. Finally, MC is still largely in the research stage, with limited commercial deployment, and its economic viability has yet to be fully established.

title: A Synchronous Gate Driver System for Series-Connected SiC MOSFETs for High-Voltage Pulsed Power Supplies Based on Magnetic Pulse Compression
authors: Pourya Javidi, Hyeongmeen Baik, Jinia Roy
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: This paper proposes a synchronous gate driver system for series-connected SiC MOSFETs based on Magnetic Pulse Compression (MPC) for a direct-switched High-Voltage Pulsed Power Supply (HVPPS). In these pulse generators, a large number of series-connected switches are typically used to handle and process high voltage levels, with required rise/fall times in the nanosecond range. The proposed synchronous gate driver provides robustness against Short-Circuit Semiconductor Failures (SCSFs), which is the most common failure mechanism that can occur in any of the series-stacked devices, while eliminating the need for separate isolated power supplies to drive each switch. Additionally, through the operation of magnetic pulse compression employed on the gates of these devices, a high current can be delivered to the gate, resulting in improved switching performance. The functionality of the proposed synchronous gate driver system is validated through SPICE simulation results for 10 series connected SiC MOSFRTs.

title: Mutation-Driven Ensemble Learning Framework for Glioma Subtype Classification
authors: Isabella Shen
publish: 2025 18th International Congress on Image and Signal Processing, BioMedical Engineering and Informatics (CISP-BMEI)
abstract: Gliomas are tumors originating from glial cells that support and protect neurons in the nervous system but can become malignant and quickly invade healthy brain tissue. Glioma subtypes have varying growth rates and respond differently to treatment options. Early identification of the subtype will help determine the treatment plan and can affect patient outcome. Some studies have differentiated between low-grade and highgrade gliomas, but limited studies have closely examined the factors that distinguish subtypes. Further, while clinical and radiographic features are commonly used for diagnosis, purely genomic approaches remain understudied. Thus, this study aims to leverage a mutation-driven machine learning classification pipeline to predict glioma subtypes based on genomic data. Data was extracted from The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) Project and Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center (MSK), and a panel of 20 most frequently mutated genes in gliomas was analyzed to predict three major glioma subtypes: oligodendroglioma, astrocytoma, and glioblastoma. Three base models (multinomial logistic regression, Random Forest, and XGBoost) were trained and evaluated independently. To further improve generalization and accuracy of classification, out-of-fold predictions from the base models were used to develop an ensemble XGBoost metamodel. The stacked model achieved an overall accuracy of 77.9 % and an AUC of 0.896, outperforming all the base models. Notably, the meta-model classified glioblastomas, the deadliest subtype, with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 2. 2 \%}$</tex> accuracy, highlighting the model's ability to identify high-grade tumors. Our findings illustrate the clinical potential that mutation-based classifiers hold and suggest that genetic features alone can hold strong predictive value for glioma subtype classification. This study also demonstrates how mutation-based machine learning frameworks can enable precision accuracy, especially in settings where clinical data may not be readily available.

title: Mixed Potential Theory-Based Large-Signal Stability Analysis Method for Multi-Port Dual DC Buses Power Router
authors: Bingjie Liu, Yaopeng Huang, Xianzhe Pang, Alian Chen, Wei Wang, Shijie Cheng
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: The dual DC buses power router (DBPR) is becoming a prevalent architecture due to its ability to improve the grid compatibility and economy. However, the mutual influence between the DC buses and ports severely endangers the system stability. In this regard, a novel large-signal stability analysis method for the multi-port DBPR in system level is proposed based on the mixed potential theory (MPT), which can obtain a uniformed stability criterion under variations in system topology and parameters. First, according to the operating characteristics of distinct DBPR ports, a simplified equivalent circuit model is established to achieve topological unification, which reduces the modeling complexity and improves feasibility. Then, the mixed potential function is constructed to derive the large-signal stability criterion for the DBPR, where the parameters affecting system stability can be identified. Finally, simulation results verify the correctness and accuracy of the proposed method.

title: Discrete Control Barrier Function Design for Constrained Heat Pump Control Using Local Linear Models
authors: Regina Deisling, Robert Dehnert, Laura Ackerschott, Michelle Rosik, Bernd Tibken
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Control and Fault-Tolerant Systems (SysTol)
abstract: Heat pumps play a key role in decarbonized energy systems due to their fully electric operation. Ensuring safe and efficient performance requires compliance with internal constraints, and future grid conditions may additionally impose power consumption limits. This paper proposes a control approach based on Discrete Control Barrier Functions (DCBFs) to enforce such constraints within an existing heat pump control structure. The DCBF is designed using a Local Linear Model Network (LLMN) trained via the Local Linear Model Tree (LOLIMOT) algorithm. A robust observer for a linear parameter-varying representation of the LLMN provides state estimates for the DCBF, whereby robust stability is ensured by the use of linear matrix inequalities (LMIs). The method is validated in a closed-loop simulation using a dynamic model of the refrigerant circuit.

title:
Nonlinear dynamics in pulse-modulated feedback drug dosing
                    <sup>*</sup>
authors: Alexander Medvedev, Anton V. Proskurnikov, Zhanybai T. Zhusubaliyev
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Pulse-modulated feedback is utilized in drug dosing to mimic sustained over a longer period of time manual discrete dose administration, the latter is in contrast with continuous drug infusion. The intermittent mode of dosing calls for a hybrid (continuous-discrete) modeling of the closed-loop system, where the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of the drug are captured by differential equations whereas the control law is described by difference equations. Hybrid dynamics are highly nonlinear which complicates formal design of pulse-modulated feedback. This paper demonstrates complex nonlinear dynamical phenomena arising in a simple control system of dosing a neuromuscular blockade agent in anesthesia. Along with the nominal periodic regimen, undesirable nonlinear behaviors, i.e. periodic solutions of high multiplicity, multistability, as well as deterministic chaos, are shown to exist. It is concluded that design of feedback drug dosing algorithms based on a hybrid paradigm has to be informed by a thorough bifurcation analysis in order to secure patient safety.Clinical Relevance—The paper highlights potential patient safety risks posed by complex nonlinear phenomena in closed-loop drug administration. It also presents a systematic approach to mitigate them at the controller design phase.

title: Fuzzy Modeling and Tracking Control of Fuel Consumption in Cargo Ships
authors: Abderrahim El-Amrani, Ayah Barhrhouj, Bouchra Ananou, Mustapha Ouladsine
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Control and Fault-Tolerant Systems (SysTol)
abstract: This paper addresses the modeling and control of fuel consumption in diesel-powered cargo ships, focusing on ensuring robust performance under varying operating conditions. The objective is to regulate the ship's propulsion and engine dynamics by adjusting the engine power command, despite the presence of external disturbances such as waves and wind. The nonlinear behavior of the fuel consumption system is represented using a Takagi-Sugeno (T-S) fuzzy model derived from multiple operating scenarios. Based on this representation, a fuzzy static output feedback (SOF) controller is designed using the descriptor approach. The proposed control strategy guarantees stability and satisfactory fuel regulation performance through conditions formulated as linear matrix inequalities (LMIs). Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness and robustness of the control scheme under realistic conditions.

title: Design and Implementation of an Intelligent Negotiation System: Using Dispute Settlement as an Application Scenario
authors: Jing Jiang, Rui Jiang
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Business Analytics for Technology and Security (ICBATS)
abstract: The intelligent consultation system based on dispute settlement is an important link in the application and development of dispute settlement. The high-quality intelligent consultation system based on dispute settlement helps to promote the development of dispute settlement application and has an important impact on the development of dispute settlement application. Nowadays, the research on the construction and application of intelligent consultation system based on dispute settlement mostly focuses on the direction of theoretical research, expounds the management of intelligent consultation system and dispute settlement management, lacks the construction and application analysis of intelligent negotiation system based on dispute settlement, and ignores the influence direction of the application of dispute settlement management. In order to further study, the actual impact of the construction and application of the intelligent negotiation system based on dispute settlement, this paper completes the design case based on the analysis and conclusion of the intelligent negotiation system model based on dispute settlement, and provides some reference for the construction and application process of the intelligent negotiation system based on dispute settlement.

title: Short Training Techniques to Enhance Usability of System-Assigned PINs
authors: Israt Jahan Jui, Amirali Salehi-Abari, Julie Thorpe
publish: 2025 22nd Annual International Conference on Privacy, Security, and Trust (PST)
abstract: Personal Identification Numbers (PINs) are widely used for authentication on mobile devices such as smartphones, which act as gateways to many important accounts (e.g., financial, email, etc.). Unfortunately, people tend to choose easy-to-recall PINs involving birthdays, anniversaries, or keypad patterns that are vulnerable to guessing attacks. System-assigned PINs can improve PIN security in this regard; however, they have usability problems such as feeling the need to store the assigned PIN, longer login times, and difficulty remembering. In this paper, we propose, design, and evaluate a set of short training techniques (16-34 seconds) inspired by implicit learning techniques, to improve the usability of system-assigned PINs. We evaluated our designs in a two-session user study with 184 university students. Our results show that some designs offer significant improvements in the login success rate, login times, and user perceptions. These advantages are in addition to our design’s short single-session training, making it more compatible with typical registration workflows than previously proposed multisession training techniques.

title: Multi-Scale Convolutional Attention Enhanced Residual Network for Cuff-less Blood Pressure Prediction
authors: Xiangyu Zhang, Yumin Li, Li Ling, Jianqing Li, Chengyu Liu
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: The demand for cuffless blood pressure monitoring is increasing in the clinical management of cardiovascular events. Currently, cuffless non-invasive devices for blood pressure control are widely used, with the primary research focus on enhancing the accuracy of blood pressure estimation using intelligent algorithms. This study aims to explore a cuffless method for estimating systolic blood pressure (SBP) and diastolic blood pressure (DBP) using photoplethysmogram (PPG) and electrocardiogram (ECG) signals. To this end, we propose a novel residual network framework based on dynamic convolution strategy and multi-scale convolutional attention enhancement mechanisms. The framework first utilizes dynamic convolution and channel adaptive mechanisms to extract low-level features from the PPG and ECG modalities. It then employs a novel parallel cross-mixing architecture that integrates residual blocks with a multi-scale attention block (MSAB), which complements a global attention mechanism to enhance the modeling of long-range dependencies. The proposed framework was validated on the VitalDB dataset, and experimental results demonstrate excellent performance in both SBP and DBP estimation tasks (SBP MAE ± SD: 3.83 ± 5.71 mmHg, DBP MAE ± SD: 2.29 ± 3.69 mmHg). The framework outperforms existing models and meets international blood pressure measurement standards, including those set by the American Association for Medical Instrumentation (AAMI).

title: Optimization of a Permanent Magnet Shaft Generator System for Large Vessels
authors: Hyeon-Jeong Bak, Min-Jun Cho, Ruzsa János, Sang-Hyun Kim, Seung-Ki Sul
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: This paper presents the design optimization of a permanent magnet shaft generator (PMSG) to improve the overall shaft generator system efficiency for large vessels. The study focuses on selecting appropriate system constraints and determining the optimal design parameters of the PMSG, with consideration for both cost-effectiveness and operational system-level efficiency. To validate the proposed design, a prototype was manufactured and tested with a variable frequency drive under realistic operating conditions. The results indicate that the optimized shaft generator system achieves up to a 0.79% increase in total system efficiency compared to a conventional configuration, demonstrating the potential advantages of applying advanced electrical machine optimization to marine propulsion systems.

title: Additive Manufactured Vapor-Chamber-Based Two Phase Modular Cold Plate for TO-247- Packaged Power Semiconductor
authors: Ishfaqur Rahman, Jason Auduong, Scott Thompson, Qingyun Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: TO-247 packaged power semiconductors offer significantly lower packaging cost compared to traditional power modules, making them strong candidates for high-power, cost-sensitive applications. However, their compact footprint and high heat flux density pose considerable thermal management challenges. This study presents a compact <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathbf{13.5}\times \mathbf{16.5}\times \mathbf{9.1}\ \mathbf{mm}^{\mathbf{3}})$</tex> modular dual-phase cold plate that integrates a vapor chamber with a liquid-cooled heat sink, designed for metal additive manufacturing. The heat sink includes internal pin fin structures to promote coolant flow, while the vapor chamber provides lateral heat spreading via vapor–liquid phase interactions. Experimental testing with approximately 80% fill level showed improved performance over the empty configuration, with the charged device maintaining chip surface temperatures below 62 °C up to 63 W. The corresponding thermal resistance ranged from 0.65 to 1.04 K/W, compared to 0.71 to 0.88 K/W in the empty case, representing a reduction of up to 22%. These results highlight the potential of additively manufactured dual-phase cold plates for compact, high-flux electronic cooling.

title: Joint Brain Structure-Function Analysis with Correlation-Consistent Learning for Alzheimer's Disease Diagnosis
authors: Kaixiang Shu, Peng Yang, Tianfu Wang, Xuegang Song, Baiying Lei
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: In neuroimaging-based Alzheimer's Disease (AD) diagnosis, effectively integrating structural MRI (sMRI) and resting-state functional MRI (rs-fMRI) data while preserving clinical interpretability remains a significant challenge. To address this issue, we propose a novel transformer-based framework that unifies heterogeneous imaging features into coherent region-level representations. Our approach uniquely leverages prior anatomical knowledge to guide attention toward AD-relevant regions while employing a learnable mapping mechanism that transforms sMRI spatial features into biologically meaningful regional representations. We implement a consistency constraint to ensure optimal alignment between structural and functional coupling across modalities, followed by a Bayesian fusion strategy to integrate these aligned multi-modal features. Through comprehensive evaluation on the ADNI dataset, our method demonstrates not only superior diagnostic accuracy compared to existing state-of-the-art approaches but also provides clinically interpretable insights into AD-related brain connectivity patterns. This work represents a significant advancement in multi-modal neuroimaging analysis for AD diagnosis, successfully combining enhanced diagnostic performance with clinical interpretability.

title: NeuroMoE: A Transformer-Based Mixture-of-Experts Framework for Multi-Modal Neurological Disorder Classification
authors: Wajih Hassan Raza, Aamir Bader Shah, Yu Wen, Yidan Shen, Juan Diego Martinez Lemus, Mya Caryn Schiess, Timothy Michael Ellmore, Renjie Hu, Xin Fu
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: The integration of multi-modal Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) and clinical data holds great promise for enhancing the diagnosis of neurological disorders (NDs) in real-world clinical settings. Deep Learning (DL) has recently emerged as a powerful tool for extracting meaningful patterns from medical data to aid in diagnosis. However, existing DL approaches struggle to effectively leverage multi-modal MRI and clinical data, leading to suboptimal performance.To address this challenge, we utilize a unique, proprietary multi-modal clinical dataset curated for ND research. Based on this dataset, we propose a novel transformer-based Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) framework for ND classification, leveraging multiple MRI modalities—anatomical (aMRI), Diffusion Tensor Imaging (DTI), and functional (fMRI)—alongside clinical assessments. Our framework employs transformer encoders to capture spatial relationships within volumetric MRI data while utilizing modality-specific experts for targeted feature extraction. A gating mechanism with adaptive fusion dynamically integrates expert outputs, ensuring optimal predictive performance. Comprehensive experiments and comparisons with multiple baselines demonstrate that our multi-modal approach significantly enhances diagnostic accuracy, particularly in distinguishing overlapping disease states. Our framework achieves a validation accuracy of 82.47%, outperforming baseline methods by over 10%, highlighting its potential to improve ND diagnosis by applying multi-modal learning to real-world clinical data.Clinical Relevance— In neurological disorder (ND) research, a critical gap remains in mapping the continuum of disease progression, from prodromal conditions such as idiopathic REM Sleep Behavior Disorder (iRBD) to fully developed disorders like Parkinson’s Disease (PD). A robust multimodal approach that seamlessly integrates diverse data modalities is essential for accurately predicting and understanding this progression. Advancements in this area would provide the foundation for developing models capable of distinguishing overlapping disease states (e.g., PD, dementia with Lewy bodies, and multiple system atrophy) and predicting the transition from presymptomatic conditions like iRBD to established NDs.

title: Novel Rotor Surface Profile Control Method for Minimizing Position Error in VR Resolvers by Harmonic Injection
authors: Ju-Yeong Shin, Gilsu Choi
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: This paper presents an analytical approach to identify the harmonic order of permeance harmonics that affect the position error of a VR resolver based on slot-pole combinations. We apply this technique to identify the dominant permeance harmonic components and propose a novel method to mitigate the position error by incorporating their harmonic coefficients into the rotor airgap function. To evaluate the effectiveness of different optimization techniques for minimizing the position error, we compare the results of applying golden section search and global optimization techniques. A finite element analysis (FEA)-based design optimization is performed to verify the effectiveness of the proposed method, and a 98% reduction in position error is achieved compared to the design without injecting harmonic coefficients.

title: Development of a Free-Viewpoint Bladder Observation System for Cystoscopy
authors: Shunta Kaneko, Hirokazu Nosato, Kyoko Sudo
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Patients with bladder cancer typically require both a transurethral examination and surgery, and accurate recording of information observed during a transurethral examination is necessary for surgery. However, observational recordings are made manually and depend on the physician’s ability, and the digital information gathered during the examination is not fully utilized in surgery. To address these issues, this study aimed to propose a free-viewpoint bladder observation system for cystoscopy based on multi-view image-based three-dimensional (3D) reconstruction. We used neural radiance fields (NeRF) and 3D Gaussian splatting (3DGS) to develop the proposed system as 3D reconstruction methods. Although these methods are state-of-the-art in the field of 3D reconstruction, adapting them to a small dome-shaped bladder is challenging; there needs to be an assumption that the inputs of these methods are the sets of images of the same region captured from multiple viewpoints. To overcome this problem, by classifying the images into bladder dome and neck areas and reconstructing each location, we obtained the entire 3D bladder model. This approach leads to the generation of free-viewpoint images of the whole bladder. We present the results of a comparative study concerning the possibility of preserving examination records. Our findings indicated that NeRF outperformed 3DGS in terms of texture reproducibility, and that reconstruction through dividing area of the bladder was successful in generating free-viewpoint inner images.

title: FS-UNet3+: A Coronary Vessel Segmentation Network Combining High and Low-Frequency Features
authors: Xiu Yang, Yilu Zheng, Li Li, Guoqiang Zheng, Fan He, Zhongxv Yuan
publish: 2025 18th International Congress on Image and Signal Processing, BioMedical Engineering and Informatics (CISP-BMEI)
abstract: Coronary angiography image segmentation serves as a foundational tool in clinical diagnostics, providing critical support for atherosclerotic burden quantification, plaque morphology analysis, and vascular lumen measurement. While deep learning has advanced coronary artery segmentation, current algorithms exhibit persistent limitations: excessive output smoothing and inadequate fusion of localized details with global contextual information, frequently causing segmentation leakage or discontinuity. To resolve these challenges, we propose FSUNet3+, a frequency-aware architecture that synergizes highfrequency boundary cues with low-frequency anatomical patterns. Through frequency decomposition and adaptive feature recalibration, our framework enhances multi-scale representation learning while explicitly modeling spectral complementarity. Complementing this design, we develop a Cascaded MultiScale Strip Convolution (CMSC) block, leveraging elongated kernels to preserve vascular connectivity in branching structures. The hierarchical convolution cascade enables cross-scale feature interaction, improving geometric reasoning of complex vessel networks. Benchmark evaluations on the XCAD dataset confirm our method's effectiveness in maintaining topological integrity while capturing subtle textural variations, demonstrating statistically significant improvements over contemporary segmentation baselines.

title:
Safety-Guaranteed Lung-Protective Mechanical Ventilation using Digital Twins and Reinforcement Learning
                    <sup>*</sup>
authors: Sina M.H. Hajkarim, Prathyush P. Menon, Nadir Yehya, William Joy, Declan G. Bates, Sina Saffaran
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: We present a novel control strategy for automated and individualized mechanical ventilation based on a Reinforcement Learning (RL) controller for a Constrained Markov Decision Process (CMDP). This approach enhances an off-policy actor-critic algorithm known as Primal-Dual Soft Actor-Critic (SAC) with the addition of dual variables to bound critical parameters within clinically acceptable ranges. The proposed technique first creates a high-fidelity computational model (digital twin) of the patient, so that physiological reactions to changes in ventilator settings can be generated in silico to train the RL controller quickly and safely. Once brought online, the novel primal-dual SAC then safely converges to ventilator settings that minimize the risk of ventilator-induced lung injury (VILI), while guaranteeing that the patient’s physiological parameters remain within specified safety limits. Correct and robust functioning of the proposed controller is demonstrated by detailed simulations based on real patient data.Clinical relevance— Closed-loop ventilation has been demonstrated to reduce clinician workload, improve patient-ventilator synchrony, and shorten weaning duration in certain settings. However, most existing closed-loop ventilation modes focus solely on achieving oxygenation targets, offering no assurance of minimizing VILI indices or maintaining them within safe limits. In this study, we address this limitation by introducing a safety-guaranteed closed-loop ventilation technique.

title: Improving Omics-Based Classification: The Role of Feature Selection and Synthetic Data Generation
authors: Diego Perazzolo, Pietro Fanton, Ilaria Barison, Marny Fedrigo, Annalisa Angelini, Chiara Castellani, Enrico Grisan
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Given the increasing complexity of omics datasets, a key challenge is not only improving classification performance but also enhancing the transparency and reliability of model decisions. Effective model performance and feature selection are fundamental for explainability and reliability. In many cases, high-dimensional omics datasets suffer from limited number of samples due to clinical constraints, patient conditions, phenotypes rarity and others conditions. Current omics-based classification models often suffer from narrow interpretability, making it difficult to discern meaningful insights where trust and reproducibility are critical. This study presents a machine learning-based classification framework that integrates feature selection with data augmentation techniques to achieve high-standard classification accuracy while ensuring better interpretability. Using the publicly available dataset E-MTAB-8026, we explore a bootstrap analysis in six binary classification scenarios to evaluate the proposed model’s behaviour. We show that the proposed pipeline yields cross-validated perfomance on small dataset that is conserved when the trained classifier is applied to a larger test set. Our findings emphasize the fundamental balance between accuracy and feature selection, highlighting the positive effect of introducing synthetic data for better generalization, even in scenarios with very limited samples availability.Clinical relevance— The proposed framework addresses a critical challenge in omics-based disease classification by improving model interpretability while maintaining high classification performance. By providing a more explainable data-driven approach, this study contributes to the development of reliable and reproducible diagnostic tools that can support clinical decision-making.

title: Comparative Analysis of High-Power Transient Voltage Suppression Diodes
authors: Yang Xu, Xingyue Tian, Ruirui Chen, Ching-Hsiang Yang, Samuel J. Klein, Hua Bai, Fred Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: Compared to metal oxide varistors (MOVs), highpower transient voltage suppression (TVS) diodes offer faster response, longer lifespan, and more accurate clamping voltage, making them well-suited for protection applications. This paper presents a comprehensive characterization and comparative analysis of two types of high-power TVS diodes, i.e., foldback and non-foldback TVS diodes. Both steady-state and dynamic tests are performed across various temperatures to evaluate their performance. Based on the test results, a detailed comparison is conducted to highlight the distinct behaviors of each type. Finally, the design considerations of TVS diodes are provided through a DC solid-state circuit breaker case study, offering practical insights into their selection and application.

title: A Neuromorphic-Inspired Pipeline for Real-Time Anomaly Detection in IoT Sensor Networks
authors: Nida Nasir, Hussam Al Hamadi
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Business Analytics for Technology and Security (ICBATS)
abstract: As the Internet of Things (IoT) expands into critical domains, real-time anomaly detection becomes essential to maintain system integrity across constrained, distributed sensor networks. Traditional machine learning-based intrusion detection systems are often unsuitable for deployment at the edge due to their reliance on intensive computation, static training pipelines, and cloud connectivity. Inspired by the energy-efficient, eventdriven processing of biological systems, this paper proposes a neuromorphic pipeline tailored for IoT edge environments, integrating spiking neural architectures and biologically plausible learning mechanisms. Throughout the pipeline design, constraints inherent to neuromorphic and IoT-based hardware, such as low power, limited memory, asynchronous operation, and online adaptability—are carefully considered to ensure feasibility for real-world deployment.

title: Towards the Correction of Covariate Shift in EEG-Based Passive Brain-Computer Interfaces for Out-of-Lab Applications
authors: D. Germano, V. Ronca, R. Capotorto, G. Di Flumeri, G. Borghini, A. Giorgi, F. Babiloni, P. Aricò
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: The increasing adoption of wearable EEG technology is enabling the development of passive Brain-Computer Interface (pBCI) systems for real-world applications, in the near future, such as Industry 5.0. However, one major challenge in classifying electroencephalographic (EEG) signals in these settings is covariate shift, which occurs when the distribution of the data changes between training and testing sessions due to variations in EEG headset positioning. This study investigates the effectiveness of a linear transformation approach to mitigate the negative effect of covariate shift. Simulations were conducted by using different shift conditions (i.e. deviation of the headset position from the original one), to evaluate (i) the performance of the transformation function used for mitigating the covariate shift occurrence and (ii) the importance that the change of reference and/or channels has on the classification performance. Results show that normalizing covariate shift-affected data (i.e., target) using shift-free data as a template (i.e., source) helps mitigate the negative impact of covariate shift, leading to improved classification performanceThe accuracy loss drops from 14% to 6% in the worst configuration and from 5% to 4% in the best configuration. This improvement is more pronounced when the shift is larger, i.e., when both the reference and channels change between the control dataset and the test dataset. These findings have significant implications for the development of robust and reliable pBCI models for out-of-the-lab contexts.

title: A Timing-Driven Layout Method Based on Distributed Reinforcement Learning
authors: Minghan Zeng, Xuejun Li, Hongmei Fu, Tao Sun
publish: 2025 18th International Congress on Image and Signal Processing, BioMedical Engineering and Informatics (CISP-BMEI)
abstract: Timing-driven layout faces the formidable challenge of multi-objective optimization [1]. Traditional layout algorithms [2], which prioritize wirelength minimization, inherently suffer from delayed timing path optimization and insufficient accuracy in critical path identification. To address these limitations, this study proposes a distributed deep reinforcement learning architecture that achieves a breakthrough in layout quality through a three-stage innovative mechanism. First, an adaptive grid partitioning strategy based on timing criticality is designed to construct a hierarchical layout decision space. Second, a gradientsharing mechanism across agents is introduced to effectively address the policy convergence issue under sparse reward conditions. Finally, a dynamic neighborhood communication model is established to achieve the co-evolution of local optimization and global timing constraints. In the ICCAD-2015 benchmark test, this study's method demonstrates significant advantages over DREAMPlace4.0: the total negative slack (TNS) is optimized by 12.39%, the worst negative slack (WNS) is improved by 1.66%, and the runtime is reduced by 26.71%. The experimental results indicate that the distributed collaborative learning mechanism can effectively break through the bottleneck in solution space exploration efficiency inherent in traditional single-agent reinforcement learning.

title: High-Density MEA Reveals Distinct Sharp-Wave Ripple Network Dynamics Across Induction Methods in the Hippocampus
authors: Shahrukh Khanzada, Xin Hu, Brett Addison Emery, Hayder Amin
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Learning and memory are fundamental brain functions governed by rhythmic oscillatory activity, which synchronizes neural communication and modulates network dynamics. Distinct oscillatory patterns—theta (θ), beta (β), gamma (γ), and sharp wave-ripples (SWR)—coordinate neural ensemble activity, particularly in the hippocampal CA1-CA3 regions, where they play a crucial role in learning and memory. Understanding the mechanisms underlying SWR generation is crucial, as these oscillations play a fundamental role in memory consolidation, synaptic plasticity, and cognitive function. Unlike previous small-scale studies that relied on limited electrode coverage, our approach leverages high-density microelectrode arrays (HD-MEAs) to capture SWRs across large-scale hippocampal networks. This enables a direct comparison of how different induction methods influence network-wide dynamics, rather than focusing on isolated neuronal activity. By quantitatively assessing spatiotemporal propagation, frequency distributions, and ensemble synchronization, we aim to determine whether experimentally evoked SWRs truly replicate the functional characteristics of their spontaneous counterparts or introduce distinct network properties. Our findings provide a critical foundation for interpreting SWR activity in both physiological and experimental settings, offering novel insights into large-scale neural dynamics and their implications for memory-related processes and therapeutic interventions.

title: The Role of Information Technology in Enhancing Sales Revenues of Smartphone Companies
authors: Shayma Al-Aqabi, Hasna Al-Moussawi
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Business Analytics for Technology and Security (ICBATS)
abstract: the objective of the research is to examine the impact of information technology on the revenue generation of smartphone companies. The issue was defined as the manner in which information technology can be effectively deployed to enhance sales revenues of smartphone companies and how to optimize the use of IT technologies, including artificial intelligence, big data analysis, and digital marketing, to achieve revenue growth in the context of competitive challenges. The research proposes a number of hypotheses, including the assertion that information technology applications exert a positive influence on the sales of smartphone companies. Additionally, the research sought to present a comprehensive overview of the ways in which information technology can be leveraged to enhance operational efficiency and facilitate market expansion. In the applied aspect of the research, the two researchers employed a questionnaire form comprising two axes, the results of which were analyzed using the SPSS program. The research yielded a number of significant conclusions, including the development of technology and its impact on revenue generation. The role of technology in developing and improving smartphones has been demonstrated, resulting in increased demand and revenues. Furthermore, additional research was conducted.

title: The Fifth Main Dynamic Factor: Skin Temperature and Its Effects on EMG-Based Gesture Recognition
authors: Etienne Michaud, Xavier Isabel, Evan Campbell, Raphaël Paradis, Dylan Renaud, Ulysse Côté-Allard, Benoit Gosselin
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Surface electromyography (sEMG) has become a cornerstone for gesture recognition in prosthetic control and human–machine interfaces. However, its performance is often compromised by several dynamic factors, including gesture intensity, limb position, electrode shift, and signal non-stationarities. This work introduces and investigates skin temperature as the "fifth" dynamic factor influencing sEMG-based gesture recognition. Synchronized sEMG, photoplethys-mography (PPG), and inertial measurement unit (IMU) data were recorded from 12 participants without limb differences performing five hand/wrist gestures under three temperature conditions (cold, baseline, and hot) using the BioPoint wearable device. Analysis revealed that cold conditions increased the mean absolute value and reduced the median frequency of sEMG signals, while the signal’s complexity (assessed via fuzzy entropy) remained largely unchanged. Gesture recognition models trained exclusively on baseline data showed a decline in accuracy when tested on non-baseline temperature conditions. In contrast, training with temperature-diverse data improved classification robustness across thermal conditions, albeit at the cost of baseline performance. Furthermore, while a multisensor approach combining EMG, PPG, and IMU data enhanced baseline accuracy, it also demonstrated heightened sensitivity to temperature variations. These findings underscore the necessity for skin temperature-aware strategies for the development of robust sEMG-based gesture recognition systems. Additionally, we introduce a novel hand gesture dataset collected under varying skin temperature conditions to support future research on developing more adaptive and reliable gesture recognition solutions.

title: Novel Dynamic Inverter Control Mechanism for Reliable Solar-PV Energy Access in Weak Rural Grids
authors: Gajendra Singh Chawda, Wencong Su, Mengqi Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: This research proposes a decentralized photovoltaic (PV) system specifically designed for low-income rural communities, addressing both household and agricultural energy needs within weak electrical grids (Short Circuit Ratio < 3 and X/ R ≥ 10). The system features a 12-panel PV array delivering 5 kW, managed through a two-stage power conversion process comprising a boost DC-DC converter and a single-phase DC-AC inverter. This setup converts 250 V DC to 240/120 V AC for grid and household integration while maintaining a stable 400 V DC link. A novel Dynamic Duty Cycle Adjustment mechanism enhances the Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) algorithm by dynamically adjusting to sudden irradiance changes, improving tracking performance, and avoiding local maxima traps, particularly under partial shading conditions. Additionally, a novel dq-frame with a fractional order-based dynamic PI anti-windup (FO-DPI-AW) mechanism stabilizes the system during grid disturbances and load fluctuations, which are common in rural settings. The proposed system meets IEEE power quality (PQ) standards, ensuring voltage regulation within ±5 % and achieving over 96% PV utilization even under load fluctuations. This affordable and scalable solution minimizes reliance on diesel generators and centralized grids, presenting a sustainable pathway to rural electrification.

title: Development of a Bioimpedance Probe for Enhanced Tissue Identification in the Upper Aerodigestive Tract
authors: Marianne Viola Petersen, Thiusius Rajeeth Savarimuthu, Zhuoqi Cheng
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Upper Aerodigestive Tract (UADT) cancers are prevalent, and often fatal, due to late diagnosis. Like many other biological tissues, UADT tissue consists of multiple layers, with cancer commonly developing in the epithelial layer, before spreading to deeper structures. Accurate identification of each layer can aid in early diagnosis, resulting in improved treatment outcomes. This study presents a bioimpedance sensing probe with optimized electrode placement for diagnosis of UADT cancers. The probe, designed to fit a laryngoscope’s working channel, is equipped with four electrodes, allowing for a total of 12 impedance measurements. To determine the electrode position on the probe, a novel optimization method is used to increase the difference between sensitivity distributions for different measurements. Experiments performed using simulation validate the probe’s effectiveness in retrieving more information to be used for tissue identification, demonstrating its potential for real-time, on-site cancer detection.

title: Performance Evaluation of Heat-Pipe-Based Thermal Management System for a 250 kW GaN-Based Integrated Modular Motor Drive
authors: Seyed Iman Hosseini Sabzevari, Salar Koushan, Armin Ebrahimian, Nathan Weise, Ayman EL-Refaie
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: Heat pipes are effective passive devices for transferring heat, enabling physical separation between the heat extraction and heat rejection units. This separation can reduce the overall weight of the cooling system, which is particularly beneficial in high-power-density applications such as aviation electrification, where integrated motor designs are preferred. This paper evaluates a heat-pipe-based thermal management system (TMS) designed for a 250 kW integrated modular motor drive (IMMD), with a focus on the performance of the condenser chamber. The condenser chamber design was analyzed using ANSYS Fluent, where CFD simulations were used to optimize coolant flow distribution and enhance thermal contact between the heat pipes and the working fluid. The CFD results were validated experimentally by testing three different condenser chamber designs under DC current mode. The improved design resulted in a reduction of approximately 4.5 °C in the GaN device junction temperature compared to the baseline configuration.

title: Novel Compensation Topology for IPT System in V2G Applications Using Switched Controlled Capacitors
authors: Yeongseon Lee, Seungmin Kim, Seungjin Jo, Seungsoo Kim, Gwang-Su Park, Dong-Hee Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel compensation topology for inductive power transfer (IPT) systems considering vehicle-to-grid (V2G) operation. During V2G operation, maintaining power quality supplied to the grid is critical. However, the conventional double-sided LCC topology in EV IPT systems has a constant current (CC) characteristic, making it difficult to maintain the DC link voltage as the battery state of charge decreases. To solve this limitation, this paper presents a new topology utilizing a switched controlled capacitor (SCC). The proposed topology modifies the resonant network configuration through the SCC, enabling both CC and constant voltage (CV) outputs. Additionally, the system can operate efficiently through zero phase angle operation and zero voltage switching. To validate the feasibility of the proposed design, a 3.3 kW prototype was developed. The experimental results demonstrated that the proposed system achieves both CC and CV operations, delivering power with a maximum efficiency of 93.42%.

authors: Arindam Sircar, Xiu Yao
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: Ga<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> is an ultrawide bandgap material with the potential to replace SiC in Power Electronic applications. It is inherently designed to support double-side cooling.
