This study proposes a novel integrated structure for bidirectional inductive power transfer (BIPT) system and LVB chargers. Specifically, by sharing the resonant and switching components of the IPT converter with the existing LVB charger, proposed structure achieves highly efficient integrated charging. To validate the feasibility of the proposed structure, simulations were conducted and a 3.3 kW-class BIPT prototype was developed. Experimental results successfully demonstrated 3.3 kW bidirectional HVB operation mode. These findings are expected to significantly contribute to the miniaturization and cost-effectiveness of electric vehicle charging systems.

title: RSCNet: A Rhythmic Supervised Contrastive Network for Motor Imagery EEG Decoding
authors: Jialing Huang, Guoqing Cai, Ting Ma
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Numerous studies have underscored the crucial role of rhythmic components in decoding motor imagery electroencephalogram (MI-EEG) signals. However, most existing approaches rely on generic convolutional operations to process broadband EEG signals, neglecting critical rhythm-specific spatiotemporal features and cross-rhythm coupling dynamics. To address these limitations, we propose the Rhythm Supervised Contrastive Network (RSCNet) for enhanced MI-EEG decoding. Specifically, we introduce a rhythm encoder inspired by neural oscillatory mechanisms to extract rhythm-specific information, combined with a pointwise convolutional structure to capture rhythm coupling features. Additionally, we propose a novel hybrid-loss classifier that leverages supervised contrastive learning to strengthen rhythm coupling features and utilize cross-entropy loss for classification. Experimental results demonstrate that RSCNet significantly outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of classification accuracy and kappa coefficient. Notably, RSCNet achieves a 3.86% improvement in classification accuracy over existing methods in multi-class tasks.

title: Nonlinear Design Scaling of Electric Machines Based on Hybrid DE and Meta-Modeling-Application to Synchronous Motors with Combined PM Stator and Reluctance Rotor Excitation
authors: Oluwaseun A. Badewa, Dan M. Ionel
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: This paper presents an innovative method for nonlinear scaling of electric machines by integrating machine learning (ML)-based meta-modeling with a differential evolution (DE) algorithm. The technique is applied to high-performance combined-excitation synchronous electric motors which exhibit highly nonlinear characteristics, making performance scaling challenging. The proposed approach employs an ML meta-model trained on data obtained from finite element analysis (FEA), utilizing an experimentally validated model for nonlinear scaling and performance prediction at different power ratings. The accuracy of the meta-model in capturing the nonlinear relationships between design parameters and motor performance is first assessed using metrics such as R-squared (R2) and normalized root mean square error (NRMSE) prior to nonlinear scaling. The scaled results are then compared with those obtained from finite element analysis (FEA), demonstrating good correlation within acceptable tolerances. This hybrid ML-DE approach aims to provide a robust and resource-efficient method for electric motor design, optimization, and performance estimation.

title:
A Framework for Assessing the 2
                    <sup>nd</sup>
                    Life Potential of End-of-Life Electric Vehicle Power Electronics for a More Circular Economy
authors: Olayiwola Alatise, Jose Ortiz-Gonzalez, Saeed Jahdi, Burhan Etoz, Arkadeep Deb
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: This study proposes a framework for assessing the usability of end-of-life automotive traction converters for stationary applications like grid-tied inverters in micro-grids. This is especially important in low-income countries where the cost of new components may be prohibitive. Studies like this are already at advanced stages for Electric Vehicle (EV) batteries, however, very few exist for power electronic converters. Repurposing power converters for stationary applications can also address the problem of electronic-waste from end-of-life EVs. Power converters used in automotive traction applications undergo a thermo-mechanical mission profile that results in packaging degradation which is manifested as an increase in the thermal impedance of the package due to die-attach delamination, solder voiding and/or base-plate degradation. It is customary to consider a module with 20% higher thermal impedance as no longer useable due to reduced energy conversion efficiency from higher junction temperatures. However, these converters may still be capable of service under de-rated conditions. This paper proposes a method through which 2<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">nd</sup> life usability can be assessed.

title: Monitoring of Medium Voltage Switchgear Using Dedicated High Technological Sensors
authors: Caia Mihnea, Mihai Andrușcă, Maricel Adam, Alin Dragomir, Beatris Natalina Ghiujan, Adrian Anton
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromechanical and Energy Systems (SIELMEN)
abstract: This paper presents a monitoring system for air-insulated medium-voltage switchgear (AIS) that uses high-technology sensors such as LEM current sensors and surface acoustic wave (SAW) sensors. The solution enhances the reliability of electrical distribution by enabling continuous condition tracking, fault detection, and local data logging through a LabVIEW interface. Built on a hardware and software platform for monitoring, the system provides a scalable and cost-effective approach that increases safety, minimizes downtime, and is validated through a performance evaluation.

title: ActiveSSF: An Active-Learning-Guided Self-Supervised Framework for Long-Tailed Megakaryocyte Classification
authors: Linghao Zhuang, Ying Zhang, Gege Yuan, Xingyue Zhao, Zhiping Jiang
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Precise classification of megakaryocytes is crucial for diagnosing myelodysplastic syndromes. Although self-supervised learning has shown promise in medical image analysis, its application to classifying megakaryocytes in stained slides faces three main challenges: (1) pervasive background noise that obscures cellular details, (2) a long-tailed distribution that limits data for rare subtypes, and (3) complex morphological variations leading to high intra-class variability. To address these issues, we propose the ActiveSSF framework, which integrates active learning with self-supervised pretraining. Specifically, our approach employs Gaussian filtering combined with K-means clustering and HSV analysis (augmented by clinical prior knowledge) for accurate region-of-interest extraction; an adaptive sample selection mechanism that dynamically adjusts similarity thresholds to mitigate class imbalance; and prototype clustering on labeled samples to overcome morphological complexity. Experimental results on clinical megakaryocyte datasets demonstrate that ActiveSSF not only achieves state-of-the-art performance but also significantly improves recognition accuracy for rare subtypes. Moreover, the integration of these advanced techniques further underscores the practical potential of ActiveSSF in clinical settings.

title: Real-Time Instance Segmentation via Frequency Domain and Hierarchical Feature Fusion
authors: Ruixiang Deng, Jingkai Shang, Kairun Tan, Haozheng Bai, Yang Hu, Wuqiang Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Imaging Systems and Techniques (IST)
abstract: Accurately locating object instances and generating precise segmentation masks remains a major challenge in complex, real-world environments due to occlusions, cluttered scenes, and scale variations. In this work, we propose FRISNET, a fast and real-time instance segmentation network that effectively fuses frequency-domain and spatial-domain representations to enhance both semantic understanding and spatial precision. Building upon the YOLACT framework-the current speed benchmark in singlestage instance segmentation-we incorporate a 2D Fast Fourier Transform (FFT)-based module to extract and isolate low- and high-frequency components from feature maps. These frequency-domain features are then reintegrated with spatialdomain representations to capture both global context and finegrained details. Additionally, we enhance the standard Feature Pyramid Network (FPN) by introducing a novel bottom-up pathway and same-level skip connections, which reinforce multi-scale feature representation and preserve high-resolution spatial information. FRISNET is trained and evaluated on two widely used benchmarks: PASCAL Segmentation Boundary Detection (PASCAL SBD) and Microsoft COCO. Experimental results demonstrate that FRISNET achieves a mean Average Precision (mAP) of 34.5 at 31.8 FPS on MS COCO, outperforming YOLACT++ with a ResNet-50 backbone by $1.17 \% \mathrm{mAP}$. Its superior accuracy-speed trade-off makes FRISNET particularly suitable for time-critical applications, such as robotic motion planning and tactile-sensor-assisted object grasping in unstructured environments.

title: Current Situation and Inspiration of Risk Management in Foreign Aerospace Systems
authors: Dongliang Liu, Zixia Zheng, Yalong Wang, Yang Gao
publish: 2024 15th International Conference on Reliability, Maintenance and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: The risk management of aerospace systems has the characteristics of high complexity, high risk, long cycle, and high cost. Scientific, systematic, and comprehensive risk management methods need to be adopted to ensure the safety and stability of aerospace systems. This article summarizes the characteristics of risk management standardization, systematization, quantification, and technicalization in foreign aerospace systems through research and application status of risk management in foreign institutions such as the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), the Department of Defense (DoD), the European Space Agency (ESA), and the International Organization for Standardization (ISO). It has important reference significance for the development of risk management in China’s aerospace models.

title: Application of Augmented Reality (AR) and Virtual Reality (VR) in the Tourism Industry Based on People's Experience
authors: Jessie R. Balbin, Benjie T. Guiwo, Coleen Cate P. Francisco, Ryu P. Valiente, Angela Gian B. Junio, Rohn Miguel Y. Fonbuena, Juliana Diane A. Tanhueco
publish: 2024 IEEE 16th International Conference on Humanoid, Nanotechnology, Information Technology, Communication and Control, Environment, and Management (HNICEM)
abstract: This study explores the integration of Augmented Reality (AR) and Virtual Reality (VR) technologies within the tourism industry, focusing on user experiences and perceptions. By analyzing various case studies and user feedback, the research highlights how AR and VR enhance tourist engagement, provide immersive experiences, and offer innovative solutions for destination marketing. The findings suggest that these technologies enrich the visitor experience and present new opportunities for tourism businesses to differentiate themselves in a competitive market. The study concludes with recommendations for effectively implementing AR and VR to maximize their potential benefits in the tourism sector.

title: A New Hybrid Approach for Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip Detection Utilizing Artificial Intelligence
authors: Ziyad Khalaf Farej, Zuhal Maher MohammedSami
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Business Analytics for Technology and Security (ICBATS)
abstract: Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH) is a congenital or developmental case where the hip joint does not form correctly causing misalignment between the femoral head and the acetabulum. Early diagnosis via X-ray imaging utilizing digital radiography detection systems has an important role for DDH diagnosis and prevents complications or mobility issues and according to 2024 statistics of registered disabled people at Nineveh Center for Rehabilitation of Disabled 1582 cases of complications and 285 mobility issues resulted from misdiagnosis and delay diagnosis of DDH. This manuscript introduces a new approach for detecting DDH from X-ray images by integrating Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) with traditional image processing techniques to get superior classification performance. Radiography images are processed to get high-quality image resizing, reduce noise, enhance brightness and contrast, enhance edges while keeping fine details and making noise low by adaptive adjusting and eliminate artifact elements. These preprocessing steps improve feature extraction for CNN analysis and image classification. A real pelvic dataset comprising 2824 cases, which plays an important role in the classification of DDH, are used from hospitals in Mosul. The dataset contains two classes (DDH and normal) of images derived from digital radiography detection systems for different patients of varying genders and ages from six months to eight years. DDH Diagnosis using a Convolutional Neural Network (DDHCNN) combined with traditional image processing techniques to create hybrid model which obtain an exceptional accuracy of 99.88%, outperforming the DDHCNN model which has 98.58% accuracy without image processing. So the enhanced accuracy highlights the critical role of image enhancement in improving diagnostic reliability. Although there were challenges in collecting a real dataset for DDH but this hybrid model is a great step toward establishing an enhanced DDH detection paving the way for improved healthcare interventions, sustainable healthcare principles and telemedicine applications.

title: An Exploring Systematic Review Deep Learning Techniques for Autism Spectrum Disorder Diagnosis Based on MRI Information
authors: Nayif Mohammed Hammash, Mohammed Chachan Younis
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Business Analytics for Technology and Security (ICBATS)
abstract: Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) stands as one of the most complicated neurological and developmental brain disease disorders because it cannot be diagnosed through clinical means. Traditional ASD diagnosis relies on behavioral patient observation together with family interview assessments. These traditional diagnostic methods are slow and based on symptoms while sometimes producing incorrect results during diagnosis. The MRI machine brought a medical revolution to neuroscience by transforming brain disease diagnosis. Through this technology scientists can visualize information about human brain structure and function. analyses New MRI automatic image methods have been introduced in ASD recent diagnosis. years This based review on paper machine focuses learning on or the deep learning models approaches that and models that used sMRI or fMRI information for the purpose of ASD detection. The search strategy resulted in 68 studies which guided the reporting of these findings. Different features were extracted as inputs for the Deep learning-based approach from the eligible studies. This paper reviews and discusses wellknown MRI datasets which include sMRI and fMRI images of Autism patients. The paper discusses both the benefits of deep learning and preprocessing methods for ASD individual classification. The paper concludes by discussing the obstacles encountered during ASD automated detection and classification and validation processes. The research findings present value to researchers and therapists as well as psychologists and stakeholders for enhancing ASD screening and diagnostic and monitoring practices through deep learning approaches with sMRI or fMRI data or combined data.

title: Drone-Based Depth-Specific Water Sampling Device
authors: Jeanette C. Pao, Immanuel P. Paradela, Irish Mae G. Lariosa, Carl John O. Salaan
publish: 2024 IEEE 16th International Conference on Humanoid, Nanotechnology, Information Technology, Communication and Control, Environment, and Management (HNICEM)
abstract: One of the most important processes in environmental monitoring and assessment is water sampling. In order to assess the quality and composition of water bodies, this procedure entails the methodical collection of water samples from a variety of sources, such as rivers, lakes, groundwater, and wastewater. Conventional water sampling method includes on-site sampling at different depth levels using spot bottles. This method can be labor-intensive and risky especially for dangerous and inaccessible areas. Using drones with water sampling equipment has proven to be an effective way to deal with these problems. This study focuses the development of drone-based depth-specific water sampling system featuring depth sensor as sampler's auto-lock activator. Water quality indicators are introduced and designed a system for integrating turbidity, pH, and temperature sensors with the depth-specific water sampling device of 530 mL sample capacity. The device was tested with the actual drone operation. The auto-lock mechanism of the water sampler effectively activated, enabling sample collection at a depth of 3.5 meters.

title: Winding Comparison of Symmetrical Dual-Three Phase PMSMs with PWM Carrier Phase Shift considering Leakage Inductance
authors: Ye-Na Bai, Seung-Hun Lee, So-Yeon Im, Hyun-Jeong Hong, Myung-Seop Lim
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: Torque ripple and acoustic vibration in dual three-phase drives can be mitigated by introducing a carrier-phase shift between the two inverters (CPS-PWM). Although this scheme suppresses torque ripples, it also amplifies high-frequency current ripple because the two winding sets are magnetically coupled through their leakage inductance <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$L_{ls}$</tex>; the resulting rise in copper and iron losses can negate the expected benefits. This work quantifies the influence of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$L_{ls}$</tex> on CPS-PWM performance. An analytical model is first developed to link <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$L_{ls}$</tex> to the switching-ripple components of the phase currents. The model is then validated by time-domain simulation and finite-element analysis using three winding layouts that provide low, medium, and high leakage inductance. Results show that a larger <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$L_{ls}$</tex> markedly reduces PWM-induced current ripple, yielding the smallest torque ripple and almost no efficiency penalty, whereas a very small <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$L_{ls}$</tex> can increase both torque ripple and total loss. The study thus offers clear design guidance for selecting winding configurations when CPS-PWM is applied in dual three-phase machines.

title: Ripple Compensator Circuit for LCL Voltage-Controlled PHIL PMSM Emulation
authors: Nícolas Baschera, Marco Di Benedetto, Alessandro Lidozzi, Luca Solero
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: Traditional machine test benches are often characterized by their lack of flexibility, safety concerns, substantial weight, and high costs. To address these limitations, Power Hardware-In-the-Loop (PHIL) has emerged as an advanced technique for testing and validating control algorithms and hardware in Variable Speed Drives (VSDs) for electrical machines. This paper explores the application of PHIL for the emulation of a Permanent Magnet Synchronous Machine (PMSM). This paper proposes the integration of a Ripple Compensator circuit as a key enhancement to the LCL voltage-controlled PHIL system for PMSM emulation. The Ripple Compensator works in conjunction with the LCL coupling network to improve emulation accuracy, ensuring better system performance. This approach reinforces the effectiveness of PHIL as a flexible and safe alternative to traditional machine test benches.

title: 3 kV-Class Scalable SCR-Based Solid State Circuit Breaker
authors: Marcio L. Magri Kimpara, Rajendra Prasad Kandula, Elvey T. Andrade
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: In this paper, a scalable solid-state circuit breaker based on silicon-controlled rectifiers (SCRs) is presented for medium-voltage DC (MVDC) applications. To address the voltage scalability, two different approaches are investigated: i) a topology based on simultaneous operation of series-connected SCRs and ii) a modular configuration consisting of a series connection of two building blocks based on SCR devices. Both solutions feature fast current interruption time thanks to the optimally designed auxiliary commutation circuit, based on the device characteristics. Simulation analyses are presented, and experimental validation was successfully conducted on 3 kV-class prototypes, confirming the designed operating behavior of each proposed solution and demonstrating effective current interruption times below 60 μs.

title: Multiscale Temporal Dependency-based Transfer Learning with Degradation Stage Calibration for Remaining Useful Life Prediction of Energy Systems
authors: Xuefei Xu, Wei Qiao, Liyan Qu
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: Remaining useful life (RUL) prediction plays a critical role in predictive maintenance for energy systems. The real-world run-to-failure condition monitoring data is often collected from varying operating conditions, which leads to domain shifts between datasets and unsatisfactory performance when using these datasets for RUL prediction. Besides, most of the existing RUL prediction methods are inadequate to capture intricate and multidimensional features of degradation processes. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a Stage-Calibrated Multiscale Temporal dependency-based Transfer Learning (SCMTTL) model to predict the RUL of energy systems with varying operating conditions. The SCMTTL model captures both short-term and long-term dependencies of monitoring data while effectively integrating system degradation stage information to enhance RUL prediction accuracy.

title: Data Augmentation with Fine-Tuning Strategy for Enhanced Myoelectric Pattern Recognition Using Deep Learning
authors: Anyuan Zhang, Ying He, Haowen Zheng, Qunchao Lu
publish: 2025 18th International Congress on Image and Signal Processing, BioMedical Engineering and Informatics (CISP-BMEI)
abstract: The performance of myoelectric pattern recognition is significantly affected by electrode shifting. Although data augmentation methods based on traditional convolutional neural network (CNN) aims to address this issue, their effectiveness remains limited due to suboptimal utilization of temporal information and variability in data distribution. To further enhance the effectiveness of data augmentation, we developed a convolutional neural network-long short-term memory (CNN-LSTM) model combined with a fine-tuning strategy. To validate this approach, we classified surface electromyography (sEMG) signals from 10 subjects in the Ninapro DB5 dataset performing six distinct movements. We compared the classification accuracy of the proposed method with three baseline approaches: CNN, CNN with a multi-head attention mechanism, and CNN-LSTM with a multi-head attention mechanism. These methods were evaluated under five experimental scenarios: (1) no electrode shifting, (2) electrode shifting, (3) electrode shifting with data augmentation, (4) electrode shifting with fine-tuning, and (5) electrode shifting with both data augmentation and fine-tuning. The results show that the proposed method achieved significantly higher classification accuracy compared with the other three methods under electrode shifting with data augmentation and fine-tuning (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{p}<0.05$</tex>). The classification accuracy of electrode shifting with data augmentation and finetuning was also significantly higher than the accuracy of electrode shifting with fine-tuning alone <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(p<0.05)$</tex>. The proposed method can further enhance data augmentation performance by improving the utilization of temporal signal information and reducing data distribution discrepancies.

title: Biochemical Oscillations in HeLa Cells: Automated Time-Lapse Image Analysis and Two-Step Parameter Estimation
authors: Satya Deepika Neelapala, Suman Gare, Vaibhav Dhyani, Kishalay Mitra, Soumya Jana, Lopamudra Giri
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: In recent times, single-cell analysis from time-lapse imaging has been used to characterize distinct subpopulations of a complex heterogeneous cell system. This can offer significant insights leading to robust cancer treatment strategies. In particular, calcium imaging may have significance since the pattern in oscillation may encode the cell state. Although model fitting to single-cell dynamics is pivotal, the analysis remains time consuming due to manual segmentation from time-lapse microscopic images. Secondly, the parameter estimation for the nonlinear system of differential equations (ODEs) describing these oscillations remains challenging due to the massive search space and the presence of multiple local minima in the objective function. To address these problems,firstly, we propose a computer vision algorithm (YOLOv9) to automatically extract calcium signals from the live cell imaging video dataset. Next, we implemented a two-step approach that combines Monte Carlo simulations (MC) and Genetic algorithm (GA) for parameter estimation. The first step (MC), was used to narrow down the search space and find the best performing upper and lower bounds for GA. In the second step, we implemented GA to determine the optimized parameters for the nonlinear model. Monte Carlo sampling along with GA shows significant reduction in KL divergence compared to only GA. We have also presented multiple simulations for the stochastic version of the model using the estimated parameters. The proposed pipeline shows significant promise for understanding the underlying cell states.

title: Impact of 0.8 kV Inverters on AC Losses in a 2.2 MW PV Plant
authors: Rotari Iulian, Tverdohleb Ala
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromechanical and Energy Systems (SIELMEN)
abstract: The efficiency of photovoltaic (PV) power plants is critically influenced by power losses occurring during energy conversion and transmission, particularly within alternating current (AC) components. This study addresses the challenge of quantifying and minimizing these losses by focusing on PV system configurations that utilize inverters with an output voltage of 0.8 kV—a relatively high level for low-voltage applications. The primary objective is to analyze the distribution of active and reactive power losses across key AC elements, including low-voltage cables, medium-voltage cables, and transformers, and to evaluate the impact of inverter voltage on overall system performance. Through analytical modeling and simulation under varying operational scenarios, the research demonstrates that systems operating at 0.8 kV and unity power factor achieve the lowest total active power losses across internal AC components and grid connection lines. Although external line losses slightly increase due to higher grid injection levels, the total system losses are significantly lower than those observed in conventional 0.4 kV configurations—resulting in a reduction of 53.79 kW in active losses and approximately 13 kVAr in reactive losses at full capacity for a 2.2 MW installation. Structural analysis reveals that internal losses are predominantly concentrated in low-voltage cable lines 65-68%, followed by transformers (29-31%) and internal 10 kV cabling (3-4%).

title: Real-Time Control of an Arm-Type Robot Using Electromyographic Inputs
authors: Andrei Popa, Florin-Gheorghiţă Horgot, Marian-Silviu Poboroniuc
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromechanical and Energy Systems (SIELMEN)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of a robotic arm control system based on electromyographic (EMG) signals. The project integrates Myo v1.5 surface EMG sensors, an Arduino microcontroller, and a Lynxmotion AL5D robotic arm, managed through MATLAB. EMG signals, generated by voluntary muscle contractions, are acquired from the forearm flexor muscles and the biceps, filtered, digitized, and classified into discrete states that command robotic movements. These specific muscle groups were selected for their accessibility and clear activation during common upper limb gestures. The system architecture supports real-time interaction between human intent and robotic execution. The proposed solution demonstrates that even minimal muscle activity can be harnessed to control assistive devices, enhancing autonomy and improving the quality of life for individuals with motor disabilities.

title: Characterization of the Fast Interactions Between Mean Cerebral Blood Flow and Brain Activity in Healthy Subjects
authors: Beatrice Cairo, Vincenzo Catrambone, Vlasta Bari, Pavandeep Singh, Beatrice De Maria, Gaetano Valenza, Alberto Porta
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Cerebral vasomotion is modulated according to brain demands via neurovascular coupling (NVC). NVC can be evaluated noninvasively via the simultaneous recording of electroencephalogram (EEG) and mean cerebral blood velocity (MCBv) monitored via transcranial Doppler (TCD) device. We propose an approach for NVC estimation grounded on the assessment of the cross-correlation at zero lag between the beat-to-beat variability series of MCBv and EEG power assessed over typical frequency bands utilized in EEG analysis, namely δ, θ, α and β bands. A surrogate data approach was applied to test the null hypothesis of the absence of NVC. This methodology was tested in 20 right-handed healthy volunteers (9 males, 11 females; age: 31±4 yrs) in which MCBv was monitored via TCD device along with a 19-channel EEG. Recordings were performed at rest in supine position (REST) and during active standing (STAND). We found that the strength of NVC varies with frequency band, experimental condition and brain region. More specifically, NVC strength was significant at REST especially in the δ and α bands and in the occipital and parietal regions, while it was much weaker during STAND, especially in those brain areas where NVC was particularly strong at REST. This novel approach to the NVC characterization highlights the complexity of the interactions between cerebral vasomotion and brain activity even in absence of a definite cognitive task.

title: Neuro-computational modelling of closed-loop prostheses control
authors: Leonardo Nacci, Vittorio Sanguineti, Strahinja Dosen
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Despite advancements in myoelectric control of upper-limb prostheses, their use remains challenging and the rejection rates are still high. One step towards improving the human-prosthesis interfacing is to implement artificial sensory feedback as this can improve performance and user experience. While some late-generation prostheses incorporate supplementary feedback, there is still a lack of a principled method to investigate the impact of feedback and evaluate its effectiveness. In this study, we focused on how the subjects learn to operate an upper-limb prosthesis to control the grip force in a grasping task under visual control. We manipulated target grip force, and sensory and motor noise and investigated how these factors affected control performance. To interpret the empirical findings, we developed a computational model in which learning is described as the gradual acquisition of an internal representation of the prosthesis transfer function. The experimental data were collected in 20 non-disabled subjects and the results showed that the precision of control decreased with the increase in the target force and the level of motor noise, whereas the sensory noise did not have a significant impact. The model qualitatively reproduced the main experimental findings, in particular the dependence of performance on motor noise magnitude. The developed model is the first promising step towards capturing the behavior of prosthesis user and developing a more comprehensive understanding of the interaction between the different factors governing closed-loop prosthesis control.

title: WAveHCT: Wavelet-Attentive Hybrid Convolution-Transformer Network for Breast Cancer Diagnosis in Ultrasound Images
authors: Arita Halder, Manjunatha Mahadevappa
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Breast cancer diagnosis using ultrasound imaging remains challenging due to noise, variability in lesion appearance, and several artifacts. To address these concerns, this study proposes WAveHCT, a Wavelet-Attentive Hybrid Convolution-Transformer Network that uses wavelet decomposition and a hybrid architecture to diagnose breast cancers in ultrasound images. The proposed approach begins by applying anisotropic diffusion filtering to the ultrasound images, effectively reducing noise while preserving edge details. A ResNet50-based encoder backbone is then used to extract features from the wavelet-decomposed and anisotropic diffusion-filtered images. These features are integrated using a novel Wavelet-Attentive Feature Fusion (WAFF) module, enabling improved diagnostic performance. Further, the study introduces a hybrid block with convolutional and transformer layers. The transformer layers effectively capture global dependencies, while convolution operations preserve local feature representations. WAveHCT demonstrated superior accuracy, recall, F1-score, and AUC compared to existing methods. Heatmaps generated by WAveHCT exhibited improved localization of clinically relevant features, emphasizing its potential to assist radiologists in diagnosing breast cancers.Clinical relevance—Ultrasound imaging is a cost-effective, non-invasive and non-ionizing method of breast cancer screening. Therefore, developing advanced deeplearning-based tools for diagnosing breast cancer using ultrasound images can enhance radiologists’ efficiency and reduce unnecessary invasive biopsies.

title: CNN-Mamba Interaction Fusion Network for Diagnosis Retinopathy of Prematurity
authors: Shaolong Wang, Xinyu Zhao, Zhenquan Wu, Zhen Yu, Guoming Zhang, Tianfu Wang, Baiying Lei
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) manifests clinically through abnormal development of the retinal capillary, ischemia, proliferative retinopathy, and retinal detachment, making it one of the leading causes of childhood blindness. Diagnosis of ROP from images of the full retinal fundus is challenging due to the presence of small peripheral lesions and underdeveloped ocular structures in premature infants. Current methods for fundus image analysis, based on Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and transformers, often struggle to capture long-range dependencies or are limited by the complex computational demands. To address these challenges, we propose a CNN-Mamba interaction fusion network, CMIFNet, for diagnosing ROP. This network consists of a CNN-based branch for local feature extraction and a bidirectional state space model (BSSM) based branch for global information integration. We developed an interactive attention fusion module (IAFM) to enhance feature interaction and facilitate attention-based integration between the two branches. Our approach demonstrates promising recognition performance on a clinical ROP dataset.

title: Heart Rate and Heart Rate Variability as Indicators for Stress and Skill Development in Minimally-Invasive Surgery
authors: Liv Arning, Amir Ebrahimzadeh, Sami Beirami, Nora Friedrich, Michael Ghadimi, Jannis Hagenah
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: The acceptance of surgical assistance systems is highly dependent on their ability to dynamically adapt the level of assistance to the surgeon’s individual needs. The challenge is to assess the skill level across a variety of surgical tasks. Intra-operative stress measurement could present an opportunity for task-independent skill assessment, with the hypothesis that challenging situations lead to higher stress levels. In this paper, we investigate the relationship between physiological and subjective measures of stress and surgical performance in a simulator setting. To this end, we collected heart rate as well as mental load self-assessment data of ten participants during repetitive training sessions of a minimally-invasive surgery curriculum. We explore the training effects on stress levels across different time scales and show a clear relationship between experienced stress and surgical performance. Our results indicate that intra-operative stress assessment could play a key role in designing adaptive surgical assistance systems.Clinical relevance— Our research offers a new approach to allow assistance systems to adapt to the surgeon’s skill level. Thus, it holds the potential to increase the acceptance of these systems, ultimately leading to more reliable clinical outcomes. Furthermore, the collected data provides valuable insights into the relationship between training progress, skill level and stress. This could function as a basis for more advanced surgical training tools

title: Designing Real-Time EEG and ECG Integration for VR-Based Exposure Therapy: A User Study
authors: André Antunes, Joana Cerqueira, Íris Peixoto, Anna Letournel, Rui Neves Madeira
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Innovative therapeutic approaches are crucial to the treatment of anxiety and food aversion disorders. This study integrates EEG and ECG signals with a VR-based serious game for exposure therapy, assessing neurophysiological engagement in a framework designed for real-time integration. Our results demonstrate consistent detection of EEG biomarkers, particularly N200, during VR tasks, providing evidence of neural habituation. While ECG signals faced motion-related artifacts, EEG data reliably captured cognitive adaptation to repeated stimuli, reinforcing the feasibility of real-time neurofeedback. Despite these challenges, our study successfully validates the integration of multimodal biosignals in VR-based exposure therapy, confirming its potential for adaptive, personalized interventions. By leveraging VR’s immersive capabilities with physiological feedback, this approach advances real-time, patient-centered exposure therapy, laying the groundwork for customized therapeutic strategies.

title: Text-to-ECG: a Framework to Generate 12-Lead ECG from Text Reports
authors: Fabrizio Cattozzo, Sara Battiston, Massimo W. Rivolta, Roberto Sassi
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Synthetic electrocardiograms (ECGs), obtained with Generative Artificial Intelligence (GenAI), are currently used to support the training of other AI algorithms, most often decision support systems, by augmenting the dataset for the minority classes. In this study, we proposed a Text-to-ECG (T2ECG) framework, which could generate synthetic ECG beats from textual data. The framework made use of two components. The first, Bio_ClinicalBERT, produced an embedded vector from the input text (e.g., "left ventricular hypertrophy"). Then, a second component leveraged such representation to generate a 12-lead ECG heartbeat by means of a Wasserstein Generative Adversarial Network with gradient penalty. The training was performed on the PTB-XL dataset, freely available on Physionet. The framework was designed to generate five different diagnostic classes: i) normal sinus rhythm; ii) inferior myocardial infarction (IMI); iii) antero-septal myocardial infarction (ASMI); iv) left anterior fascicular block (LAFB); and v) left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH). The realism of the generated signals was assessed through three different methodologies, involving both visual inspection and quantitative analyses. Our results show that the T2ECG framework was able to generate heartbeats of sufficient quality, except for the the ASMI class. In conclusion, the framework proposed does not only support data augmentation but also facilitates the creation of ECGs by non-technical users, offering a textual interface to the GenAI model.

title: Efficiency Enhancement of Dynamic Wireless Power Transfer Considering the Impact of Magnetic Field Reconfiguration
authors: Tianlu Ma, Chen Chen, Yue Liu, Ben Zhang, Jiaqi Huang, C. Q. Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: Dynamic wireless power transfer (DWPT) technology can achieve wireless charging for devices that move, like warehouse robots. Distinguished from the traditional stationary wireless power transfer, the couplings between the receiving (Rx) and transmitting (Tx) coils vary when the receiver moves in DWPT systems, which leads to voltage and current fluctuations on the Rx side. In this paper, the magnetic field reconfiguration (MFR) of the DWPT system is reported first. Namely, the position variation of the receiver changes the magnetic flux loop, which causes the self-inductance variation of Rx and Tx coils. This phenomenon will reduce the system's efficiency. In order to mitigate the impact of MFR, efficiency optimization strategies are proposed, and experiments are conducted to verify the analysis.

title: The Effect of Changes in the Number of People in a VR Environment on Interpersonal Distance
authors: S. Oobayashi, H. Nagata, K. Mizutani
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: With the recent popularization of online interviews, lack of communication has become an issue. By using VR technology, it is expected to duplicate an environment similar to a face-to-face interview and optimize the interview environment with psychological comfort in mind. In this study, we examined the effects of the number of interviewers and types of objects in a VR space on participants' interpersonal distance. In Experiment 1, cardboard, mannequin, and human avatars were presented and participants’ interpersonal distance was investigated. The results showed that participants tended to increase their interpersonal distance as the number of avatars increased. And there was no significant difference in distance between the different types of avatars. In Experiment 2, one to five interviewer objects were presented in a VR conference room to measure the interpersonal distance and psychological load level that participants considered appropriate. The results showed that there was no increase in appropriate distance whether there were one or two interviewers, and that the psychological load was lower with one interviewer than with two. The results suggest that one interviewer is appropriate for counseling, while two interviewers are appropriate for interview practice. This study suggested optimal values for the distance between the interviewer and the interviewee and the number of interviewees participating in the VR interview environment by measuring personal space while measuring the effect of the avatar and number of interviewees on the psychological load level of the participants.Clinical Relevance— Prolonged hospitalization in intensive care units (ICUs) causes rehabilitation difficulties and communication barriers for patients. Creating a interactive rehabilitation environment using VR is expected to contribute to situations where patients with PTSD and trauma are provided with opportunities to gradually learn how to interact with others, as well as to situations where patients with stroke and physical disabilities are rehabilitated in spatial cognition. The distance between the interviewer and the interviewee during an interview affects the smoothness of communication. This study provided insight into the optimal distance between interviewer and interviewee in VR interviews, depending on the number of interviewees participating.

title:
A Synthetic Dataset for in Silico Studies of Parameters Influencing Changes in Mean Arterial Blood Pressure During Hemodialysis
                    <sup>*</sup>
authors: Leszek Pstras, Jacek Waniewski
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Intradialytic hypotension is a major complication of hemodialysis (HD) and is still incompletely understood. Similarly, intradialytic hypertension is also associated with adverse outcomes and increased mortality and also remains not fully elucidated. Here we present and discuss a synthetic dataset (HD-SIM-MAP) with various cases of dialysis-induced changes in mean arterial blood pressure (MAP) simulated using a lumped-parameter model of the cardiovascular system and the whole-body water and solute kinetics in 5,000 virtual patients with randomly adjusted values of 90 physiological parameters. The dataset includes a wide range of intradialytic MAP patterns including both decreases and increases in MAP during HD. The dataset can be used to analyze parameters (or their combinations) affecting the blood pressure response to HD and to investigate mechanisms that may be responsible for hemodynamic instability during HD.Clinical Relevance— Exploration of the presented dataset may help elucidate the mechanisms behind intradialytic hypo- or hypertension.

title: Design of Magnetic Flux Concentrators for NV-Diamond Magnetoencephalography
authors: Tingyu Zhu, Naota Sekiguchi, Yuta Kainuma, Motofumi Fushimi, Takayuki Iwasaki, Mutsuko Hatano, Masaki Sekino
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Nitrogen-vacancy (NV) centers in diamond magnetometers are promising to be used for new magnetoencephalography (MEG) systems. However, the sensitivity of current NV magnetometers is limited for MEG signal detection. In this study, we demonstrate a novel magnetic flux concentrators (MFCs) design with trumpet and cut trumpet geometries for NV magnetometers, allowing MEG measurement. The sensitivity enhancement can be achieved 140 and 110-fold, and the field inhomogeneity can also be improved to 0.02% and 0.35% when using the trumpet and cut trumpet MFCs, respectively.

title: Inhibitory Effects of Individualized Transcranial Alternating Current Stimulation on Motor Imagery and Interhemispheric Symmetry: Implications for Stroke Rehabilitation
authors: Jun Xun Ong, Brian Premchand, Rosary Yuting Lim, Effie Chew, Muyun Jiang, Ning Tang, Kai Keng Ang
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Transcranial alternating current stimulation (tACS) holds potential in stroke rehabilitation, but its effects when delivered at an individual’s peak motor imagery (MI) frequency remain unclear. This study investigated the impact of tACS delivered at subject-specific peak MI frequencies on MI performance accuracy, quantified in terms of classification accuracy, and interhemispheric symmetry, measured via the brain symmetry index (BSI). Using a brain-computer-brain closed-loop system, each subject’s peak MI performance frequency was first identified during the Pre-stimulation phase, after which tACS was delivered at this determined frequency. Our findings show that active individualized tACS decreased MI performance and increased BSI, suggesting inhibitory effects on motor-related neural processes.Clinical Relevance— The observed inhibitory effects of tACS highlight its potential for targeted neuromodulation in stroke recovery. Future research should explore how inhibitory effects can be harnessed therapeutically and investigate stimulation parameters that could optimize outcomes for functional recovery. The demonstrated ability of tACS to modulate brain activity, evidenced by increased BSI, underscores its promise as a neuromodulatory tool in clinical applications.

title: Database Systems Examination and Digital Forensics Tool: The Progress and Limitations
authors: Oluwasola Mary Adedayo
publish: 2025 22nd Annual International Conference on Privacy, Security, and Trust (PST)
abstract: Databases play a critical role in many computing systems and applications and provide an excellent source of information for forensics investigations. Also, with many advances in the digital forensics field, several forensic tools can be employed for different purposes in digital investigations. Despite this, many forensics tools have limitations when it pertains to the collection, examination, or analysis of potential evidence from database management systems due to the inherent complexities of handling different database systems. This is particularly true for free or open-source tools that can be used for research purposes, and this limits the development of new tools and solutions for database forensics. To address this and forge a path for the development of new tools for database forensics, this paper highlights some of the available tools that can be used for database forensics, the limitations of using some of these tools, and the challenges of performing database analysis in general. We achieve this through a practical analysis of the tools and examine their capabilities in terms of supporting the forensics analysis of databases found on digital devices. Given their popularity, we consider databases found on both Android and iPhone devices, as well as other data sources. We integrated an analysis of relevant testing reports from the Computer Forensics Tool Testing (CFTT) program to provide a complete picture of the forensic tools. This paper establishes the aspects where these tools can be improved and provides recommendations for handling some of the challenges associated with the forensics analysis of database systems.

title: Automated In-situ Analysis of Tumor-Associated Macrophage Attachment on Antifouling Polymer Brushes
authors: Volkan Uslan, Ibrahim Onaran, Huseyin Seker, Michael Hirtz, Kristina Riehemann
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Tumor-associated macrophages (TAMs) are critical to tumor progression. Quantifying their interactions with biomaterial surfaces is crucial for developing effective cancer therapies. Traditionally, manual cell counting has been used to assess macrophage adhesion, a labor-intensive and subjective process. To address these limitations and enable unbiased analysis, we developed an automated in-situ system to quantify TAM attachment to antifouling polymer brushes. Bland-Altman analysis indicated a high agreement between our automated method and traditional manual cell counting. For M1 macrophages, the mean difference was less than 4 cells, with limits of agreement (LoA) ranging from -70.18% to 80.16%. For M2 macrophages, the mean difference was 25 cells, with LoA ranging from -51.61% to 72.71%. These results were consistent across different experimental conditions, including Unspecific Binding, Specific Antibody, and IgG Control. Our analysis revealed no systematic differences in cell counts and holds significant potential for point-of-care applications, potentially enhancing personalized treatment strategies.Clinical relevance— This approach could enhance personalized treatment strategies by providing real-time assessment of the tumor microenvironment through minimally invasive liquid biopsies.

title: Porcine Training Models for Image-Guided Transoral Robotic Surgery
authors: Yuan Shi, Sudi Zhao, Joseph A. Paydarfar, Michael A. Kokko, Ryan J. Halter
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Image-guided surgical navigation could potentially improve the accuracy and safety of throat cancer resections in transoral robotic surgery (TORS). However, cost-effective and realistic research and training models for evaluating advancements in this technology remain limited. In this study, we present two porcine models that provide a realistic simulation of anatomic structures, including the tongue, larynx, and pharynx. The efficacy of the training models was evaluated in a series of experiments, in which a previously developed TORS navigation system was employed to guide surgeons in target localization tasks using a da Vinci surgical system.Clinical Relevance— The porcine models presented in this study are cost-effective and realistic research and training tools for assessing advancements in image-guided TORS. These models can be adapted for other ear, nose, and throat (ENT) procedures such as transoral laser microsurgery (TLM).

title: Detection of Suspicious Lesions in Breast MRI: Radiomics Patch-based Granular Classification Approach
authors: Aleksandar Krivokapic, Marija Gijic, Dusan Simonovic, Tatjana Loncar-Turukalo
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: In addition to mammography and ultrasound, breast magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is indicative in a number of cases. Both cost and low reader availability hinder the more common use of MRI. This paper builds on the previously published work on breast region segmentation in MRI and evaluates the possibility of automated detection of suspicious lesions in the breast region using radiomics breast tissue analysis. The processing pipeline assumes regular grid division of breast tissue and characterization of each image patch by radiomics features for further binary classification using Random Forest (RF) and XGBoost to differentiate between suspicious lesions and fibro-glandular tissue. The patch-wise results obtained reveal F1 scores ≥ 0.92, with balanced precision (0.94) and recall (0.95) for different patch sizes. Reassembling patch decisions supports positioning of the identified suspicious breast regions and patient-level decision making.Clinical relevance— With high incidence rates of breast cancer, an automated detection of suspicious lesions in MRI breast scans can offer a valuable support in patient prioritization and clinical decision making, especially in settings with low reader availability.

title: Freezing of Gait Detection Using Gramian Angular Fields and Federated Learning from Wearable Sensors
authors: Shovito Barua Soumma, S M Raihanul Alam, Rudmila Rahman, Umme Niraj Mahi, Abdullah Mamun, Sayyed Mostafa Mostafavi, Hassan Ghasemzadeh
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Freezing of gait (FOG) is a debilitating symptom of Parkinson’s disease that impairs mobility and safety by increasing the risk of falls. An effective FOG detection system must be accurate, real-time, and deployable in free-living environments to enable timely interventions. However, existing detection methods face challenges due to (1) intra-and inter-patient variability, (2) subject-specific training, (3) using multiple sensors in FOG dominant locations (e.g., ankles) leading to high failure points, (4) centralized, non-adaptive learning frameworks that sacrifice patient privacy and prevent collaborative model refinement across populations and disease progression, and (5) most systems are tested in controlled settings, limiting their real-world applicability for continuous in-home monitoring. Addressing these gaps, we present FOGSense, a real-world deployable FOG detection system designed for uncontrolled, free-living conditions using only a single sensor. FOGSense uses Gramian Angular Field (GAF) transformations and privacy-preserving federated deep learning to capture temporal and spatial gait patterns missed by traditional methods with a low false positive rate. We evaluated our system using a public Parkinson’s dataset collected in a free-living environment. FOGSense improves accuracy by 10.4% over a single-axis accelerometer, reduces failure points compared to multi-sensor systems, and demonstrates robustness to missing values. The federated architecture allows personalized model adaptation and efficient smartphone synchronization during off-peak hours, making it effective for long-term monitoring as symptoms evolve. Overall, FOGSense achieved a 22.2% improvement in F1-score and a 74.53% reduction in false positive rate compared to state-of-the-art methods, along with enhanced sensitivity for FOG episode detection, empowering preventive care and long-term symptom management as Parkinson’s progresses. Code is available: https://github.com/shovito66/FOGSense.

title: Active Learning Model for EEG Annotation Driven Jointly by Pseudo-Labels and Manual Annotations
authors: Yijing Long, Jie Lin, Chunnuan Chen, Zhihua Huang
publish: 2025 18th International Congress on Image and Signal Processing, BioMedical Engineering and Informatics (CISP-BMEI)
abstract: Electroencephalogram (EEG) data provides real-time insights into brain functional states, holding significant value in medical diagnostics and neurotechnology. However,expert annotation of EEG signals is costly and time-intensive, limiting the scalability of deep learning models for brain-state classification. While active learning reduces annotation needs by prioritizing informative samples, it neglects unlabeled data; pseudo-labeling leverages unlabeled data but risks label noise. To address these limitations,we propose a hybrid framework integrating active learning with confidence-based pseudo-labeling. The framework operates iteratively through three key steps: 1) Uncertainty sampling selects high-value EEG epochs for expert annotation; 2) High-confidence pseudo-labels are generated for the remaining data; and 3) A Temporal Convolutional Network (TCN) is trained on the combined dataset. The TCN architecture efficiently models EEG temporal dependencies. As a result, our framework significantly outperforms conventional approaches, achieving a 9.75% improvement in accuracy (91.83% vs. 82.08%) and a 24.12% boost in precision with 36% fewer expert-annotated samples. It also yields a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 4. 5 4 \%}$</tex> improvement in F1-score, demonstrating balanced performance across metrics. This synergistic approach provides a cost-effective solution for EEG annotation, facilitating efficient model development for clinical applications.

title: Towards the integration of in-silico electro-chemo-mechanical smooth muscle cell and cardiovascular system models
authors: Nicole Anderton, Francesca Menna, Amin Forouzandehmehr, Joan Duprez, Jose Suihkonen, Virginie Le Rolle, Jussi T Koivumäki, Jari Hyttinen
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Smooth muscle cells (SMCs) are largely responsible for maintaining vascular tone. Their ability to adapt to any local hemodynamic change is thus an integral mechanism of both cardiovascular function and systemic cardiovascular control. However, the exact processes driving smooth muscle cell contraction, and subsequent local and systemic level vascular tone adaptation, to hemodynamic changes are complex and not well understood. This leaves a gap in our understanding and ability to predict and manage cardiovascular disease progression. We aim to begin addressing this knowledge gap by coupling, in-silico, a detailed electro-chemo-mechanical smooth muscle model with a systemic level integrated cardiovascular model that includes a mechanoelectric heart generating the cardiovascular drive, and a detailed circulatory system including the coronary arteries. The system and cell level models are coupled through the flow and pressure profiles obtained from the systemic level driving the muscle force generation. The model behaviors are demonstrated for the cell level control of left main coronary artery in LVOT obstructive and non-obstructive cases for both hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) and non-HCM virtual patients. The pulsatile pressure and flow changes between the obstructive and non-obstructive cases are observed to alter the contractile force of the SMC through Nitric Oxide and stretch driven pathways. A marked difference in vascular tone between the obstructive and non-obstructive cases is observed. Most interestingly, an inverse force response to obstructive pressure and flow is observed in HCM cases. In this work we demonstrate a successful preliminary coupling of arterial smooth muscle cell cardiovascular and systemic level cardiovascular models.

title: Thermal Investigation of SiC Die-Top Layers Under Short-Circuit Operation
authors: Youssef Abotaleb, Ekaterina Muravleva, Jun Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: Short-circuit ruggedness remains a critical challenge in silicon carbide (SiC) power devices, where excessive hot-spot temperatures contribute to device degradation and failure. During a Type-I short circuit lasting several microseconds, the heat flux localized at the top surface of the SiC die cannot dissipate effectively through the substrate, rendering the die-bottom thermal capacitance ineffective. This work investigates increasing die-top thermal capacitance to absorb short-circuit heat flux and reduce hot-spot temperature. It examines both existing alternatives to aluminum metallization and newly proposed materials. State-of-the-art SiC packaging technologies have integrated advanced material solutions. However, existing literature has primarily focused on copper for die-top metallization and has not systematically investigated alternative materials for optimizing short-circuit thermal management. FEA simulation shows that copper/diamond composite is expected to reduce the hot-spot temperature by 35%-40%, outperforming alternative materials significantly. With that, an extension of short-circuit withstand time (SCWT) might be achieved, enabling higher ruggedness and reliability, simpler protection circuit design, and the pursuit of lower specific on-resistance. These findings support the feasibility of material-level thermal optimization as a pathway to improve device ruggedness and simplify protection circuit requirements.

title: A Comprehensive Evaluation of 24 GHz CW Radar for Accurate Breathing and Heart Rate Monitoring
authors: Anaïs Espinoso, Miquel Alfaras, Daniel Romero, Yolanda Castillo-Escario, Raimón Jané, Zouhair Haddi
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: This study evaluates the potential of a 24 GHz continuous-wave (CW) radar for non-contact monitoring of vital signs, including breathing, pulse, and heart sounds. Instantaneous rates extracted from estimated heart sounds and breathing signals showed strong agreement with the reference systems, with a Mean Absolute Error (MAE) of 2.46 beats/min and 0.57 breaths/min, respectively. Additionally, averaged heart rates obtained from radar-derived pulse signals had an MAE of 2.41 beats/min. Then, the analysis of breathing variability revealed that chest movement values are more widely distributed at lower breathing rates. The radar’s ability to detect fine chest displacements associated with vital signs highlights its increased suitability for continuous and unobtrusive cardiorespiratory health monitoring.Clinical relevance—Explore the capabilities and limitations of cardiorespiratory signals extracted from CW radar in healthy subjects to detect instantaneous rates accurately.

title: Efficacy and usability of facial dry-printed electrodes for transocular stimulation
authors: Daniele Re, Rawan Ibrahim, Yael Hanein
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Transorbital electrical stimulation (TES) has emerged as a promising approach for eliciting visual percepts, or phosphenes, in both sighted and visually impaired individuals. However, the utility of these approaches is limited owing to cumbersome setups consisting of wired gel electrodes and the difficulty in optimizing stimulation paradigms. Overall, optimizing transorbital stimulation paradigms, remains a huge challenge, particularly regarding electrode type and waveform characteristics. In this study, we investigated whether the type of electrode (i.e. wet versus dry) affects the psychometric curve for phosphene detection. Our findings indicate that both electrode types yield comparable detection thresholds, suggesting that dry electrodes could offer a viable, practical alternative for TES without compromising efficacy, while dramatically enhancing usability. Building on this, we explored whether temporal interference (TI) stimulation, a technique leveraging high-frequency signals to create a low-frequency envelope at a targeted neural region, could enhance phosphene perception when optimized for the posterior retina. Our results demonstrate that TI stimulation significantly increases phosphene detection rates in sighted subjects, highlighting its potential to improve TES precision and effectiveness.Clinical relevanceThese findings have significant implications for the development of non-invasive neurostimulation technologies aimed at testing, restoring, or augmenting vision. The high performances of dry electrodes pave the way for more user-friendly, portable stimulation devices, reducing the reliance on cumbersome electrode preparations. Additionally, the enhancement of phosphene perception via TI suggests a pathway toward more selective, spatially targeted stimulation strategies, potentially refining TES for future clinical applications. Put together, these results contribute to the optimization of TES paradigms, bringing the technology closer to real-time, wearable neurostimulation solutions for visual rehabilitation and augmentation.

title: Multi-Channel Functional Electrical Stimulation to Improve Specificity of Hand Extension
authors: Clay T. Stanley, Marshall A. Trout, Kristen M. Saad, Fredi R. Mino, Amelia E. Nelson, Troy N. Tully, Tyler S. Davis, Jacob A. George
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: The long-term goal of this research is to improve the functionality of non-invasive transcutaneous functional electrical stimulation (FES) by improving specificity in upper extremity paralysis. Spinal cord injuries result in an estimated 10,000 new cases of upper extremity paralysis yearly. FES has been used extensively to assist and rehabilitate individuals with lower-limb paralysis, but it has not been widely adopted for upper-limb paralysis. This is in part due to the complex setup necessary to target the right combination of small muscles densely packed in the forearm to create a desired hand gesture. To address this challenge, here we introduce a new multichannel FES system that enables complex current steering with a high compliance voltage to selectively recruit small extrinsic hand muscles in isolation or in combination. Using this system with real-time motion capture data of the hand, we stimulated unique electrode configurations each second to rapidly identify a rich repertoire of hand gestures. Additionally, as an initial demonstration of the unique current steering capabilities, we show that FES involving three active electrodes, instead of the traditional 2-electrode setup, provides greater specificity and redundancy, which in turn could support more therapeutic motions and interleaved stimulation to reduce fatigue Thus, this work constitutes an important step towards more efficient, dexterous, and robust upper-limb FES to improve neurorehabilitation outcomes for people with spinal cord injuries.Clinical Relevance— A new multichannel FES system can rapidly configure FES stimulation to evoke a variety of single-digit and multi-digit hand gestures.

title: An unobtrusive PEP estimation method using hand-to-hand impedance plethysmography
authors: Emiliano Rojano-Hernández, José A. García-Limón, Jorge Enrique Baños-Bautista, Carlos Alvarado-Serrano, Ramon Casanella
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: There is currently a wide interest in developing wearable devices for the estimation of cuffless blood pressure (CBP) based on pulse transit time (PTT) measurements. However, to make the measurement more convenient for the user, many devices measure pulse arrival time (PAT), the time difference between the ECG and a distal pulse wave, typically in the hands, using, for example, photoplethysmography (PPG). The drawback of this procedure is that PAT includes not only PTT but also the pre-ejection period (PEP), which can limit the reliability of the measurements. On the other hand, the measurement of the PEP usually involves the placement of sensor elements on the torso by specialized operators, which greatly limits the measurement of this parameter outside of hospital settings. In this work, we present an unobtrusive method for the estimation of PEP using hand-to-hand impedance plethysmography (hh-IPG). To validate the feasibility of the presented approach, hh-IPG and reference impedance cardiography (ICG) signals were recorded sequentially for 2 min from 9 subjects with a wide age range. The results obtained show a strong correlation (R = 0.90) between the PEP estimate obtained with hh-IPG and the reference PEP obtained with ICG, which opens up the possibility of incorporating this measurement in a much more convenient and non-invasive way in wearable devices in the near future.Clinical Relevance— The hh-IPG method offers a non-invasive, stable, and user-friendly alternative to traditional impedance cardiography (ICG) for pre-ejection period (PEP) estimation. Its consistent performance with lower variability supports its application in wearable devices and telemedicine platforms.

title: UrbanGreen - E-Waste Detection and Analysis using YOLOv5
authors: A.R.M.S Madusanka, D.M.R.S Nawaratne, Narmada Gamage, Buddhima Attanayaka
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Business Analytics for Technology and Security (ICBATS)
abstract: E-waste has become a global concern that challenges environmental sustain ability. The disposal of electronic devices is often poorly managed, especially in urban areas. This research aims to develop an innovative e-waste management system suitable for urban areas, focusing on accurately identifying electronic devices and their harmful components through advanced image processing techniques. (Y olov5) The system identifies various electronic devices, harmful components and materials and assesses their recyclability, improper disposal's environmental and health impacts, empowering users to make informed decisions about disposal and recycling. The system will integrate tools to identify E-waste, promote the reuse of electronic devices, educate the public through interactive educational platforms, and locate nearby e-waste collection centers. By addressing these critical aspects of e-waste management, the project aims to provide a useful platform to manage e-waste effectively in urban areas. This paper was developed to discuss E-waste detection and analysis using YOLOv5 object detection model.

title: The Evolution of Fuel Cells: State-of-the-Art and Emerging Trends
authors: Emil D. Maer, Daniel Fodorean, Anamaria A. Șpaimoc
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromechanical and Energy Systems (SIELMEN)
abstract: Fuel cells (FCs) are a crucial technology in the global shift toward sustainable energy systems, providing efficient and low-emission energy conversion for a wide range of applications. This paper delivers a review of the latest advancements in FC technologies, their applications and challenges they face. It examines key types of fuel cells, such as Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cells (PEMFCs), Solid Oxide Fuel Cells (SOFCs), and others, with a focus on their performance features and industrial significance. Despite substantial advancements, obstacles such as high production costs, durability limitations, and inadequate hydrogen infrastructure continue to hinder their widespread adoption. Additionally, this paper explores emerging trends and opportunities, such as the integration of fuel cells with renewable energy systems and their use in heavy industry and transportation. By synthesizing recent innovations and outlining future directions, this study seeks to provide valuable insights for researchers, industry professionals, and policymakers working to maximize the potential of fuel cell technology.

title: AI-Powered Urban Traffic Management: an Innovative Solution for Real-Time Traffic Optimization and Congestion Control
authors: Jessie R. Balbin, Benjie T. Guiwo, Noel A. Salalila, Esperanza E. Chua, Kallista Coleen T. Antenor, Allana Kyle H. Deang, Sumin Yoo, Marlon Jim P. Garino
publish: 2024 IEEE 16th International Conference on Humanoid, Nanotechnology, Information Technology, Communication and Control, Environment, and Management (HNICEM)
abstract: This study presents an AI-based Real-time traffic control and management system data and machine learning to optimize traffic Improving the efficiency of traffic management to ensure smoother flow and reduce congestion. Simulations The system offers a marked enhancement in traffic flow and travel efficiency over conventional approaches.

title: Technological Entrepreneurship in Renewable Energy: Challenges and Opportunities in Eastern Europe
authors: Mădălina-Maria Brezuleanu, Marius Pîslaru, Andrei Mămăligă
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromechanical and Energy Systems (SIELMEN)
abstract: The transition to a renewable energy system that can be maintained in the long term requires the creation of new ways of developing business models, based on green technologies and adapted to the requirements of the circular economy. This highlights the importance of technological entrepreneurship, which plays an essential role in promoting renewable energy, especially in regions with underexploited potential such as Eastern Europe. This paper analyzes the challenges and opportunities encountered by start-ups in the field of renewable energy, starting from a qualitative analysis supported by a bibliometric one of the specialized literature and relevant public policies. The results of the analyses highlight a series of systemic obstacles in the order of unstable regulations, limited access to financing but also the lack of an efficient infrastructure, where at the same time a series of opportunities that we could consider significant were identified, such as those related to the fierce concern for the digitalization of industries but also accessing financing for green energies. The study offers recommendations that could contribute to strengthening green entrepreneurship in Eastern Europe, emphasizing the importance of cooperation between key actors and the efficient use of European resources that are already available.

title: Modeling and Control of a Single-Inductor SIDO DC-DC Converter Used in Auxiliary Power Units
authors: Pengwei Li, Ali M. Bazzi
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: This paper presents a novel single-inductor, single-input, dual-output (SIDO) DC-DC converter designed for auxiliary power supply applications in modern electronic systems. The proposed topology aims to achieve high power density and a compact layout to reduce electromagnetic interference (EMI). A comprehensive analysis is presented to address the circuit topology, switching patterns, and operating modes. Continuous conduction mode (CCM) and discontinuous conduction mode (DCM) are studied to develop a complete dynamic model and clarify the power transfer mechanism. Two control strategies, a mixed proportional-integral (PI) control and an inductor peak current control, are proposed to regulate the dual outputs in CCM and DCM conditions, respectively. It is shown that full decoupling of voltage control is achievable in DCM but limited in CCM due to inductor current sharing. Simulation results validate the theoretical analysis and demonstrate the converter's performance.

title: Modeling and Simulation of Regenerative Braking Systems Using MATLAB System Composer and Simulink
authors: Vlad-Andrei Scarlatache, Marius Andrei Olariu, Florina Scarlatache, Sebastian Aradoaei, Tudor Alexandru Filip, Madalina Petronela Simion
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromechanical and Energy Systems (SIELMEN)
abstract: Regenerative braking is a key technology in modern electric and hybrid vehicles, enabling recovery of kinetic energy during deceleration and its conversion into useful electrical energy. This paper presents the modeling and simulation of a regenerative braking system using MATLAB System Composer and Simulink. A system-level architecture is developed in System Composer to define functional components, interfaces, and data flows, while Simulink is employed for dynamic modeling and performance analysis. The integration of these tools facilitates a multi-domain representation, allowing seamless transition from architectural design to time-domain simulations. Various braking scenarios are simulated to evaluate system behavior, energy recovery efficiency, and interactions between mechanical and electrical subsystems. The results demonstrate the effectiveness of regenerative braking in improving vehicle energy efficiency and highlight the advantages of a model-based systems engineering (MBSE) approach for design, validation, and optimization. This work underscores the potential of MATLAB System Composer and Simulink as comprehensive platforms for the analysis and development of advanced vehicular energy management systems.
