title: A Supervised Contrastive Learning Approach for ECG Label Noise Learning
authors: Yixue Li, Yuchen Wang, Yongjian Li, Yiheng Sun, Meng Chen, Shoushui Wei
publish: 2025 18th International Congress on Image and Signal Processing, BioMedical Engineering and Informatics (CISP-BMEI)
abstract: Label noise is common and affects model accuracy when using deep learning for electrocardiogram (ECG) classification. To address this challenge, we propose an innovative frame-work that enhances model robustness: (1) Adding a projection layer after the generic model to extract features, and making the features from the same labeled samples more similar through supervised contrastive learning. (2) Quantifying the similarity between the feature of one sample and the features of other sam-ples, thereby accurately determining the true category and label reliability of samples. During training, the system automatically retains cleanly labeled samples, while correcting identified noisy labels using model predictions. We give reasons for using feature similarity and provide a proof for the effectiveness of our method. Experiments conducted on the MIT-BIH Arrhythmia Database and the MIT-BIH Atrial Fibrillation Database demonstrate that our method achieves competitive performance compared to state-of-the-art label noise learning approaches under both symmetric and asymmetric noise conditions, with an precision of over 90 % for clean label identification.

title: Emulation of Induction Machine Eccentricity Faults using a Voltage Behind Reactance Model
authors: Solihah Sharief Shiekh, Pragasen Pillay
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: Power hardware-in-the-loop (PHIL) is an effective testing method used for emulating faults in electric motors, enabling real-time evaluation of motor behavior under fault conditions. Eccentricity faults, a common mechanical issue, can lead to further motor failures and permanent damage if not detected early. Motor current signature analysis (MCSA) is an effective technique for detecting such faults. However, when using switched amplifier PHIL-based emulation, the presence of switching harmonics in the frequency spectrum complicates MCSA. To address this challenge, this paper develops a voltage-behind reactance (VBR) model for eccentricity faults. The model is capable of emulating both axially uniform and more complex axially non-uniform eccentricity faults under various loading conditions. Experimental validation is performed using a micro-machine of a scaled-down 2.5 MW wound rotor induction motor with eccentricity faults.

title: CGAN-Based Cross-Sectional Ultrasound Image Generation from Probe-Pose Vectors
authors: Khanabhorn Kawattikul, Kazuhiko Hamamoto
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Imaging Systems and Techniques (IST)
abstract: This work proposes a Conditional Generative Adversarial Network (CGAN)-based framework for generating realistic 2D ultrasound images conditioned on 3D ultrasound probe (US-probe) poses, including both spatial position and orientation. The dataset, acquired from a breast ultrasound phantom (BB-03), consists of 2,656 multi-view B-mode images paired with 6-degree-of-freedom US-probe parameters, providing diverse US-probe movements and orientations to ensure comprehensive multi-view coverage for training. The US-probe positions and orientations are encoded using a positional encoding scheme that enables the model to learn spatial relationships between probe placement and internal anatomy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model generates anatomically consistent grayscale ultrasound slices across diverse probe poses. Moreover, the results indicate that the proposed positional encoding method enhances the quality and realism of the synthesized images, showing improved alignment with US-probe position and orientation compared to a baseline approach. This is further reflected by consistently high Pose-Consistency Scores (PCS) ranging from 0.8766 to 0.8950. In addition, quantitative image quality assessments indicate that the synthesized images achieve performance close to the acceptable ranges across standard ultrasound evaluation metrics. Although further refinements are needed to enhance realism, these findings highlight the potential of CGAN-based frameworks for ultrasound image synthesis, where preserving both probe-dependent spatial positioning and anatomical structural consistency remains essential.

title: Technology Adoption of Electronic Control Systems in Enhancing Patient Care in the Philippines
authors: Roldeo Rien B. Asuncion, Maxine Jane S. Rodrin, Selverino A. Magon, Argel A. Bandala
publish: 2024 IEEE 16th International Conference on Humanoid, Nanotechnology, Information Technology, Communication and Control, Environment, and Management (HNICEM)
abstract: This paper explores and discusses the transformative impact of electronic control systems on healthcare optimization across various domains in the Philippines. This paper includes introductory information regarding patient monitoring, medical imaging, pharmaceutical drug delivery, robotic surgery, and digitalization of medical records, as well as the analysis of other literature covering the issues related to technology adoption. By integrating these electronic control systems, healthcare has seen remarkable improvements in patient care, operational efficiency, and error reduction. Electronic systems enable continuous monitoring, enhance diagnostic accuracy in medical imaging, ensure precision and safety in drug delivery, facilitate precise surgical maneuvers in robotic surgery, and improve healthcare service through digital medical records. Despite challenges like data privacy and interoperability, electronic systems promise interconnected, patient-centered healthcare ecosystems, leading to improved delivery and enhanced patient experience.

title: A Battery Charging System Using Ultra-Thin Nanocrystalline Laminated Magnetic Sheets
authors: Guangyu Yan, Jie Deng, Binhong Cao, Zhicheng Guo
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: “FINEMET” laminated magnetic sheets exhibit high saturation flux density and superior mechanical flexibility, which allow for very thin profiles. This article presents a battery charging system using such nanocrystalline (NC) laminated sheets with a thickness of only 0.9mm. The charging is based on a CLLC resonant converter. Constant current (CC) charging and constant voltage (CV) charging are implemented through the PI-controlled phase-shift inverter, with seamless transitions between the two modes. The experimental results validate the feasibility of the CC-CV charging strategy, achieving over 84% DC-DC efficiency during the CC stage. Furthermore, the converter can reach a peak efficiency of 94.8% at a 100 W power level. The proposed system demonstrates a promising solution for compact and high-efficiency battery charging.

title: CVCResNSFormer: An Efficient Deep Learning Model for Short-Term PV Power Forecasting
authors: Zijie Fang, Ye Yuan, Yinquan Li, Shaoping Liu, Chaoyang Tang
publish: 2025 18th International Congress on Image and Signal Processing, BioMedical Engineering and Informatics (CISP-BMEI)
abstract: With the growing integration of photovoltaic systems into smart grids, accurate power forecasting is considered essential for optimized energy management and maintained grid stability. In this study, a novel model named CVCResNSFormer is proposed to enhance short-term PV power forecasting accuracy and efficiency. The forecasting framework is primarily composed of two modules: the CVC Module and the ResBG Module. In the CVC Module, leading variables and their lead times are accurately predicted at various time nodes, enabling effective utilization of forward-looking information by lagging variables. The ResBG Module incorporates a ResNet-like architecture where both linear and non-linear features are preserved, resulting in improved simulation of future curve characteristics. Experimental validation on real-world datasets confirms the superior performance of CVCResNSFormer compared to existing deep learning approaches, particularly in terms of prediction accuracy and computational efficiency. These results suggest strong potential for renewable energy applications, providing a reliable and scalable power forecasting solution for sustainable energy systems. The model's effectiveness is quantitatively verified through two performance metrics: Mean Absolute Error (MAE) and Mean Squared Error (MSE), both indicating exceptional predictive accuracy and stability.

title: GenAU-net: Genomic Attention U-net for Lower-Grade Glioma MRI Segmentation
authors: Jihoo Chung, Jang-Hwan Choi
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Medical image segmentation is pivotal for diagnosing and analyzing brain tumors, particularly lower-grade gliomas (LGG). Accurate tumor delineation is critical for clinical decision-making and treatment planning, yet this task remains challenging due to the complex structure of brain tissues and the heterogeneity of tumor characteristics. In this paper, we propose Genomic Attention U-Net (GenAU-net), an enhanced segmentation framework that integrates genomic clustering data into the widely used Attention U-Net architecture. By incorporating patient-specific genomic information, GenAU-net achieves a more personalized approach to LGG MRI segmentation, demonstrating a DICE score of 0.827 on a public LGG dataset. Leveraging genomic data not only improves segmentation performance but also opens avenues for an individualized diagnosis and treatment strategy.Clinical relevance—This research underscores the potential of incorporating genomic information for more accurate LGG segmentation in brain MRI. By providing richer context in the segmentation process, GenAU-net could help clinicians better identify tumor boundaries, optimize surgical resection or radiation therapy plans, and ultimately guide tailored patient care, improving outcomes and survival rates.

title: Multi-RCAT modem for Small-Scale PV Systems and Renewable Energy Communities
authors: Alzbeta Kostelanska, Petr Mlynek, Lukas Benesl
publish: 2025 17th International Congress on Ultra Modern Telecommunications and Control Systems and Workshops (ICUMT)
abstract: In recent years, there has been a significant trend in the energy sector to build small-scale photovoltaic plants (PVPs). PV plants are a good tool to accelerate the drive towards zero-emission infrastructure in Europe. However, they impose significant demands on the adaptation of the existing power grid to accommodate their specific operational requirements. This paper discusses the key requirements and typical communication technologies in smart grid systems and energy communities, which can be utilized by small-scale PVPs. Based on the discussed features and challenges of small-scale PVPs, a modem prototype unit for reliable and secure communication is introduced. The proposed modem utilizes multiple wired and wireless technologies to ensure the best possible scalability and adaptability for most scenarios that may occur in typical communication scenarios.

title: Assessing Privacy Practices on Ontario Municipal Websites
authors: Adegboola David Adelabu, Yan Yan, Wenjing Zhang, Sampsa Rauti, Ville Leppänen, Zuhaibuddin Bhutto, Wenjun Lin
publish: 2025 22nd Annual International Conference on Privacy, Security, and Trust (PST)
abstract: The sharing of personal data on government websites is a major concern of daily users. The existing regulations do not allow for the collection and sharing of personal data. This study investigates the privacy practices of 444 municipal websites across Ontario, Canada, focusing on compliance with relevant data protection regulations and the extent of third-party data sharing. In particular, we examine the issues in line with Canadian standards, the Personal Information Protection and Electronic Documents Act (PIPEDA), the Canadian Privacy Act (CPA), and the Municipal Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act (MFIPPA). We perform network traffic analysis, and apply a combination of privacy policies. Our findings uncover substantial gaps in privacy practices, including insufficient transparency, inadequate user-consent mechanisms, and pervasive third-party data sharing. The results of our study highlight an urgent need for the enhancement of privacy measures on government municipal websites to protect the personal data of users and for the implementation of practices that comply with local and international privacy laws, such as PIPEDA, CPA, MFIPPA, and the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). The study provides actionable recommendations aimed at strengthening data protection and restoring public trust in digital municipal services.

title: Dual High-Frequency Signal Injection for Stator and Rotor Winding Temperature Estimation in Wound Rotor Synchronous Machines
authors: Diego F. Laborda, Lidia Sánchez, Marcos Orviz, Javier G.-A. Tiemblo, David Reigosa
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: Wound Rotor Synchronous Machines (WRSMs) offer high efficiency and rare-earth-free design, making them attractive for electric vehicle applications. However, increasing power density requirements highlight the need for accurate monitoring of both stator and rotor temperatures. This paper presents a method for estimation of both stator and rotor winding temperatures using dual high-frequency (HF) signal injection: pulsating HF current for stator and HF voltage for rotor.

title:
Pooling assessment of homing pigeons during urban and extra-urban flights: an instrumental approach
                    <sup>*</sup>
authors: Ilenia De Meis, Flavia Forconi, Daniele Bibbo, Giacomo Dell’Omo, Paolo Di Feo, Giuseppe Vannozzi, Silvia Conforto
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: The field of biologging has undergone significant advancements, enabling researchers to collect high-resolution data on a range of ecological and biological phenomena. In the context of avian studies, miniaturized biologgers have proven instrumental in investigating flight dynamics, particularly in species such as homing pigeons (Columba Livia). While earlier research has principally classified pigeon flight as either flock or solo only based on release conditions, free-flight scenarios are more complex, involving variations in route choice, pausing behavior and different pooling in comparison to original release conditions. To address this gap, a novel instrumental approach is presented in this paper to automatically detect homing pigeons’ flight type and flock size and to take into account modifications of the previous characteristics over urban and extra-urban areas, by equipping homing pigeons with wearable sensors. To deeply characterize pigeons’ flight in flock or solo condition above urban and extra-urban areas, wingbeat frequency, peak-to-peak acceleration and ground speed were computed. In comparison to the original releases conditions, in approximately a half of the total releases solo-released pigeons joined the flock and vice versa, indicating a consistent pattern to deviate from the initial release configuration, which may lead to a realistic analyses of solo or pooling behavior during flight.The results show that pigeons flying in flock exhibit a higher wingbeat frequency compared to solo flight modality, while showing an inverse pattern for peak-to-peak acceleration. Comparing urban and non-urban environments, the results show that in extra-urban contexts pigeons exhibit a reduction in wingbeat frequency when flying in flocks. Additionally, they tend to form larger flocks compared to those observed in urban settings.

title: Hybrid Neural-Kalman Filtering for Robust Battery Health Estimation
authors: Islam A. Sayed, Yousef Mahmoud
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: Accurate State of Health (SOH) estimation is essential for ensuring the reliability and longevity of lithium-ion batteries in electric vehicles (EVs). Traditional SOH estimation methods face significant challenges, including nonlinear battery degradation, sensor noise, and variations in operating conditions. Data-driven techniques, such as deep learning, offer high accuracy but require large datasets and high computational power, while Kalman filters are computationally efficient but suffer from lower accuracy. This paper is the first to apply neural network aided Kalman filter (KalmanNet) for battery SOH estimation, combining the adaptability of deep learning with the efficiency of Kalman filtering to strike a balance between accuracy and computational load. KalmanNet dynamically updates state estimates and noise covariance without requiring extensive training data or accurate battery models. The preliminary results demonstrate that KalmanNet achieves higher estimation accuracy compared to two conventional approaches, the Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) and the Sigma-Point Kalman Filter (SPKF), highlighting its potential as a promising solution for real-time battery SOH estimation.

title: Erratum to “Scalable Design of an Atomic Clock Stabilized and ML-Optimized RF Synthesizer”
authors: Sujaya Das Gupta, Sumit Ghosh, Stanley Johnson, Sankar Majhi, Sankalpa Banerjee, Subhadeep De
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Typographical unit errors were introduced in the published version that changed several occurrences of “mHz” (millihertz) to “MHz” (megahertz). The following corrections are made to the published article. 1)Abstract: “greatly enhanced to 10 MHz with ML” should read: “greatly enhanced to 10 mHz with ML.”2)Abstract: “phase drifts of 1.3 MHz” should read: “phase drifts of 1.3 mHz.” 3)Section II-C, Frequency Resolution: “The lowest frequency-tuning resolution of 100 MHz” should read: “The lowest frequency-tuning resolution of 100 mHz.”4)Section II-C, Frequency Resolution: “10-MHz frequency-tuning resolution” should read: “10-mHz frequency-tuning resolution.”5)Section II-C, Frequency Drifts: “drift of 1.3 MHz over 24 h” should read: “drift of 1.3 mHz over 24 h.”6)Section IV, Conclusion: “with its 10-MHz frequency” should read: “with its 10-mHz frequency.”

title: Maximizing Power Density in SiC Inverters: Copper-Diamond Composite Embedded Power Modules with Advanced Local Cooling Strategy
authors: Da Zhou, Zhiqiang Wang, Kangyong Li, Yu Liao, Cheng Qian, Neng Wang, Guoqing Xin, Xiaojie Shi
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: In order to explore the high power density potential of SiC-based converters for the next-generation applications, in this paper, a power-dense 3-phase inverter using the innovative SiC power modules and enhanced direct liquid cooling technology is elaborately developed. First of all, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$a 1.2 \text{kV}/120 \mathrm{A} \text{SiC}$</tex> half-bridge power module in a low-inductance package and embedded with copper-diamond composite is proposed and manufactured, with the intention of providing both fast switching speed and minimal thermal resistance for the power stage. Second, a sophisticated direct liquid cooling strategy utilizing the manifold microchannel heatsinks is implemented to improve the heat dissipation uniformity among 3-phase power semiconductors. Finally, a prototype inverter that incorporates these state-of-the-art techniques is built, demonstrating continuous operation with a rated output power of 75 kW and reaching a gravimetric power density above 60 kW/kg, marking a significant advancement for SiC inverters without the help of multi-MOSFET parallel technology.

title: EEG-Based Analysis of Breakfast’s Impact on Cognitive Performance Using Earth Mover’s Divergence
authors: Dhakshinesh Anandh, Muthukumar K A, Priya Ranjan, Soumya Gupta
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Cognitive performance, particularly focus and attention, is critical for academic success, and lifestyle factors such as breakfast consumption significantly influence these functions. However, existing studies often rely on subjective measures, leaving a gap in objective, quantitative assessments. To address this, we propose a novel framework, Optimal Representative Selection via Earth Mover’s Divergence (ORS-EMD), which leverages Earth Mover’s Divergence (EMD) to objectively quantify the impact of breakfast on cognitive performance using electroencephalogram (EEG) signals. The ORS-EMD framework computes pairwise dissimilarities between EEG segments using EMD, identifies optimal representative segments for each group, and classifies new EEG segments as healthy (breakfast-consumed) or unhealthy (breakfast-skipped) based on a divergence thresholding rule. Our results demonstrate that breakfast consumption significantly enhances cognitive performance, as evidenced by faster task completion times (6.1 ±0.5 minutes for the breakfast group vs. 8.3 ±0.7 minutes for the no-breakfast group, p < 0.001) and distinct neural activity patterns. The ORS-EMD framework achieved an accuracy of 92.5%, outperforming traditional methods such as time-domain features (85.3%) and frequency-domain features (88.7%). This study provides a quantitative, evidence-based framework for understanding the impact of breakfast on cognitive performance, highlighting the potential of EEG-based analysis in real-world educational and healthcare settings.

title: A Secure Framework for Automated Question Generation and Examination Protection Using Natural Language Processing(NLP) and Multilayer Encryption
authors: Mohammed T. Abdulhadi, Doaa T. Kadhim, Rafeef A. Hameed
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Business Analytics for Technology and Security (ICBATS)
abstract: Academic integrity in digital education is increasingly threatened due to the unauthorised access and sharing of examination content. These practices enable cheating, compromise fair assessment processes, and damage the credibility of educational institutions. The shift to online learning environments has exacerbated these challenges, as traditional methods of ensuring the security of exams are less effective in digital settings. This growing issue necessitates robust solutions to safeguard exam materials and maintain equity in the evaluation process. This research introduces a novel framework that integrates NLP-driven question generation with Shamir's Secret Sharing and multi-layer encryption, combining the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{T 5}$</tex> model and advanced cryptographic methods to securely and efficiently manage academic assessments. The system involves a pre-trained T5 transformer model for automated generating high-quality, contextually relevant questions, minimising work in preparing an examination. These questions have been divided into multiple shares with the help of Shamir's Secret Sharing Scheme, which has a predefined threshold to reconstruct them. Each share is encrypted with algorithms like AES, Blowfish, and ChaCha20 to enable robust multi-layer protection. Results showed strong performance for the system as indicated by BLEU and ROUGE1 competitive scores in question generation and efficient encryption/decryption times. Share generation took about 0.0005 seconds, while reconstruction took about 0.0056 seconds. This framework scales well, is secure, and efficient for protecting examination content by ensuring fairness and integrity when conducting online assessments.

title: Temperature Compensation Control System and Pseudocode Algorithm for Next Generation 6G Microstrip Antennas
authors: Fredelino A. Galleto, Aaron Don M. Africa, Rhen Anjerome Bedruz, Marnel Peradilla, Ann E. Dulay, Raphael Karlo S. Santiago, Ej Garett D. Sosa
publish: 2024 IEEE 16th International Conference on Humanoid, Nanotechnology, Information Technology, Communication and Control, Environment, and Management (HNICEM)
abstract: Next-generation networks, such as 6 G antenna designs, are focused on meeting the demands of future wireless networks. This study aims to design a system for controlling the temperature in microstrip antennas so that it can provide its best performance under changing environmental conditions. Due to the antenna's small size and simplicity of integration into PCBs, they can be integrated into mobile phones and satellite communications. However, they are sensitive to temperature changes. As a result of these changes, the resonant frequency will shift, and impedance mismatches will occur, leading to impacts on the antenna's performance. The substrate material chosen was Teflon due to its excellent dielectric properties. Simulations in MATLAB were carried out along with the Antenna Designer tool to comprehend a pseudocode algorithm on how temperature affects the dimensions and performance of an antenna. The simulations showed that when the temperature increased, there was a change in the dielectric constant, which in turn caused a decrease in both the width and length of the patch substrate. Adding a controller to adjust the height of the substrate helped keep a high antenna gain and achieve a 3 GHz resonance frequency at all times as the dielectric constant shifts. The results enabled the development of the proposed hardware implementation for the antenna design.

title: Comparative Analysis of CHIL, PHIL, and Dyno Testing for ePowertrain and System Validation
authors: Akm Arafat, Davis Trapp, Mitch Ober, Raef Aidibi
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: Modern high-performance electric drive systems demand validation workflows that balance fidelity, safety, and development speed. This paper presents a three-stage validation framework using 1) Control Hardware-in-the-Loop (CHIL), 2) Power Hardware-in-the-Loop (PHIL), and 3) dynamometer-based testing and evaluates their mutual correlation for a commercial inverter–motor system. In the CHIL stage, a real DSP-based control board executes motor-inverter algorithms against a real-time plant simulator incorporating FEA-derived motor models. In the PHIL stage, the simulated plant is replaced by a physical inverter interfaced through a power amplifier to the real-time simulator, capturing non-ideal electrical interactions. Finally, the dynamometer stage couples the actual inverter and motor on a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$100-\text{kW}$</tex> test cell to provide ground-truth performance data under steady-state and transient operating conditions. Across a matrix of tests including torque–speed sweeps, step and sinusoidal speed transients, and efficiency mapping–the CHIL and PHIL predictions agree with dynamometer measurements within <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 2 \%$</tex> for torque and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 0.05 ~\mathrm{s}$</tex> for dynamic response. Discrepancies are analyzed in terms of interface latency, model simplifications, and measurement uncertainties. The proposed workflow shortened overall development time by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 30 \%$</tex> and reduced prototype cost compared to a purely dyno-based approach. These results confirm that well-calibrated HIL techniques can deliver reliable early-stage validation, guiding design refinement and minimizing risk before full-scale prototyping.

title: Dynamic Reliability Allocation of Ship Electronic Information System Based on CF model and BWO Algorithm
authors: Jingli Yang, Ying Wang, Wenmin Wang
publish: 2024 15th International Conference on Reliability, Maintenance and Safety (ICRMS)
abstract: Current research on the reliability allocation of ship electronic information systems often overlooks the challenges posed by dynamic changes in system structure due to the diversity of task models. To address this issue, we developed an optimization model for dynamic reliability allocation within ship electronic information systems. This model leverages the Certainty Factor (CF) model and the Beluga Whale Optimization (BWO) algorithm to achieve dynamic reliability allocation. First, the CF model is employed to assess the global weights of each component within the system. Additionally, the BWO algorithm retains some historical solutions when generating the initial population, allowing it to adapt to varying reliability allocation requirements across different task models. The effectiveness of the proposed method is validated through simulation experiments.

title: Detection of Synchronous Reluctance Motor Coupling Unbalance via Vibration and Current Analysis
authors: Angela Navarro-Navarro, Jose E. Ruiz-Sarrió, Vicente Biot-Monterde, Jose Antonino-Daviu
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: This paper analyzes vibration and current signals to detect unbalance faults in a Synchronous Reluctance Motor (SynRM), focusing on unbalanced coupling. Experimental tests were performed under controlled laboratory conditions, evaluating two levels of unbalance severity at different load conditions and rotational speeds. The analysis focuses on the evolution of key spectral components associated with the rotor rotational frequency in both vibration and current signals. Results indicate that vibration measurements at the rotational frequency consistently increase with unbalance severity. In contrast, current signal components also reflect fault progression but exhibit greater sensitivity to operating conditions. These findings support the feasibility of using current signal analysis alongside vibration monitoring to enhance fault detection in rotating machinery.

title: A Low-Noise High-Frequency Power Supply Based on Linearly-Operated MOSFETs for EMF Reduction in WPT Systems
authors: Shunsaku Nomoto, Keisuke Kusaka
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: Wireless power transfer (WPT) systems generate leakage magnetic fields due to their operating principle. Therefore, minimizing harmonic electromagnetic fields (EMF) is crucial to comply with standards published by CISPR. A WPT system utilizing a flying-capacitor linear amplifier (FCLA) has been proposed to mitigate radiation noise. However, only low-power experiments had been conducted using the FCLA with the number of MOSFETs limited to two. This paper proposes a high-frequency FCLA with a controller configuration that allows function at high frequencies while minimizing voltage distortion through an open-loop control method that excludes feedback components. Moreover, the gate driver with digital input isolates multi-stage MOSFETs, enabling a high-power output from the FCLA. Experimental results show that the 3.1 kW WPT system employing a 30-series FCLA and a three-level rectifier achieves 91.3% DC-DC efficiency. Moreover, the prototype decreases the third-order harmonic component of radiation noise by 16.0dB compared to the conventional H-bridge-based WPT system with a square-wave output.

title: Entropy analysis of diaphragmatic EMG signals as an indicator of extubation viability in mechanically ventilated patients
authors: Alejandro Arboleda, Manuel Franco, Liliana Valladares, Francisco Naranjo, Beatriz F. Giraldo
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Surface electromyographic (sEMG) signals from the diaphragm has become a valuable tool for monitoring muscle activity during the weaning process from mechanical ventilation. However, EMG signals are inherently nonlinear and susceptible to noise contamination, which poses challenges for traditional signal processing methods. In this study, we propose the use of entropy metrics to evaluate the dynamic complexity and irregularity of surface electromyographic (EMG) signals of patients assisted with mechanical ventilation. Shannon entropy and spectral entropy were computed to analyze EMG signals from two surface diaphragm channels recorded in mechanically ventilated patients during extubation preparation. According to clinical criteria, the patients were classified into the successful group (GE) – 19 patients with successful extubation after 48 hours, and the failure group (GF) – 21 patients who required reconnection to the ventilator within 48 hours. sEMG signals were recorded using 5-channel surface electrodes placed around the diaphragm muscle. Shannon and spectral entropies were calculated using a 0.5-minute window with an overlap of 80%. The results presented a greater complexity of the EMG signal in the SG group. This group shows higher peaks in Shannon entropy and elevated spectral entropy values compared to the FG group. Channels 2 and 3 presented the largest statistically significant differences.Clinical Relevance— Analyzing diaphragm EMG signals using entropy metrics could improve patient outcomes by optimizing the timing of extubation. These metrics would serve as a key indicator of readiness for extubation, providing an objective basis for more informed clinical decision-making.

title: Design Optimization and Scaling of Coreless AFPM Machines Using Hybrid FEA-Based Differential Evolution and Machine Learning
authors: Matin Vatani, David R. Stewart, Donovin D. Lewis, Dan M. Ionel
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: This paper presents a machine learning (ML)-based design framework for the fast and accurate optimization of coreless axial flux permanent magnet (AFPM) machines. Although the absence of magnetic cores eliminates material nonlinearity, the design process remains highly nonlinear due to the complex influence of geometric parameters. To overcome the computational challenges of finite element analysis (FEA)-based optimization, a series of multi-objective differential evolution (MODE) optimizations were conducted across various machine sizes at constant power output. The resulting design data was used to train an artificial neural network (ANN), enabling rapid prediction of machine performance without the need for repeated FEA simulations. Case study results indicate that values of torque constant can be predicted with satisfactory accuracy, even for designs of a different size from the simulated set used for training. The proposed ML framework can significantly reduce design time and computational burden, providing a practical tool for efficiently exploring the design space in the optimization process.

title: Effect of Electrotactile Stimulation on Local Peripheral Hemodynamics
authors: Liuni Qin, Yinshen Huang, Mingyang Dou, Jiabin Yang, Hui Wang, Guanglin Li, Yanjuan Geng
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) has emerged as a promising, non-invasive sensory feedback approach in neurorehabilitation. However, its modulatory effect on local peripheral hemodynamics has been seldomly investigated by far. This study aims at exploring how the electrotactile stimulation on fingertip affect the participant’s local blood perfusion volume (BPV). 14 healthy volunteers participated in the experiment. The results showed a decrease of peripheral BPV regardless of the tactile sensations types, which were elicited by regulating the pulse frequencies (PF) and pulse amplitudes (PA) concurrently. In terms of four time-domain BPV features, significantly stronger temporal BPV response occurred when increasing either PF or PA (p-value<0.05). And the PA demonstrated more pronounced effect on the BPV response compared to the PF and the interaction effect of PF and PA. This study may facilitate researcher to better understand peripheral microvascular function related to sensory-motor pathways, and offer fundamental basis for the application of TENS in neurorehabilitation.Clinical Relevance— This study may shed valuable insights into how the sensory-level TENS modulates local peripheral blood perfusion, which provides fundamental basis for the application of TENS in neurorehabilitation.

title: Computational Modeling of NMDAR-Mediated Calcium Dysregulation in Hippocampal Dendritic Spines in Alzheimer's Disease
authors: Shyam Pranav G, Amritanshu Gupta
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Disruptions in calcium (Ca<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>⁺) signaling play a central role in neurodegenerative processes, particularly in Alzheimer’s Disease (AD), where Aβ pathology alters synaptic function. This study presents a computational framework integrating an NMDAR model into an existing astrocyte calcium signaling model adapted for hippocampal dendritic spine to examine the effects of Aβ-induced Ca<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>⁺ dysregulation. The model incorporates NMDAR-mediated Ca<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>⁺ influx, ER calcium dynamics (IP3Rs, RyRs, SERCA pumps, buffering), to simulate pathological Ca<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>⁺ signaling. Results indicate that Aβ increases NMDAR burst probability and conductance, leading to sustained cytosolic Ca<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>⁺ elevation, further influenced by ER-mediated Ca<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>⁺ release, which contributes to calcium imbalance. Elevated glutamate levels are also observed to exacerbate these effects. The study further examines possible modulatory mechanisms, suggesting that changes in NMDAR kinetics and calcium-buffering capacity may influence intracellular Ca<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>⁺ stabilization. Findings highlight the complex interplay between glutamate signaling, ER stress, and NMDAR dysfunction in synaptic calcium dysregulation. The model is constrained by physiological values and the range of values for the model outputs are validated where possible with experimental studies. The model provides a framework for investigating potential mechanisms underlying disruptions in calcium homeostasis in AD and could be extended to study CaMKII activation pathways, synaptic remodeling dynamics, and calcium-binding proteins to enhance its predictive capabilities and broader applicability in understanding AD pathology.Clinical Relevance— Aβ-driven calcium dysregulation is implicated in early synaptic dysfunction in AD, making it a potential target for therapeutic strategies. Insights from this model may help in exploring how modulating NMDAR activity, ER calcium regulation, and calcium-buffering proteins could influence synaptic stability offering directions for future research into neuroprotective strategies for AD.

title: Improving Food Image Recognition with Noisy Vision Transformer
authors: Tonmoy Ghosh, Edward Sazonov
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Food image recognition is a challenging task in computer vision due to the high variability and complexity of food images. In this study, we investigate the potential of Noisy Vision Transformers (NoisyViT) for improving food classification performance. By introducing noise into the learning process, NoisyViT reduces task complexity and adjusts the entropy of the system, leading to enhanced model accuracy. We fine-tune NoisyViT on three benchmark datasets: Food2K (2,000 categories, ~1M images), Food-101 (101 categories, ~100K images), and CNFOOD-241 (241 categories, ~190K images). The performance of NoisyViT is evaluated against state-of-the-art food recognition models. Our results demonstrate that NoisyViT achieves Top-1 accuracies of 95%, 99.5%, and 96.6% on Food2K, Food-101, and CNFOOD-241, respectively, significantly outperforming existing approaches. This study underscores the potential of NoisyViT for dietary assessment, nutritional monitoring, and healthcare applications, paving the way for future advancements in vision-based food computing. Code for NoisyViT for food recognition is publicly available.

title: A Low-Voltage DC-DC Converter with Integrated Vehicle-to-Load (V2L) Circuit for Hybrid Electric Vehicles (HEVs)
authors: Gyeong-Hyun Kwon, Dong-In Lee, Yeonho Jeong, Han-Shin Youn
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: This paper proposes a low-voltage dc-dc converter to enable vehicle-to-Ioad (V2L) for hybrid electric vehicles (HEVs). In the proposed converter, the primary switches of a low-voltage dc/dc converter (LDC) are integrated with the boost converter switch and diode in the V2L circuit, thereby reducing the number of components and overall system complexity. This approach improves power density while reducing cost and volume. The validity of the proposed converter is experimentally verified using a hardware prototype operating over a high-voltage (HV) input range of 200–400 V, delivering 2 kW to a low-voltage (LV) output of 12–15 V and 1 kW to an external 220 V ac load. The proposed converter achieves simultaneous operation efficiency exceeding 93.1 % under all tested conditions.

title: PWM-Controlled ZVS Technique for Efficiency Optimization in Boost Operation of Series Resonant Converter
authors: Jaehyeok Jang, Yujin Shin, Jongwoo Kim, Donghyuk Yang, Heonhee Kim, Younghoon Cho
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: This paper focuses on the zero-voltage switching (ZVS) challenges and synchronous rectifier (SR) issues that arise during boost operation in series resonant converters (SRCs). Resonant converters are widely adopted in electric vehicle (EV) charging systems due to their high efficiency and high-power density. As the EV battery voltage increases from 400 V to 800 V, the ability of resonant converters to support a wide output voltage range becomes a significant advantage. Among them, SRCs are preferred due to their inherently low primary-side circulating current resulting from a large magnetizing inductance. Optimal efficiency is achieved by operating near the resonant point. However, the SRC is fundamentally limited to a maximum voltage gain of unity. To extend the output voltage range while maintaining high efficiency, pulse-width modulation (PWM) control is employed. By reconfiguring the secondary-side full-bridge rectifier into a voltage-doubler structure, the voltage gain curve can be effectively doubled. This enables both wide output voltage range and high efficiency. However, under PWM operation, the inherently low magnetizing current of the SRC results in insufficient energy to achieve ZVS, which leads to increased switching losses and reduced efficiency. Furthermore, improper turn-off timing of the synchronous rectifier (SR) can cause additional power losses or even device failure. To address these limitations, this paper proposes a control strategy that enables full-range ZVS operation in PWM-controlled SRCs, thereby achieving high efficiency and robust performance across a wide output voltage range.

title: Video Summarization and Fracture Detection in Pediatric Wrist Ultrasound Using Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Shrimanti Ghosh, Geetika Vadali, Yuyue Zhou, Ayush Singh, Jessica Knight, Christopher Keen, Mahesh R. Panicker, Abhilash R. Hareendranathan, Jacob L. Jaremko
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Wrist fractures are common injuries among children, significantly impacting daily activities and contributing to prolonged wait times in emergency departments. Portable ultrasound is a safe, radiation-free, and cost-effective diagnostic tool with real-time imaging capabilities to identify these fractures. Ultrasound (US) videos offer dynamic, detailed views for fracture detection but can be lengthy and redundant, making interpretation time-consuming for clinicians. To address this challenge, we developed a novel video summarization and fracture detection method using Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL). The DRL agent emulates a human expert by analyzing the entire video, selecting diagnostically relevant frames, and leveraging a CNN to classify these frames as either normal or fractured. The reward mechanism, which prioritizes feature similarity and frame dissimilarity, enhances the agent’s ability to identify the keyframes. Anisotropic diffusion is applied to US images to enhance bright bony regions, before feature extraction and representativeness calculation. Frame similarity calculations are parallelized to reduce computational complexity, storage demands and simplify the classification task by focusing solely on frames indicative of fractures. On a dataset of 114 patients, the proposed classification network achieved an accuracy of 88.8% with a sensitivity of 92.5% and a specificity of 86.6% using the RL-generated video summaries. Our primary focus is on enhancing sensitivity to ensure that no fractured cases are missed. This performance surpasses the 84.4% accuracy achieved with full video classification. AI-driven ultrasound, with its efficiency, and reduced computational demands, provides a promising solution for early disease detection in resource-constrained environments.Clinical relevance— This AI-driven fast, cost-effective ultrasound tool achieves high accuracy and sensitivity while reducing training time by 50%, making it suitable for real-time clinical use on low-power devices. This can assist lightly-trained healthcare providers in early disease detection, reduce long wait times, and enhance treatment access in remote areas.

title: A Conditional Gaussian Mixture Model for Battery SOH Estimation with Uncertainty Quantification
authors: Isaiah O. Oyewole, Meriam Chelbi, Wael Hassanieh, Youngki Kim, Abdallah Chehade
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: Accurate state-of-health (SOH) estimation is crucial for ensuring the reliability and safety of lithium-ion batteries. However, traditional machine learning and deep learning models often assume a unimodal distribution of degradation characteristics, which limits their ability to generalize across different battery types and operating conditions, resulting in biased predictive performance and weak uncertainty quantification. This work proposes a Conditional Gaussian Mixture Model (CGMM) to address these challenges by modeling degradation data of aged battery cells as a weighted combination of Gaussian components, effectively capturing diverse degradation characteristics of multi-battery datasets. For SOH estimation of test battery cells, even at the beginning-of-life, Bayesian statistics is utilized to adaptively update the parameters of the trained GMM based on newly observed data. The proposed CGMM was trained and tested on a publicly available accelerated aging battery dataset. Experimental results demonstrate that CGMM outperforms benchmark models, showcasing its improved accuracy, adaptability, strong generalizability, and reliable uncertainty quantification.

title: Smooth Adjustment of Switching Frequency of Triple PWM Inverters of Transformer-Based PV System
authors: Valentin Oleschuk
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electromechanical and Energy Systems (SIELMEN)
abstract: This paper presents a comparative analysis of the operation of a photovoltaic (PV) inverter unit consisting of three voltage source inverters with synchronous pulse-width modulation (PWM). The inverters are controlled by flexibly adjusting their switching frequency based on the current magnitude of the dc voltage of the corresponding PV strings. Such smooth adjustment of the switching frequency of inverters allows for a reduction in harmonic distortion of the winding voltage of the power transformer. Continuous and discontinuous schemes of synchronous space-vector PWM for smooth regulation of inverters are investigated. Simulation results are provided to verify the analyzed control and modulation strategy.

title: Improving SOC and SOT Estimation Using Time-Dependent Reversible Heat Generation Analysis and Kalman Filtering
authors: Seongkyu Lee, Youngwoo Son, Seunghyun Lee, Umar Jamil, Woonki Na, Jonghoon Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: Batteries are essential components in various applications, such as electric vehicles (EVs) and energy storage systems (ESS), and they operate under a wide range of environmental conditions. These batteries are highly sensitive to temperature changes. At high temperatures, accelerated aging and reduced stability can occur, while at low temperatures, undesirable side reactions such as reduced output and slower diffusion may arise. To ensure optimal performance and safety, it is crucial to maintain battery operation within an ideal temperature range of 15-35°C. This study aims to quantitatively analyze the heat generation characteristics of batteries prior to designing an effective cooling system. To evaluate the initial characteristics of the battery, Hybrid Pulse Power Characterization (HPPC) tests were conducted. In addition, reversible heat generation—one of the key factors influencing thermal behavior—was analyzed to support the development of advanced thermal management strategies.

title: Removing motion artifacts from mechanomyographic signals: an innovative filtering method applied to human movement analysis
authors: Matthieu Correa, Nicolas Vignais, Isabelle A Siegler, Maxime Projetti
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Mechanomyography (MMG) is a promising tool for measuring muscle activity in the field but its sensitivity to motion artifacts limits its application. In this study, we proposed an adaptative filtering method for MMG accelerometers based on the complete ensemble empirical mode decomposition, with adaptative noise and spectral fuzzy entropy, to isolate motions artefacts from the MMG signal in dynamic conditions. We compared our method with the traditional band-pass filtering technique, demonstrating better results concerning motion recomposition for deltoid and erector spinae muscles (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.907 and 0.842). Thus, this innovative method allows the filtering of motion artifacts dynamically in the 5-20 Hz bandwidth, which is not achievable with traditional method. However, the interpretation of accelerometric MMG signals from the trunk and lower-limb muscles during walking or running should be approached with great caution as impact-related accelerations are still present, though their exact quantity still needs to be quantified.

title: Effect of the use of wheelchair bags on the kinetic and kinematic aspects of manual propulsion
authors: R. T. Monteiro, E. T. Tobaro, F. O. Medola
publish: 2025 47th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBC)
abstract: Handrim propulsion is the main means of independent mobility with manual wheelchairs. Biomechanical studies have indicated that manual propulsion exposes the users to the risk of injuries due to the loads on the upper limbs. Wheelchair configuration and the use of accessories may affect propulsion efficiency by altering total mass and weight distribution. This study explores the effect of using wheelchair hanging storage bags on manual propulsion forces and kinematics. Twenty participants performed two mobility tasks – straight motion and circular trajectory – in four different wheelchair configurations: conventional; and with a hanging storage bag with 5kg in front of the seat, behind the backrest and on the rear wheel spokes. Propulsion forces and motion data were collected with the Smartwheel, an instrumented wheel that is attached in substitution of the regular wheel. In general, the results showed that the addition of a 5kg bag and the place it was installed both affected propulsion forces and kinematics. In the start-up phase of the straight motion, propulsion forces were higher with the bag attached in front of the seat (79.43N first push, 83.62N 3rd push) and lower in the standard (55N 1st push, 56.26N 3rd), while in the steady-state motion both average (45.60N) and peak (64.14N) forces were greater with the bag attached on the rear wheel rim. Kinematic data – propulsion frequency, velocity and push angle – were also influenced by the added mass and its place but with greater variation of the results. The current study provides additional knowledge on the effect of using accessories on manual wheelchair propulsion efficiency. Wheelchair users, provisioners and therapists should consider the potential effect that using – and where to attach - accessories on the wheelchair may impose on propulsion efficiency and the biomechanical loads for the user.Clinical Relevance— Understanding how weight distribution impacts manual wheelchair propulsion is important to optimize mobility performance and reducing physical strain of wheelchhair users. This study highlights how added weight position influences propulsion effort and maneuverability, providing knowledge that may support clinicians in prescribing and customizing wheelchairs.

title: Comparative Thermal Analysis of Mixed Hybrid Rare-earth and Ferrite Magnet Asymmetric IPMSMs with Symmetrical Rare-earth IPMSMs for EV applications
authors: Ankan Dey, Z.Q. Zhu, Seyedmilad Kazemisangdehi, Dawei Liang, Liang Chen, Lei Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE Energy Conversion Conference Congress and Exposition (ECCE)
abstract: This paper assesses the operational performance of a mixed hybrid (ferrite + rare-earth (RE)) permanent magnet (PM) asymmetric (MHPMA) interior PM synchronous machine (IPMSM) against a benchmark REPM-based symmetrical IPMSM (S-IPMSM), considering the influence of different cooling strategies, including jacket cooling (JC) and oil spray cooling (OSC). The continuous torque capabilities of both IPMSMs are evaluated over the full speed range using finite element analysis and computational fluid dynamics, accounting for thermal constraints of the REPMs and winding insulation, as well as PWM-induced losses. In addition to steady-state conditions, the thermal analysis is extended to transient operations to evaluate temperature profiles during city, freeway, and hybrid (city + freeway) driving cycles. It is found that significantly reduced RE PM eddy current losses in MHPMA-IPMSM allow for the relief of REPM thermal stress under steady-state operation, using only JC, whereas the S-IPMSM requires additional OSC for similar high-speed performances. Furthermore, across various driving cycles, the MHPMA-IPMSM maintains comparatively lower REPM and end-winding temperatures, effectively mitigating thermal stress in electric vehicle applications and suggesting a potentially longer operational lifespan and enhanced reliability.

title: Intelligent Metasurface-Enabled Integrated Sensing and Communication: Unified Framework and Key Technologies
authors: Shunyu Li, Tianqi Mao, Guangyao Liu, Fan Zhang, Ruiqi Liu, Meng Hua, Zhen Gao, Qingqing Wu, George K. Karagiannidis
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications
abstract: As the demand for ubiquitous connectivity and high-precision environmental awareness grows, integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) has emerged as a key technology for sixth-generation (6G) wireless networks. Intelligent metasurfaces (IMs) have also been widely adopted in ISAC scenarios due to their efficient, programmable control over electromagnetic waves. This provides a versatile solution that meets the dual-function requirements of next-generation networks. Although reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RISs) have been extensively studied for manipulating the propagation channel between base and mobile stations, the full potential of IMs in ISAC transceiver design remains under-explored. Against this backdrop, this article explores emerging IM-enabled transceiver designs for ISAC systems. It begins with an overview of representative IM architectures, their unique principles, and their inherent advantages in EM wave manipulation. Next, a unified ISAC framework is established to systematically model the design and derivation of diverse IM-enabled transceiver structures. This lays the foundation for performance optimization, trade-offs, and analysis. The paper then discusses several critical technologies for IM-enabled ISAC transceivers, including dedicated channel modeling, effective channel estimation, tailored beamforming strategies, and dual-functional waveform design.

title: Uncertainty-Aware Decisioning for Robust Delivery Zone Partition in Last-Mile Logistics
authors: Yinfeng Xiang, Lidi Zhang, Yinqian Zhang, Chao Li, Shibo He, Haotian Wang, Jiming Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: In last-mile logistics, robust delivery zone partitioning is critical for ensuring timely service and maintaining a positive courier experience. However, existing network-structured spatial partitioning strategies often fail to address heterogeneous uncertainties in both delivery demand and courier supply. In particular, two challenges remain: (i) irregular demand patterns with weak periodicity, and (ii) stochastic courier availability. To this end, we propose the Prediction and Sampling Then Optimization (PSTO) paradigm, which integrates hybrid uncertainty modeling with Monte Carlo optimization. Specifically, we implement a model named RobustDZP, which combines time-series prediction with residual learning for demand estimation, a multi-agent RL sampler for supply estimation, and an iterative perturb-and-vote algorithm for partition optimization. Extensive experiments on a large real-world dataset from JD Logistics demonstrate that our approach improves delivery timeliness by over 16.3% and significantly outperforms baselines under stress tests. Furthermore, we present a real-world case study to validate the practical effectiveness of our framework and highlight key lessons for designing robust and well-received partition schemes.

title: Robust Face Recognition via Adaptive Mining and Margining of Noise and Hard Samples
authors: Yang Xin, Xiang Zhong, Yu Zhou, Jianmin Jiang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Image Processing
abstract: At present, deep face recognition models working on millions of images are confronted with the challenge that such large-scale datasets are often corrupted with noises and mislabeled identities yet most deep models are primarily designed for clean datasets. In this paper, we propose a robust deep face recognition model by exploiting the advantage of integrating the strength of margin-based learning models with the strength of mining-based approaches to effectively mitigate the impact of noises during training. By monitoring the recognition performances at a batch level to provide optimization-oriented feedback, we introduce a noise-adaptive mining strategy to dynamically adjust the emphasis balance between hard and noise samples, enabling direct training on noisy datasets without the requirement of pre-training. With a novel anti-noise loss function, learning is empowered for direct and robust training on noisy datasets yet its effectiveness over clean datasets is still preserved, sustaining effective mining of both clean and noisy samples whilst weakening its learning intensiveness over noisy samples. Extensive experiments reveal that: (i) our proposed achieves competitive performances in comparison with representative existing SoTA models when trained with clean datasets; (ii) when trained with both real-world and synthesized noisy datasets, our proposed significantly outperforms the existing models, especially when the synthesized datasets are corrupted with both close-set and open-set noises; (iii) while the existing deep models suffer from an average performance drop of around 20% over noise-corrupted large scale datasets, our proposed still delivers accuracy rates of more than 95%. Our source codes are publicly available on GitHub.

title: Development and Initial Evaluation of 3D-Printed High Resolution Brain Phantom for PET_supp1-3638588.docx
authors: Takuya Toyonaga
publish: N/A
abstract: Phantoms are essential for assessing PET system performance, but most existing brain phantoms do not provide the anatomical fidelity required for the next-generation high-resolution PET systems. To address this limitation, we developed HYDRA-OL (HYDrodynamically filled Realistic Anatomy of the Occipital Lobe) phantoms using high-resolution 3D printing based on the BigBrain atlas. In this study, two phantom types were created, HYDRA-OLG (gray matter only) and HYDRA-OLGW (gray and white matter), enabling contrast modulation between gray matter (GM) and white matter (WM). Precise anatomical fidelity and repositioning accuracy were confirmed via CT. A custom closed-loop filling apparatus ensured efficient and reproducible phantom preparation. Residual air in the phantom after 15 minutes was estimated to be less than 0.01% of the fillable space. To compare spatial resolution between scanners, the HYDRA-OLG phantom was imaged on four different PET systems (NeuroEXPLORER (NX), HRRT, Vision, and Focus220), with NX and Focus showing superior spatial resolution compared to the other two systems. To generate variable GM:WM contrast, list mode datasets obtained on the NX for both HYDRA-OLG and HYDRA-OLGW phantoms were down-sampled and merged to form one list mode data. Reconstructed images were successfully produced with GM:WM contrast ratio of 4:1, 2:1, and 4:3. Overall, the HYDRA phantom platform is a versatile tool for accurately representing human brain anatomy. It is likely to be more useful than previous phantoms for evaluating image resolution and optimizing reconstruction parameters for next-generation brain PET systems.

title: A Novel Robust Cooperative Localization Method under Delay/ Loss Measurement and Unknown Non-stationary Noise.
authors: Yalin Fei, Bo Xu
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: In Autonomous Underwater Vehicles (AUVs) cooperative localization (CL), due to the variation of sensor performance with the environment, it is difficult to determine the accurate noise covariance, and the measurement noise may be time-varying with heavy tails. At the same time, in underwater acoustic communication, delays and packet loss occur randomly, which limits the reliability and accuracy of the CL system. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a new robust CL filtering algorithm that can handle time-varying delays/losses measurements and unknown non-stationary non-Gaussian noise. First, a new integrated framework for measurement loss detection and compensation in CL system has been established. Then, the probability density function (PDF) of the measurement likelihood with measurement loss/delay and non-Gaussian noise is modeled as a mixture of two skewed Gaussian (MTSG) distributions. Furthermore, a VB(Variational Bayes)-based method was proposed to achieve the state estimation of the system, treating the state, noise covariance matrix, and auxiliary random variables as estimation variables, while using the inverse Wishart distribution to model the unknown noise covariance matrix, addressing the impact of imprecise noise statistical information on the system. Finally, real lake experiments are conducted to verify the effectiveness and superiority of the algorithm.

title: A Self-Refining Framework for Intracranial Primary Tumors Diagnosis
authors: Zishuo Wan, Haibin Wan, Runting Li, Dabiao Zhou, Dawei Ding
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Accurate preoperative MRI diagnosis of intracranial primary tumors is critical for surgical planning and therapeutic decision-making. This study addresses two fundamental limitations of MRI-based diagnosis: the inherent class imbalance and resolution variations. To address these issues, we propose a novel self-refining framework that integrates three key innovations: (1) panoptic segmentation for unified representation of tumors and brain anatomy, (2) patch-wise cross-modality attention enabling adaptive feature fusion from multi-modal MRI, and (3) a dynamic loss function that automatically rebalances learning to prioritize rare tumor subtypes. Our method achieves state-of-the-art performance across multiple evaluation metrics, demonstrating consistent superiority over existing architectures while maintaining robustness to varying image resolutions. These technical advances can translate to clinical benefits, including improved detection of diagnostically challenging cases, anatomically plausible tumor segmentation for surgical planning, and reduced dependence on uniformly high-resolution scans, making the framework particularly valuable for real-world clinical deployment.

title: Exploiting Multimodal Knowledge Graph for Multimodal Machine Translation
authors: Tianjiao Xu, Xuebo Liu, Derek F. Wong, Yue Zhang, Lidia S. Chao, Min Zhang, Tian Gan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Multimedia
abstract: A neural Multimodal Machine Translation (MMT) system utilizes multimodal information, particularly images, to enhance traditional text-only models and achieve superior performance. However, the effectiveness of MMT heavily depends on the availability of extensive collections of bilingual parallel sentence pairs and manually annotated images, which poses a challenge due to the scarcity of such pairs. To address this issue, we propose incorporating the Multimodal Knowledge Graph (MMKG) for data augmentation in MMT. By utilizing MMKG as an additional source of knowledge, we can overcome the limitations of existing sentence-image pairings. This allows us to expand the original parallel corpus and generate corresponding images, creating new synthetic data pairs that facilitate effective data augmentation. Experiments conducted on two translation datasets, Multi30k and IKEA, demonstrate that the proposed MMKG enhancement method significantly improves performance across multiple baseline methods, ultimately outperforming all baseline approaches. Additionally, experiments under low-resource conditions reveal that our method achieves exceptional enhancement effects in low-resource corpora, surpassing other data augmentation baseline methods. These results indicate the efficacy and potential of the proposed method for enhancing the performance of multimodal models across diverse datasets.

title: SSPD: Spatial-Spectral Prior Decoupling Model for Spectral Snapshot Compressive Imaging
authors: Lizhu Liu, Yaonan Wang, Yurong Chen, Jiwen Lu, Hui Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Multimedia
abstract: Coded aperture snapshot spectral imaging (CASSI) captures 3D hyperspectral images (HSIs) in a single shot by encoding incident light into 2D measurements. However, recovering the original hyperspectral data from these measurements is a severely ill-posed inverse problem due to significant information loss during compression. Recent deep learning methods, especially deep unfolding networks, have demonstrated promising reconstruction results by embedding learnable priors into iterative optimization frameworks. However, most existing approaches use a single network to jointly estimate spatial and spectral priors, limiting their ability to handle the distinct properties of HSIs. To overcome this limitation, we propose the Spatial-Spectral Prior Decoupling Model (SSPD), which reformulates HSI reconstruction as a prior absorption problem, enabling independent modeling of spatial and spectral priors with specialized network architectures. To achieve this, we design two attention mechanisms tailored for hyperspectral data: one for capturing spatial correlations and another for preserving spectral signatures. Additionally, we develop a hybrid loss function that combines convergence constraints and cross-prior interactions, ensuring accurate prior fusion and stable reconstruction. Experiments on synthetic and real-world datasets confirm that SSPD outperforms existing methods in spectral snapshot compressive imaging.

title: On the Adversarial Robustness of Learning-based Image Compression Against Rate-Distortion Attacks
authors: Chenhao Wu, Qingbo Wu, Haoran Wei, Lei Wang, Fanman Meng, King Ngi Ngan, Li Zhuo, Hongliang Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Multimedia
abstract: Despite demonstrating superior Rate-Distortion (RD) performance, Learning-based Image Compression (LIC) algorithms have been found to be vulnerable to malicious perturbations in recent studies. However, the adversarial attacks considered in existing literature remain divergent from real-world scenarios, both in terms of the attack direction and bitrate. Additionally, existing methods focus solely on empirical observations of the model vulnerability, neglecting to identify the origin of it. These limitations hinder the comprehensive investigation and in-depth understanding of the adversarial robustness of LIC algorithms. To address the aforementioned issues, this paper considers the arbitrary nature of the attack direction and the uncontrollable compression ratio faced by adversaries, and presents two practical rate-distortion attack paradigms, i.e., Specific-ratio Rate-Distortion Attack (SRDA) and Agnostic-ratio Rate-Distortion Attack (ARDA). To the best of our knowledge, we are the first to conduct joint rate-distortion attacks on LIC algorithms. Using the performance variations as indicators, we evaluate the adversarial robustness of eight predominant LIC algorithms against diverse attacks. Furthermore, we propose two novel analytical tools for in-depth analysis, i.e., Entropy Causal Intervention and Layer-wise Distance Magnify Ratio, and reveal that hyperprior significantly increases the bitrate and Inverse Generalized Divisive Normalization (IGDN) significantly amplifies input perturbations when under attack. Lastly, we examine the efficacy of adversarial training and introduce the use of online updating for defense. By comparing their advantages and disadvantages, we provide a reference for constructing more robust LIC algorithms against the rate-distortion attacks.

title: Analysis and Control of Semi-Markov Jump Linear Systems Under Persistent Disturbances via Full Utilization of Fragmentary Kernel
authors: Zepeng Ning, Wei Xing Zheng, Xunyuan Yin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cybernetics
abstract: This article treats the problems of the stability, boundedness, and stabilizing control of discrete-time semi-Markov jump systems (SMJSs) with fragmentary semi-Markov kernel (SMK) under persistent disturbances. Since the statistical characteristics of stochastic processes are difficult to describe precisely and comprehensively, the available SMK information may be fragmentary, and only a portion of the information is known. Regarding this problem, we propose new approaches that leverage all the known SMK information and derive new criteria for analysis and control. The feasibility therein can be enhanced compared to the existing approaches with inadequate utilization of the known SMK information. Additionally, a polytopic approach is proposed to approximate the unknown portion of the SMK information to enrich the information available for subsequent analysis and control design. This is achieved through constructing a polytopic quadratic Lyapunov-like function (LF), which further improves the feasibility. In this way, both the available information and the approximated unknown part about the SMK are incorporated. Meanwhile, the ultimate boundedness of the closed-loop semi-Markov jump linear system (SMJLS) is ensured in the mean-square sense without requiring the deviation between the state and its nominal one to converge at all times. We illustrate the validity and superiority of the proposed approach through a numerical example and a simulated chemical process example using a machine learning-based surrogate model.
